content: Place in a large, heavy-bottomed pot and cover with cold water.  Bring to a gentle simmer and cook until tender.  Drain into an ice bath.  Remove skin and cut into 1/2 inch pieces.
Toss with potatoes, place in a large zipper bag, and refrigerate overnight.
Combine in a large mixing bowl.  Then, add the potatoes and toss to combine.  Refrigerate for at least one hour and serve.
Preheat oven to 450 F.
Combine in food processor.
Cut into cubes and add to dry goods.  Pulse food processor until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Add to the dry goods and mix until just combined.  Adjust, if necessary, until the mixture is very wet. It will be very tacky; do not add more flour.

On a lightly floured work surface, pat the dough by hand into a 1/2 inch thick mat; then, fold it in half 4-6 times.  Pat it once more by hand until it is 1 inch thick.  Cut into rounds using a small round cutter.  Place the cut biscuits on a cookie sheet and bake for 10-12 minutes, or until light golden brown.
Grind all ingredients to a fine powder and keep for up to 8 weeks.
Preheat oven to 375 F with a rack in the middle.
Combine in large bowl and set aside.

Shave a small amount off the bottom of each apple so that they will sit flat while baking.  Cut a half inch off the top of each apple and cut a one and a half inch space into the core without piercing the bottoms or sides.
Melt in a large skillet over medium heat.  Brown the cut side of each apple, flip over, and fill with the reserved filling.  Replace the apple tops.
Add to skillet and transfer to oven.  Bake until tender, 35-40 minutes, basting with the liquid every 10 minutes.
Preheat oven to 375 F.
Melt over medium heat in large ovenproof skillet.
Add to skillet and cook for about ten minutes, or until the carrots are tender but not browned.
Add and bring to a boil.  Remove from heat, cover the carrots with a parchment round, lid the skillet, and place in the oven for 30 minutes or until the carrots are very tender.  Serve.
Cook in a 10-inch saute pan over medium-high heat until crisp and brown.  Remove bacon and set aside, reserving 1 tbsp of the fat in the pan.
Reduce heat and cook until semi-translucent - about 3 minutes.
Add and cook for one minute.
Combine in a separate lidded pot and cook over high heat until tender.  Drain.
Add, with the sprouts, to the apple mixture and cook just until the sprouts are heated through.
Stir in off heat and serve.
Combine and set aside for ten minutes.
Whisk into garlic & lemon mixture
Add while whisking to emulsify.
Add to dressing
Cut into 3/4 inch pieces, rinse, and dry the lettuce.  Toss with the dressing.
Toss with the salad and serve immediately.
Combine and set aside.
Toss together in large bowl, ensuring bread absorbs water.

Add to large skillet and brown bread over medium heat.  Once the bread is browned, clear a space in the center of the pan.  Add garlic & oil mixture and cook very briefly, until the garlic is fragrant.
Add and toss to distribute.
Grind well in a spice grinder.
Add to ground mixture and store in an airtight container.

Combine in an old fashioned glass and add a few drops of water.  You must use superfine or confectioners sugar; otherwise, it will not dissolve in the liquid and it will sit unattractively and uselessly at the bottom of the glass.
Add and stir until the sugar is dissolved.  Add ice cubes and stir with a spoon until the drink is well chilled.
Garnish and serve.
Add to a mixing glass filled with ice.  Stir until very cold; then, strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Twist over cocktail to express oils; then, rub on rim of glass and drop into drink.  Serve.
Combine in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until very cold.  Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Twist over surface, add to drink, and serve.
Combine in a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until very cold.  Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Add and serve.
Heat in a medium saucepan over medium heat for about five minutes.
Add and stir to dissolve; then, cook until the mixture becomes syrupy - about another five minutes.
Stir in and cook for another two minutes.  Remove from heat, let cool to room temperature, and pour into a container.
Add, shake to combine, and use immediately, or cool and store for up to a month in a plastic squeeze bottle.
Combine in a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake until well chilled.  Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Twist over drink to express oils, add to cocktail, and serve.
Combine with ice and stir until well chilled; then, strain into a chilled cocktail glass and serve.
Add to cocktail shaker and stir until sugar is dissolved.
Add with ice to cocktail shaker and shake until very well chilled.  Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish and serve.
Run lime around the rim of a rocks glass, dip the glass in salt to crust, and set aside.
Combine in a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake until very well chilled.  Strain into prepared glasses.
Garnish and serve.
Run lemon around rim of glass; then, dip in the sugar to crust.  Chill until needed.
Combine in a cocktail shaker and shake until well chilled.  Strain into prepared glasses.
Garnish and serve.

Combine in a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake until very well chilled.  Strain into a champagne flute - note that you must use superfine sugar; otherwise it will not dissolve.  Also note that the champagne flute is important, because the proportions of this drink are partly based on the size of the serving glass.
Add champagne to flute to top.
Garnish and serve.
Rub lemon on rim of glass to wet; then, dip the rim in celery salt to form a crust.  Garnish the glass with the lemon wedge, fill it with ice, and chill until it is needed.
Add to cocktail shaker with ice and shake until very well chilled.  Strain into prepared glass.
Garnish and serve.
Place in large bowl and cover with water by at least two inches.  Soak overnight; then, drain.
Mix ingredients in a large bowl.  Process through the medium die of a food grinder.
Add to the chickpea mixture, stir to combine, and add more flour if the dough is not sticky enough to form balls.  Cover and refrigerate for two or more hours.
Add oil to a dutch oven and heat to 375 F.

Scoop chickpea mix into walnut-sized balls, and fry them, six at a time, in the heated oil, for a few minutes per side or until golden brown.  Drain on paper towels and serve with pita and fresh vegetables.
Mix with a wooden spoon until smooth and well-combined.
Mix in until the mixture becomes a shaggy mass; then, knead the dough for 10 minutes.
Preheat oven to 500 F with a stone and rack in its top position.  Line a plate with a clean kitchen towel and set aside.
Punch down the dough, transfer it to a floured work surface, and cut into six even pieces.  Cover with a damp towel and rest for 10 minutes.
Roll each dough ball into a 7-inch round without tearing the disks or making them uneven.  Place the disks on a floured surface, cover with a damp towel, and rest for 20 minutes.

Place the pitas on the hot stone and bake for 3 minutes or until slightly golden around the edges.  Store cooked pitas on the towel-lined plate.  To serve, blacken them very slightly in a hot cast-iron skillet.
Combine in a bowl and let stand for 5 minutes.

Process in a blender for 30 seconds or until finely ground.  Remove the bread from the water and lightly squeeze it.  Add it to the blender along with all but 3 cups of the soaking water.  Set aside the remaining soaking water.
Add to blender and process until the consistency of cake batter; 30-45 seconds.

Add in a thin, steady stream while blender is running.  Add reserved soaking water and process for 1 minute.  Adjust with salt and pepper.  Pass soup through a fine mesh strainer.  Press on solids and then discard them.
Mix with 1 tbsp of soup in a separate container.  Return 1 teaspoon of the almond extract mixture to the soup; discard the rest.  Chill for at least 3 hours or up to 1 day.
Heat in an 8-inch skillet until shimmering.
Add to oil and cook until golden brown; 3-4 minutes.  Transfer to a bowl and add 1/4 tsp salt.
Ladle the soup into shallow bowls and add grapes, toasted almonds, and extra virgin olive oil to each bowl.  Serve.
Bring just to a simmer in a large saucepan.
Whip to a slightly lightened color.

Whip into the eggs until the mixture falls off the whisk in long ribbons when the whisk is suspended a foot above the bowl.  Slowly stir in 1/3 of the hot cream mixture; then, return the egg mixture to gentle heat and cook until slightly thickened or nappe, 170 degrees.  Cool for 30 minutes.

Add to cooled mixture and stir to combine.  Chill for at least 4 hours, or until temperature is below 40 degrees F.  Process in an ice cream maker.  For soft-serve, serve immediately; alternatively, set in freezer for 2 hours and serve.

Add, with tomatoes cut-side up, to sheet pan lined with foil and lightly oiled.  Roast for 25-30 minutes or until tomatoes are soft but not browned.  Remove shallot and garlic after 15 minutes; peel and reserve garlic.  Cool all completely.
Add to blender with roasted tomatoes.  Process 30 seconds or until smooth.
Drizzle in a slow, steady stream while blender runs.  Press mixture through a strainer and discard the solids.
Add to tomato mixture and refrigerate for 2-24 hours. Stir to recombine, add extra vinegar, oil, and fresh ground black pepper, and serve.
Heat oven to 400 and heat chiles in 12-inch skillet until fragrant, 2-3 minutes.  Turn frequently to avoid burning.  Transfer to a medium saucepan.
Add to toasted chiles and bring to a boil; then, immediately remove from heat.  Let stand 5 minutes.
Add to broth mixture
Heat oil in skillet until shimmering; then, add onions and cook until translucent; 5 minutes.
Add and cook until fragrant; 1 minute.  Transfer half of onion mixture to a bowl and set aside.
Add to remaining onion mix and simmer until tomatoes start to brown; 3-5 minutes.  Add to broth mixture and process with an immersion blender until smooth.  Add salt to taste.

Heat oil in skillet until shimmering.  Add beef and seasonings to skillet and brown, breaking beef into chunks.  Add reserved onion mixture and continue to cook until beef is thoroughly browned, 3-4 minutes.  Return to bowl that contained the reserved onion mixture.
Add to beef mixture along with 1/4 cup of sauce.  Stir to combine and salt to taste.  Spread 1/2 cup of sauce on bottom of 13 X 9 baking dish.
Brush both sides of all tortillas lightly with oil.  Arrange tortillas on baking sheet and bake about 5 minutes, or until warm and flexible.

Add 1/4 cup filling to each tortilla.  Roll each tortilla tightly around filling and place, seam side down, in two rows in baking dish.  Spread the remaining sauce over the tortillas.  Add cheese and bake until it is lightly browned, about 15 minutes.
Add scallions and cilantro to dish, and serve with sour cream and limes.
Add to bowl and toss to coat.  Drain, reserving juice.
Add to avocados and mash using a potato masher or a fork.
Fold into avocado mash along with the reserved lime juice.  Let sit at room temperature for 1 hour.  Serve.
Combine in a small saucepan and bring to a simmer.  Cook until thickened and syrupy, 8-10 minutes.
Whisk with a pinch of sugar until foam supports soft peaks.
Whisk until combined.  Gently fold in the whipped egg white.

Melt in a small nonstick skillet and cook until foaming subsides.  Add the egg mixture and cook undisturbed until mixture is mostly set.  Gently flip with a wide-headed spatula and cook for one more minute.  Add berry filling to center, fold omelet over filling, and serve with creme fraiche.
Preheat oven to 425.  Lightly oil a 13X9 pan.
Spread on a sheet pan and toast in the oven for about 4 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent burning.
Place in bain marie (a large mixing bowl set over simmering water).  Stir until marshmallows are melted, about 5 minutes.
Add very quickly along with the toasted puffed rice.  Using an oiled spatula or oiling your hands, spread the mixture evenly into the oiled pan.  Cool completely and cut into squares.
Beat until smooth and slightly lightened
Beat into egg yolks and continue beating until yolks are light yellow and fall off whisk in long, smooth ribbons
Add to yolk mixture
Beat until foamy but still liquid
Add to whites and beat until stiff peaks form.  Fold gently into yolk mixture
Add and serve
Bring to a boil in small saucepan
Combine in separate, heavy saucepan.  Temper in 1/4 cup of the hot milk, stir to combine, and then slowly add the remaining milk.
Add and bring to a boil, whisking continuously.  When the mixture reaches the consistency of yogurt, continue cooking for 1 more minute.  Remove from heat and discard cinnamon stick.

Stir into hot mixture; keep stirring until butter is completely dissolved.  Strain the custard into a large bowl.  To serve hot, add to bowls immediately; to serve cold, refrigerate for at least four hours or until gelled.
Add to top of individual cups and serve.
Combine in large container and set aside.
Melt in a large dutch oven until foamy
Add to butter and cook until translucent, 5-7 minutes.
Add to pot and cook, breaking up large pieces, until well-browned, about 15 minutes.
Add to pot and cook until well-browned, 5-7 minutes, breaking meat into small pieces.
Add and cook for 2 minutes
Add and cook until alcohol is boiled off, about 5 minutes, continuously scraping bottom of pot to dissolve browned bits
Add to meat and stir in reserved broth, making sure to include reconstituted gelatin.  Bring to a low simmer.

Stir into pot and simmer until sauce is thickened and you can see the bottom of the pan after dragging a spoon through it, about 3 hours.  Discard bay leaves and any fat that has pooled on the surface.
Add along with more salt to taste.  Use right away, refrigerate for up to a week, or freeze for up to several months.
Melt in medium saucepan.
Add and cook until lightly browned, 5 minutes.
Stir in and cook until fragrant, about 1 minute.  Remove from heat.
Add and return to simmer, cooking until alcohol is removed from sauce, about 10 minutes,
Optionally, puree the sauce with an immersion blender if you prefer it smooth.
Stir into sauce and heat until just warm, 2 minutes.  Add salt to taste.  Serve immediately, refrigerate for up to a week, or freeze for up to several months.
Toss together in a large bowl and set aside.

Heat in large skillet until shimmering.  Add reserved shells and cook until all pink, about 5 minutes.  Remove and discard the shells, taking care to reserve the oil.

Return the skillet to the heat and add the shrimp, cooking until lightly browning, about 3 minutes.  Transfer the shrimp to a plate and set aside.
Add to skillet and return to medium heat.  Cook until fragrant and garlic is beginning to brown, about 3 minutes.
Add and cook until mostly evaporated.
Add and bring to a simmer.  Add salt to taste.
Bring to a boil while preparing the rest of the recipe.

Cook in the large pot of boiling water until al dente.  Drain, reserving 1 cup of the cooking liquid.  Add pasta to the sauce along with a splash of the cooking water to loosen.  Add the shrimp and simmer until the sauce reduces and can cling to the pasta.  Use more of the reserved pasta water to loosen the sauce if it becomes too dry.  If necessary, add more salt to taste.
Stir into sauce and serve immediately.

Combine and stir into a paste.  Coat the meat side of the rack with the paste.  Place in a heavy baking pan, coated side up, and roast for 20-25 minutes or until golden brown on the outside but still pink on the inside.  If the bones are browning or smoking, cover them with aluminum foil.  Carve into chops and serve two to each guest.
Preheat oven to 500 F.
Heat in large dutch oven until melted.
Add and reduce heat to low.  Cook until soft but not browned, 10-15 minutes.
Add along with salt and pepper, and bring to a boil.  Reduce to a simmer and cook for 15 minutes, or until potatoes are falling apart.  Discard bay leaf.
Remove potatoes from soup and process soup with an immersion blender until it is very smooth, about 2 minutes.  Return the soup to the clean pot.
Press potatoes through a potato ricer into the soup.
Whisk into soup and bring to a simmer, whisking continuously.
Whisk into soup and finish seasoning with salt and fresh black pepper.  Serve immediately.
Combine in a saucepan and bring just to a boil.  Remove from heat, cover, and steep for 1 hour.
Return mixture to a boil and immediately strain into a large, heatproof bowl, pressing lightly on solids.
Slice directly into hot cream using a mandoline on 1/8 inch setting.  Stir to coat.
Grease a 2-quart baking dish.  Preheat oven to 300 F.

Set aside half the grated cheese.  Lay potatoes on bottom of dish in a single layer, then add some of the cheese.  Continue in this way until the potatoes and half the cheese have been used up.  Pour the remaining milk mixture over the cheese.  Bake until potatoes are tender and surface is slightly brown, about 1 1/2 hours.
Top with reserved cheese mixture and broil until nicely and evenly browned.  Rest for 30 minutes and serve.
Combine in a large saucepan and bring just to a simmer.
Whip until smooth and slightly lightened.

Add to yolks and whip until light yellow and falling off the whisk in long ribbons.  Temper in 1/3 of the cream mixture, stir to combine, and add the remaining cream mixture.  Whisk to combine thoroughly and return to the saucepan over medium heat.
Add to mixture and bring temperature to 170 F, or until just thick enough to coat the back of a spoon.  Remove from heat and steep for 30 minutes.  Strain into a large bowl.

Stir into strained base and refrigerate until cool enough to process, usually at least 4 hours. Cover with plastic wrap only after mixture is cool enough not to form condensation.  Once cool, process in an ice cream maker and serve or freeze.
Preheat oven to 350 F.
Heat in a large, oven safe saucepan
Add to saucepan and sweat until onions are translucent but not browned, about 5 minutes.
Add and cook until fragrant, about 1 minute.
Add and turn the heat up to high.  Bring to a boil.
Add, while whisking, until incorporated. Cover the pot and place it in the oven, stirring every 10 minutes, until the polenta is creamy, about 40 minutes total.
Add and stir until completely incorporated.
Add and stir in until incorporated. Serve immediately, or place in the refrigerator to set. If setting and serving later, cut into squares and saute to serve.
Toss together and let sit for 30 minutes at room temperature. Preheat oven to 300 F.
Add to large, heavy dutch oven, and brown the beef in batches, taking care not to overcrowd the pan.

Add to pot with all the beef. Transfer to oven and cook until tender, about 2 1/2 hours.  Stir the pot after 1 hour.  Remove the beef and strain the sauce. Remove excess fat from the sauce and return to the now-clean pan.
Add to sauce and bring to a boil, reducing until it is the consistency of cream, about 15 minutes.

Dissolve the cornstarch in the wine; then, add to the sauce and cook gently just until the cornstarch thickens. Adjust the sauce with salt; then, add the beef back to the sauce and serve once it is just warmed through.
Melt in large dutch oven until foamy.

Add to dutch oven and cook over medium-high heat until tender, about 10 minutes. Reduce heat to medium-low and cook, stirring frequently, until onions are sweet and dark brown; this will take an hour or two. If the onions are on the verge of burning, add a little water to the pot and scrape the bottom.
Add and cook until alcohol is boiled off, about 2 minutes.
Add and bring to a simmer over higher heat; then, reduce heat back to medium-low and simmer for 20 minutes.
Add to pot while discarding thyme and bay. Adjust salt and pepper to taste.
Toss together. Puree in a blender until smooth; then, pass through a fine mesh strainer. Working quickly to avoid browning of the cherries, process in an ice cream maker and transfer to freezer.
Butter each slice of bread; then, rub each slice with a clove of garlic until it is fragrant.

Spoon a small amount of broth into the bottoms of four ovenproof soup bowls. Add one slice of toast to each bowl and top with some grated cheese. Add more broth and onions to nearly fill the bowl; then top each bowl with another slice of toast, pushing them down until they are nearly submerged. Top the bowls with the remaining cheese.
Place the bowls on a rimmed baking sheet and move the sheet under the broiler, cooking until the cheese is melted and browned, 1-3 minutes.
Garnish and serve.
Bring to boil in a small saucepan and reduce to 1/4 cup. Strain.
Pour onto a large, solid work surface and create a large well in the middle.

Add to center of well along with 1 tbsp of the saffron liquid. Work flour and liquid together from the center of the well using a fork. When the dough has come together, knead it for 10 minutes; the result should be firm and elastic. If the dough is too tacky, add a little extra flour. Wrap tightly in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes; then, process in a pasta press.
Place in a sous vide bag and vacuum seal. Place in a large pot of boiling water and cook until tender, about 20 minutes. Remove from bag and place in blender.

Add to blender with apples and puree until completely smooth. Pass through a fine-mesh strainer and chill over ice, stirring to prevent premature freezing. Process in an ice cream maker and freeze immediately.
Combine in a medium saucepan on medium heat. Bring to a strong simmer, or just under a boil.
Add and combine with a hand mixer. Strain and cool over ice, stirring to prevent premature freezing. Freeze in an ice cream maker and transfer to a freezer.
Place in bowl of food processor.
With the food processor running, slowly drizzle in the oil and continue blending until it is fully emulsified.
Add to mayonnaise and store for up to 3 days.
Preheat oven to 350 F.
Place bananas on a baking sheet, place in the oven, and roast until the bananas are brown and runny, about 30 minutes. Peel them and add to blender.
Add to blender and process until smooth. Strain.
Stir into mixture and chill over ice, stirring to prevent premature freezing. Process in an ice cream maker and move to freezer to set.
Whisk together in a small pan. Set in a larger container filled with ice.
Soak in cold water for 10 minutes.
Line a large cast-iron skillet with heavy-duty aluminum foil. Place the charcoal in the pan and set over high heat until the coals are white-hot.

Drain the applewood chips, and place 3/4 of them over the coals until they begin to smoke. Once smoking, place the skillet in the oven on the bottom or lowest rack (do not turn the oven on). Place the creme fraiche with its ice bath on the highest oven rack that will accommodate it. Taking care the the creme fraiche remains chilled, smoke for 2 hours, adding reserved applewood chips if the smoke begins to subside. Remove creme fraiche to an airtight container and store for up to 3 days.
Rinse under cold, running water for 5 minutes, and place in a large stock pot. Proportions of backs and necks are not important; total should be 10 lbs.
Add to stock pot and bring to a simmer over medium heat. Do not boil. Once simmering, skim foam and fat from surface.
Add to stock pot.
Add to a sachet and place in the stock pot.

Simmer the stock for 3 hours, skimming every 30 minutes. Strain and chill over ice to prevent spoiling. Use immediately, move to the refrigerator for up to 3 days, or move to the freezer for up to a month.
Beat together in a very large bowl until the yolks are lightened in color and fall of the whisk in long ribbons.
Combine in a separate container and beat slowly into the yolk mixture.
Move mixture to stopper-top bottles and store in the refrigerator for at least two weeks and up to a year.
Add and serve.

For the sauce: Place tomatoes in a fine mesh strainer, reserving the liquid, and crush them with your hands. Transfer the tomatoes to a food processor with the olive oil, garlic, sugar, salt, oregano, and red pepper flakes, and process for 30 seconds or until smooth.
Spread 1 tbsp olive oil onto a 9-inch pie pan. Transfer the dough to the greased pie pan and press into an 8-inch round. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 12-24 hours.
Combine in a cocktail shaker with no ice and shake for 20 seconds to thoroughly combine.

For the dough: using a wooden spoon, stir together flour, salt, and yeast. Add warm water and mix until the flour is mostly moistened. Knead with your hands for about 1 minute or until the dough forms a sticky ball.
Melt in medium saucepan over medium heat.
Add and cook until onions are softened but not browned, 5-7 minutes.

Add and increase heat to high. Bring to a simmer, and cook, covered, on medium-low heat, until the carrots are very tender, 20-25 minutes. When the soup is done cooking, process it to a very smooth consistency with an immersion blender.
Add and stir into soup.
Add and serve.
Preheat oven to 400 F.
Use to grease an 11 X 17 baking dish.

Trim off leaves and trim curds into evenly-sized, small pieces. Place in a bowl covered with a plate and microwave, covered, for 5 minutes. Rest covered for 5 minutes and uncovered for an additional 5 minutes.
Combine in a large bowl
Microwave for 30 seconds and add to cheddar mixture. Rub the steamed cauliflower to break it into florets and stir into the cheddar mixture. Add to greased baking dish and bake for 20 minutes.
Sprinkle on the cauliflower and broil for about 5 minutes, or until bubbly and browning. Rest for 10 minutes and serve.
Toss together in large bowl and refrigerate for 30 minutes.
Remove chicken, reserving soy sauce. Add chicken, skin-side down, to a large nonstick skillet. Cook over medium-high heat for 7-10 minutes or until browned.
Whisk into reserved soy sauce.

Remove chicken from skillet and discard excess rendered fat. Return chicken to skillet, skin side down, and add coconut milk mixture. Simmer, uncovered, for 20 minutes; then, flip the chicken and continue to cook for another 15 minutes. Remove the chicken when it has reached an internal temperature of 175 degrees.
Remove the chicken to a place and reduce the sauce until it is thick enough to coat the back of a spoon. Pour the sauce over the chicken.
Add to the chicken and serve.
Whisk in medium saucepan until combined.

Add and stir to combine. Bring just to a simmer, stirring to prevent scorching, and remove from heat.

Note: for substitution purposes, 2 cups of whole milk plus 2 cups of heavy cream can be used in place of the 3 cups of half-and-half plus one cup of heavy cream.
Whisk in a large bowl until slightly lightened in color.

Whisk into the yolks until the mixture is lightened in color and falls off the whisk in long ribbons. Temper in 1/3 of the cream mixture and stir to combine; then, add the remaining cream mixture and whisk until thoroughly combined. Return to gentle heat and cook to 170 degrees F. Cool for 30 minutes.

Whisk into mixture and add to refrigerator, covering after 1 hour to prevent condensation on the lid or covering. Cool for at least 4 hours and then process in an ice cream maker. For soft-serve consistency, serve immediately; for firmer consistency, freeze overnight.
Beat together in a small bowl.
Spin in food processor until almonds are finely ground, 20 seconds.
Add to food processor and pulse to combine.
Add and pulse to combine.

With processor running, drizzle in egg mixture until it is fully incorporated. Process for another 15 seconds, or until the dough forms a ball. Transfer to a large sheet of plastic wrap and form into a roughly 6-inch disk. Refrigerate for at least 30 minutes or up to several days.
Place disk between two sheets of plastic and roll out into an 11" diameter circle. Refrigerate once more, on a baking sheet, until firm again, about 15 minutes. Preheat oven to 375 F.

Oil tart pan if not nonstick. Press dough into prepared pan and line dough with aluminum foil, oiled on the dough side to prevent sticking. Fill the foil with pie weights and bake for 25 minutes, rotating halfway through. Remove the foil and weights and bake for another 10 minutes or until the crust is golden brown. Remove and cool the crust, and reduce the oven heat to 250 F.
Simmer in a small saucepan until solids are dissolved.
Place in heatproof bowl and pour in the hot cream mixture. Cover for five minutes; then, whisk gently until smooth.
Add to chocolate mixture and whisk until smooth.

Pass through  a fine mesh strainer and into the chocolate; whisk until fully incorporated. Pour the mixture into the tart pan; pop any bubbles on the surface with a fork. Bake for 30-35 minutes or until just starting to crack. Cool completely.

Supreme the citrus: cut away all the peel from the flesh of the fruit; then, cut the fruit wedges from between the membranous dividers. Alternatively, dissolve 1/8 tsp pectic enzyme in 1 gallon of water, peel the citrus, place it in the pectic solution, and place the solution in the refrigerator for several days or until membrane is completely dissolved.
Bring to simmer together over medium heat. Remove from heat.
Add to hot cream mixture, rest for 5 minutes, and whisk to incorporate.
Add and combine until glossy. With the tart at room temperature, pour the mixture into its center and tilt to distribute. Eliminate any bubbles.
Add to center of still-wet glaze.
Toss with fruit and let sit for 15 minutes in a strainer set over a bowl.
Melt in saucepan.
Add and toast, moving constantly, until fragrant, 2-3 minutes. Transfer to a paper-towel-lined plate and set aside.
Drain fruit, reserving juice, and transfer to a platter. Drizzle with olive oil.
Shake together with 2 tbsp of reserved juice in a small, lidded mason jar.
Toss together with dressing; arrange on top of fruit and top with toasted pecans. Serve.
Preheat oven to 425 F with 12-inch skillet on bottom rack.
Roast, cut-side up, until dry and tender, about 15 minutes.
Toss with roasted cherries and set aside for 5 minutes.
Combine and sprinkle over cherries; toss to coat.
Whisk together until smooth and pale, about 1 minute.
Incorporate into egg mixture; whisk until completely smooth.
Whisk into egg mixture.

Add to hot skillet from oven and tilt to distribute. Quickly add the batter while the pan is still hot. Distribute the cherries evenly throughout the batter and return to the oven until the mixture is completely cooked through, about 20 minutes. Cool on a wire rack for 15 minutes.
Sprinkle evenly over clafoutis. Optionally, caramelize the sprinkled sugar with a kitchen torch. Serve.
Cut a sandwich bag down the sides to unfold it into a long rectangle. Line a large plate or your counter with 2 damp dish towels.
Mix together in large bowl.
Stir into dough with a spatula. Using your hands, form into a soft dough, adding water 1 tbsp at a time until the dough is the consistency of putty. Cover and set aside for 5 minutes.
Heat in 8-inch nonstick skillet until shimmering. Wipe the pan with a paper towel so that only a thin layer of oil remains.

Scoop 1 oz balls from the dough. Place on one half of the opened sandwich bag, fold the other half over, and press with a glass pie plate or casserole to form 6" tortillas. Cook in the skillet for 30 seconds on one side, 1 minute on the other, and a final 30 seconds on the first side. Serve immediately or store in a zip-top bag for up to a few days.
Combine and bring to a boil in a large saucepan. Reduce to a simmer and cook for 5 minutes.
Add and simmer for 15 minutes, or until cranberries have burst and the mixture is slightly thickened. Cool for 5 minutes.
Preheat oven to 350 F.
Add and spoon into a mold. Serve immediately or refrigerate for at least 12 hours to set.
Divide ingredients evenly among 4 ramekins.
Sift together in a bowl.

Combine in another bowl and pour in four even batches into ramekins over peaches. Cook for 20-25 minutes. Once done, extract by running a paring knife around the boundary of the cake and overturning each ramekin onto a plate. Serve alone or with ice cream.
Preheat oven to 400 F.
Wash and place in a roasting pan. Cook, uncovered, for about an hour, or until a knife slides easily into the center. Peel and cut each into coarse chunks. Cool.
Add to food processor with beets and process into a smooth paste, 1-2 minutes. Transfer to a large mixing bowl.
Add and stir in, adding more salt if necessary.
Add to top of puree along with more olive oil to taste. Serve.
Combine in a nonreactive bowl, cover, and macerate in the refrigerator for 3 days.
Mash the raspberries and strain them to remove solids. Measure the resulting liquid, and for every 1/2 cup, add 1/2 lb of sugar. Add sugar and liquid to a medium saucepan.
Simmer gently for 15 minutes. Cool and keep in a squeeze bottle for up to 3 months.
Cut into a 10" diameter circle and cut a small hole in the center of the circle.
Bring to a simmer in a 12-inch skillet over medium heat.
Remove pan from heat, add carrots in a single layer, and cover with a parchment round. Cover with parchment round and pan lid and let stand for 20 minutes.

Bring back to simmer with no lid, but leaving the parchment in place. Simmer over medium-low heat until the water is almost all evaporated and the carrots are tender, about 45 minutes. Discard the parchment, increase the heat, and cook while constantly agitating the pan for 2-5 minutes or until the pan is dry and the carrots are lightly glazed.
Microwave together for 1 minute and let stand until the raisins are plump, about 5 minutes.
Add to raisins and stir to combine. Serve atop the glazed carrots.

On 2 18-inch pieces of parchment paper (each sheet big enough to cover your baking sheets), draw 1" circles, separated by 2", as a template for piping the cookies. Place each parchment segment on its own baking sheet, marked side down.
Sift together twice.
Whip together in a large, clean, dry bowl until somewhat foamy.

Increase mixing speed to high, add sugar gradually, and whip until the foam is white and shiny and supports stiff peaks. Then, gently fold in the sugar and almond flour mixture until it is completely incorporated and the mixture flows lazily.

Fit a piping bag with a 1cm tip and pipe cookies into the previously drawn templates. Tap the bottom of the pan to encourage air bubbles to leave the batter. Leave the pans at room temperature for 2 hours to form skins.

Preheat oven to 325 F. Bake for 10-11 minutes. Leave the door propped open with a wooden spoon, and halfway through baking, rotate the pans. Transfer parchment sheets to a wire cooling rack. When cool, remove macrons with an offset spatula and pair them by size. Fill each with 1 tsp of filling - do not overfill. Refrigerate overnight and serve.
Bring all ingredients to a simmer, while stirring to combine. Cook for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally. Use immediately, or cool, move to a squeeze bottle, and place in the refrigerator.
Add to a medium bowl and set aside.
Place in a small saucepan and bring to a boil.
Work with a rubber spatula until soft and creamy.

Work the cream carefully into the chocolate, stirring to melt all the chocolate without adding air bubbles. Add the butter in two additions, still stirring gently to avoid air bubbles. Serve immediately as warm liquid, or leave it to set at room temperature or in the fridge. Bring it back to pliable consistency, if necessary, with a short time in the microwave.
Heat in a medium saucepan on medium heat until shimmering.
Add and cook until softened but not brown, about 8 minutes.
Add and cook until just fragrant, less than a minute.
Add and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer and cook until reduced to thick, ketchup-like consistency, 45 minutes to an hour.
Puree in a blender until completely smooth. Force through a strainer to remove solids. Adjust seasonings, if necessary; cool; and store for up to a month in a squeeze bottle.
Add to 8-quart dutch oven on low heat and render for 25-30 minutes. Remove bacon and reserve for another use.
Add to bacon fat and stir to combine
Add clove and anise to spice bag and add to pot. Cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the onions are deep brown - about one hour.
Add to pot and cook until celery is translucent; about 30 minutes. Remove the spice bag.
Add to a separate 4-quart sauce pan and heat on high heat until shimmering.
Add to oil and cook until well browned, about 5 minutes. Remove to a colander to drain. Return pan to high heat.
Add to pan and deglaze, scraping up brown bits. Add wine and meat to dutch oven with onions.
Add to dutch oven and stir to combine. Cover and cook over low heat for 3 hours, stirring occasionally.
After the meat mixture has been cooking for 90 minutes, place oil in the 4-qt pan and heat on medium until shimmering.
Add and cook until fragrant, less than a minute.
Add and cook until most of liquid has evaporated, about 30 minutes.
Add and stir to combine; continue simmering another 30 minutes.

Once the tomato mixture is again mostly dry, add the oil and increase the heat. Fry the tomatoes for 2-3 minutes, or until starting to brown. Add the tomato mixture to the meat, stir to combine, and simmer for 10 minutes. Serve immediately over pasta or freeze for up to 3 months.
Melt in a small saucepan and add to bowl of stand mixer.
Sift together in medium bowl.
Add to mixer and beat on full speed for two minutes.
Whisk together in a small bowl; add to mixer while running on low speed. Then, add the dry ingredients in a couple of rounds, scraping the bowl after each addition.
With the mixer still running at low speed, add and stir until combined. Chill the dough for one hour.

Preheat oven to 375 F. Arrange 1.5-oz scoops of dough on two baking sheets and bake for 15 minutes, rotating the pans halfway through. Sprinkle a small amount of salt on each cookie.  Cool for five minutes and serve.
Preheat oven to 350 F. Grease 9-inch springform pan with butter; then, line sides and bottom with parchment paper.
Place in bowl of stand mixer and beat on low speed until combined; take care not to incorporate too much air.
Add and mix until just combined.
Add to stand mixer while it is running, stopping occasionally to scrape the sides.
Add and beat until completely smooth. Pour into springform pan and level with spatula. Bake for 50-60 minutes or until a skewer comes out of the middle of the cake moist but not crumby.
Bring to a boil in a small saucepan and remove from heat once boiling. Juice should total 1/2 cup. When the cake comes out of the oven, brush it with the syrup until it has all been absorbed.
Garnish and serve.

Render the pork by placing it in a large stock pot and cooking over low heat for 10-15 minutes. After the fat has rendered from the pork, increase the heat and fry the pork cubes. Remove and reserve the cracklings.
Add to fat and sweat onions until translucent but not brown, about 8 minutes.
Add, ensuring potatoes are submerged. Boil for 10 minutes or until potatoes are softened but not cooked all the way through. Reduce heat to low and season with salt and pepper.
Add to pot and cook for 5 minutes or until almost, but not quite, done. Remove from heat, cover, and rest for 10 minutes.
Add to chowder and season with additional salt and pepper, if necessary.
Serve with soup.
Add to large bowl and submerge with water, dissolving salt. Leave for 1 hour, then rinse fish thoroughly.
Heat in large saucepan until shimmering.
Add and cook until vegetables are just beginning to soften, 2-4 minutes. Add fish scraps.
Add and cook while stirring until the wine begins to steam. Add water to barely cover the solids in the pot (about 4 cups).
Add to pot and bring to a bare simmer, skimming scum off the surface regularly. After 20 minutes, strain through a fine mesh strainer and use immediate or freeze for up to several months.
Combine in a large bowl just until no dry flour remains. Cover with plastic wrap and rest at room temperature for at least 8 and up to 24 hours.
Stir into existing dough just until no dry flour remains. Cover with plastic wrap and rest at room temperature for 15 minutes.
Stir into dough and rest for 30 minutes.

Fold the dough over itself 8 times, rotating the bowl each time so that all the dough is folded. Re-cover the dough and rest for 30 more minutes. Complete this folding process a total of 3 times. Transfer to a floured surface and dust dough lightly with flour. Divide the dough in half and shape each half into a round. Preheat oven to 500 F, with a pizza stone on a low rack.

Coat two 9-inch cake pans with half the oil and salt each. Place a round of dough in each pan, smooth side down, to coat with oil. Turn the dough over and repeat. Rest the dough for 5 minutes; then, press it lightly outward toward the edges of the pan. Pop any large bubbles and poke 2 or 3 dozen holes in each round with a fork.
Sprinkle on dough and rest until it is bubbly; 5-10 minutes.

Place cake pans on pizza stone and then reduce heat to 450 F. Bake until golden brown, 25-30 minutes, rotating the pans halfway through. Remove and cool on wire racks, brushing the tops of the loaves with any oil that remains in the pans. Cool for 30 minutes and serve.
Heat oven to 425 F with a rack in the lower part of the oven. Grease a 13 X 9 baking dish.
Cook in a large skillet over medium low until crisp; then, transfer to a plate lined with paper towels and discard all but 1 tbsp of the fat.

Add to bacon fat and return to medium heat. Cook until onion is golden brown, about 25 minutes. If the bottom of the pot threatens to turn black, add 1 tbsp of water and scrape as needed. When done, transfer to a medium bowl.
Add to onions along with reserved bacon pieces. Stir to combine.
Add to the pan that was used for the onions and bring to a simmer, scraping up and dissolving any brown bits left on the bottom of the pan.
Toss with onion mixture and transfer to prepared baking dish. Press down on the mixture with a spatula to compress it. Pour the hot broth over the potatoes and dot with the butter.
Bake until the potatoes are tender and golden brown on the edges, and most of the liquid has been absorbed, 45 minutes to an hour. Cool on a wire rack for 20 minutes, and serve.
Dry roast each ingredient individually over medium heat until fragrant, taking care not to burn them. Transfer all ingredients to a spice grinder and grind.
Add to mixture and stir to combine. Store in an airtight container for up to one month.
Heat until shimmering in a medium stock pot.
Add and saute 5 minutes or until browned.
Add and cook until vegetables are slightly softened, about 5 minutes.

Add, cover the pot, and bring to a boil. Uncover and boil for another 60-90 minutes, or until the stock has reduced to 3 cups. Pass through a fine mesh strainer and use immediately, refrigerate for up to a few days, or freeze for up to a few months.
Add to a 4-quart saucier on medium heat.
Shake together in a sealed jar until smooth. Stir into the saucier and whisk constantly until thickened; 3-4 minutes. Remove from heat and cool to 190 degrees.
Shake together in a sealed jar until no lumps remain.
Whisk into saucier along with potato starch slurry. Return to low heat and simmer for 5 minutes or until just thickened. Adjust with extra salt and pepper if needed.
Heat oven to 350 F and grease an 8-inch square baking pan.
Bring to a boil in a medium saucepan over medium heat.
Add, removing pan from heat. Stir in and allow foaming to subside.
Stir in and whisk until dissolved. Remove stout mixture to a large bowl and set aside.
Whisk together in a separate large bowl and set aside.
Add to stout mixture and whisk until combined. Then, add this wet mixture to the dry mixture in three batches, whisking each until it is fully incorporated.

Transfer the mixture to the prepared pan and dislodge or pop any air bubbles. Bake 30-45 minutes or until the top is just firm and a toothpick, inserted in the center, comes out clean. Cool on a wire rack and serve with ice cream or whipped cream.

Clean by immersing in cold water, being careful not to bruise the leaves. Drain thoroughly; then, spin in a salad spinner or dry on paper towels. Kept in a sealed container with barely-damp paper towels, this mixture will keep for up to a day and can thus be prepared ahead of time.
Melt in a large frying pan
Add to butter and saute until the hazelnuts are golden, about 5 minutes. Drain, reserving the butter for some other use. Cool and chop the almonds.
Toss gently with almonds and herb leaves, season to taste, and serve immediately - do not dress the salad ahead of time.
Process in food processor until ground to powder, about one minute. Store in an airtight container.
Add with chickpeas to medium saucepan on high heat and cook for 3 minutes, stirring constantly
Add to a bowl and cover with water at least twice the volume of the chickpeas. Soak overnight and drain.

Add to saucepan and bring to boil. Cook 20-40 minutes, skimming off any foam and skins that rise to the surface. When chickpeas are almost mushy, drain them and move them to a food processor. Process to a firm paste.
Add to food processor while it is running and process until thoroughly incorporated.

Add while the processor is running and process for 5 minutes, or until the paste is very smooth and creamy. Transfer to a bowl, cover with plastic wrap, and rest for at least 30 minutes. Serve at room temperature.
Heat in a large dutch oven to 350 F.
Add to oil and cook until well browned; drain on paper towels.
Combine in a small bowl and rest for 30 minutes. Grind to a paste.
Dry roast in a small skillet until lightly browned. Grind to a paste.
Dry roast together for about a minute, taking care not to burn. Grind to a powder.
Add to food processor along with two or three ice cubes and process until smooth. Move to a large bowl and mix in reserved nut, seed, and spice mixtures and fried onions.
Mix into lamb , cover the bowl, and refrigerate for 2 hours.
Divide the lamb into 8 portions. Oil a nonstick pan and cook over medium heat for 2 minutes per side or until well browned and cooked all the way through.
Bring to a boil in a large dutch oven.
Whisk in and let set for 1 minute.

Set cheesecloth in a large colander in two layers, with plenty hanging off the edges (alternatively, use a large tea towel for this step). Pour the milk mixture through the cheesecloth and let it drain for 15 minutes.

Gather the corners of the cheesecloth and tie them together, making a pouch. Twist the pouch firmly, squeezing out moisture until it is difficult to remove more by hand. Then, place the pouch between two plates and place a heavy weight, like two 28-oz tomato cans, on the top plate. Leave until the cheese is firm, about an hour. Remove from the cheesecloth and cut into 1-inch pieces and use immediately, or store for up to a few days in the refrigerator.
Rinse in cold water, drain, squeeze out excess water, and spread on a clean towel to dry.
Mix with grated potatoes in a large bowl. Form into small patties (about 2 tbsp each) and press with your hands into thin discs, about 3" diameter.

Heat in a large frying pan. Place the latkes in the pan, with plenty of space between them. Compress them with a metal spatula as they cook, and fry them on medium-high heat for 3 minutes per side, taking care to brown the outsides completely.
Keep the latkes warm on paper towels or serve immediately, passing with sour cream.
Heat in a large saucepan on medium heat until shimmering.
Add to oil and saute for 1 minute.
Add to oil and saute for 1 minute.
Combine and stir into a paste. Add to oil and saute for 30 seconds.

Add to pan and cook until tomatoes start to break down, about 15 minutes. Strain and reserve the liquid; transfer the solids to a blender and blend them into a smooth paste. Push the paste through a strainer into the reserved liquid and add up to 1/2 cup of water if the sauce needs loosening.
Add to sauce and simmer for 10 minutes.
Add and cook for 5 minutes.
Add and cook for 2 minutes.
Stir in and serve.

Cut the garlic in half around the equator; drizzle some olive oil onto the cut pieces and replace them. Wrap the garlic tightly in foil and cook at 350 F for 45 minutes or until the cloves are soft. Remove the garlic and squeeze out the softened pulp. In a small bowl, form it into a paste with the olive oil.
Add and stir into garlic paste.
Rub the paste into the meat, place it in a large roasting pan, and roast until it reaches 140 F internally.

NOTE: For best results, the tenderloin should be unpackaged, lightly salted, and left on a plate in your refrigerator for 1-3 days before cooking. This helps the meat become more flavorful and brown more easily.
Preheat oven to 350 F.
Combine in food processor and pulse until fine and uniform.
Add and pulse just until combined. Press the mixture into the bottom and sides of a glass pie dish. Bake for 10-12 minutes or until lightly browned. Cool for 10 minutes.
Bring to a simmer in a medium saucepan and cook until slightly thickened, about 3 minutes.
Add to pumpkin and return to a simmer. Remove from heat and cool 10 minutes.

Whisk together in a large bowl until smooth. Add pumpkin mixture and whisk until well-combined. Pour into prepared pie dish, place the dish on a sheet pan, and bake 45-50 minutes, or until set but still slightly elastic. Cool 2-3 hours before serving.
If using, spread on top of pie and caramelize with a brle torch.
Bring to a boil in a medium saucepan; then, reduce to a simmer and maintain heat.
Heat in a large dutch oven on medium heat until butter is melted.
Soften in butter for 5 minutes.
Stir in and cook for 1 minute.
Toast in the butter until barely translucent, about 3 minutes.

Add to pan and stir until rice has absorbed wine, about 3 minutes. Then, add 1 cup of the simmering broth and reduce heat to medium-low to maintain a simmer. When the rice has absorbed the liquid, add another cup of broth, until 6 cups have been added in total.
Stir into the rice. Cover and let sit, off heat, for 5 minutes.
Stir into rice, agitating until butter is completely melted. Add up to 1/2 cup of the remaining broth if the rice still needs loosening. Serve immediately.
Process in food processor for 30 seconds.
Process to a smooth paste in a food processor.
Add and process to combine
Stir in and serve immediately.
Melt over medium high heat in a saucepan.
Toast for 3 minutes in the melted butter.
Add to oats and stir to combine. Reduce heat to low to maintain a simmer, cover, and cook for 25 minutes.
Stir into oats and cook for 10 additional minutes.
Add to oats and serve.
Combine in a food processor and process until sugar is dissolved.
Whisk into juice mixture. Refrigerate for at least one hour and process in an ice cream maker. Serve immediately for soft-serve consistency, or freeze for at least four hours and serve firm.
Toast in a small frying pan on high heat, taking care not to burn. Remove from the pan and cool.
Combine with sesame seeds and mix well. Use immediately or store for up to 3 months.
Whisk together in a medium bowl.
Whisk together in a separate medium bowl. Form a well in the center of the dry ingredients and pour the liquid in. Whisk until smooth.

Heat a frying pan on medium-high heat (you can keep the heat consistent using an infrared thermometer as a monitor). Spoon in the mixture in 1/4 cup increments and spread into 5" discs. Cook until bubbles set around the edges, about 3 minutes. Flip and cook another 1-2 minutes or until golden brown.
Wash thoroughly and slice 1/8" thick with a mandoline. Remove seeds and place in a large pot.
Wash, zest, and juice. Add zest and juice to pot with oranges.
Add and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to just a simmer and cook for 40 minutes or until the oranges are very soft.

Add and bring oranges to a full boil. Cook until the mixture is thick and reaches 223 degrees. The marmalade is fully cooked when it sets up into a soft gel when placed on an ice-cold plate. It should not be runny.

Sterilize 10 8-oz canning jars by boiling them for 10 minutes and then turning off the heat and adding the lids. Include any other canning materials, like tongs or a funnel, in the 10-minute boil. Ladle marmalade into jars, filling them to just below the threads, about 1/2 inch from the top. Boil them for 10 minutes, ensuring they do not touch the bottom of the pan or each other. Cool to room temperature, refrigerate, and store for up to two years.

Remove any stickers from the peppers and place them, in a shallow metal baking dish, in the oven at 450 F. Roast until top sides are blackened and blistering; then, flip and roast until the remaining side is blackened as well. Remove from the oven and cover with foil or a lid. After the peppers have steamed for 15 minutes, remove their skins and seeds, tear them into strips, and cut into 1/2 inch pieces.
Combine with the roasted peppers in a medium bowl, stir to combine, and set aside.

Place a rack near your oven broiler and turn it on. Rub each slice of bread with the garlic until it is lightly fragrant; then, broil for 1-2 minutes or until golden, flip and broil for another minute. Remove to a cooling rack.

Process in a food processor until smooth, about 15 seconds, scraping the bowl once in the middle. Divide the feta mixture among the toasts and spread it evenly. Place 2 tbsp of the pepper mixture on each toast on top of the feta. Serve immediately.
Preheat oven to 225 F with a rack in the middle.
Pat dry with paper towels and cut in half once lengthwise and once crosswise, making 4 steaks.

Stir together in a small bowl and press into each side of all four steaks. Place the steaks on a wire rack set in a rimmed baking sheet and roast in the oven until the interior registers 120 degrees F, 30-40 minutes.
Combine in a small bowl.

Heat in a 12-inch skillet over medium-high heat until the oil begins to smoke. Add the steaks and sear them, flipping every 1 minute, until they have formed a healthy crust - about 4 minutes total. Remove to a wire rack and rest for 10 minutes.
Spread 3/4 of the butter mixture on the cooked steaks; then, thinly slice the steaks against the grain. Dot with the remaining butter and additional chives and serve immediately.

Simmer together in a large skillet over medium heat until the water evaporates and the bacon sizzles, about 8 minutes. Reduce the heat and render the bacon until it is crispy and browned, another 5 minutes.
Add and cook for 30 seconds. Strain the contents of the pot and reserve the solids and the fat separately.
Combine in a large bowl and whisk in 1 tbsp of the reserved bacon fat.
Boil in 2 quarts water in and drain, reserving 1 cup of the cooking liquid.

Whisk 1/2 cup of the reserved pasta liquid into the pecorino mixture. Add the spaghetti and the reserved cooked bacon to the bowl and toss to combine. Rest, tossing frequently, 2-4 minutes while the heat from the pasta cooks the eggs. When it is creamy and slightly thickened, serve immediately.
Combine in the carafe of a cream whipper, reducing the amount of vodka if necessary to remain below the max-fill line.

Pressurize the canister with one cartridge and let the mixture sit for one minute. Shake lightly and pressurize with the second cartridge; let sit for another minute. Holding a glass over the nozzle to catch foam and runoff, depressurize the canister. Open the canister and strain the liquid into the cup used to catch the runoff. Let settle for 1 minute and use immediately or store in a dark, airtight container for up to several months.
Whisk together thoroughly in a medium bowl. Remove to a squeeze bottle and use as needed.
Combine in a blender and blend on high speed until thoroughly combined.
Transfer the mixture to a medium saucepan and cook, whisking constantly, until the mixture reaches 220 F. Chill; then, strain through coffee filter.
Whisk together in a small bowl.
Season and use immediately.
Combine in a blender and blend on high speed until fully incorporated.
Transfer the mixture to a medium saucepan and cook on moderate heat until the mixture reaches 220 F. Chill; then strain through a coffee filter.
Combine in a blender and blend on high until thoroughly incorporated.
Transfer the mixture to a medium saucepan and cook until it reaches 220 F. Chill; then, strain through a coffee filter.

Simmer in a medium saucepan over medium heat for 40 minutes or until clear and lightly brown or caramel in color. Continue simmering, while whisking, for an additional 5-10 minutes or until the color is deeper brown and nutty.
Line a strainer with cheesecloth, place the thyme and garlic inside the strainer, and pour the butter over the herbs and through the cheesecloth. Use immediately or store for up to several days.
Simmer in a medium saucepan on medium heat for 30 minutes, or until completely clear and no bubbles are formed in the pan.
Place the cheesecloth in a strainer and pour the butter through it. Use immediately or refrigerate for up to several days.
Trim the tops and bottoms of the cloves and thinly slice them with a mandoline.

Place in a saucepan with the garlic and bring just to a simmer; then, remove from heat and steep for 10 minutes. Strain out the garlic, rinse it under cold water, dry it thoroughly, and discard the milk.

Heat to 275 F in a medium saucepan. Fry the garlic chips for less than a minute, just until lightly browned. Remove them from the oil to a plate lined with paper towels. Season immediately with salt. Serve immediately or store for up to 12 hours.
Scrub the sunchokes to remove dirt, and scrape out any eyes that have formed. Slice them very thinly on a mandoline, about 1/16".
Add the oil to a large dutch oven and heat it to 300 F. Add the sunchokes and cook until they are just golden brown and still bubbling. Remove to a plate lined with paper towels.
Sprinkle over the still-hot chips. Cool and serve immediately.
Melt in a medium saucepan over medium-low heat.
Add to butter and cook until shallots are slightly softened, about 3 minutes.
Add and bring to a simmer. Once simmering, remove from heat.
Peel and halve lengthwise; reserve half the peels. Slice 1/4" thick using a mandoline. Add sliced potatoes and reserved peels to just-simmered mixture and let stand, uncovered, for 20 minutes.

Add to potatoes and bring to a simmer over high heat. Reduce the heat to medium-low, cover, and cook until the potatoes are soft, about 10 minutes. Remove the thyme sprigs and process using an immersion blender until very smooth.
Add and serve.
Process in a food processor until uniform and incorporated.
Process until fully incorporated.
Add and process until dough begins to clump. Form into a disc, wrap in plastic wrap, and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or, if making ahead of time, up to a week.
Combine in a small bowl. Preheat oven to 350 F and line two baking sheets with silicone mats.
Combine in a small bowl.

Divide the reserved dough into quarters. Roll out the first quarter on a floured surface into 12" X 8" rectangle. Spread a very thin layer of jam, 2-3 tablespoons, leaving a line of clean, un-moistened dough along one of the long sides in order to seal the dough. Evenly sprinkle 2 tbsp of the reserved cinnamon sugar and 1/4 of the reserved nuts. Roll into a very tight log, moistening and lightly sealing the end. Repeat this process with all the remaining dough, and place the logs in the freezer for 15 minutes.
Trim the ends of the logs and cut into 10-12 slices. Arrange on baking sheets, brush with the egg wash, and sprinkle on the remaining cinnamon sugar. Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until golden brown.
Add to a large plastic container and swirl to dissolve. Let sit for 10 minutes.
Add and agitate until ice is melted.
Add to liquid and refrigerate for 2 hours. Remove from brine, rinse, and cut a horizontal pocket in each chop with a boning knife.
Combine and place in a piping bag. Pipe into each chop until the cut pocket is full. Grill or sear on medium-high heat for about 6 minutes per side, or until the pork reaches 140-145 F internally.
Combine in a large bowl and stir to dissolve sugar and salt.
Trim the shrimp and reserve their shells. Submerge in the brine for 15 minutes. Remove and pat them dry.
Heat in a 12-inch skillet until shimmering. Add reserved shrimp shells and cook, stirring constantly, until spotty and starting to brown, about 4 minutes.
Add to shells and cook over medium heat for about 5 minutes, stirring occasionally. Strain out and discard the shells and thyme, reserving the liquid.

Heat on medium-low until the garlic is just beginning to brown. Add the reserved wine mixture and bring to a simmer. Add the shrimp, cover, and cook until the shrimp are just barely cooked through, 5-6 minutes. Remove the shrimp with a slotted spoon or spatula, leaving the other ingredients in the pan.
Combine in a small bowl. Return the skillet to medium heat and add the cornstarch slurry. Cook until slightly thickened, about a minute. Remove from heat.
Whisk into the sauce and stir constantly until the butter is melted by the ambient heat. Serve immediately.

Trim the cauliflower, cutting off the leaves and stem. Cut into 3/4" slices; then, cut out the core and reserve only the florets. Add the florets to a large bowl along with any small pieces left over from the cutting process.
Process into coarse crumbs in a food processor.
Add to a skillet on medium heat and add the bread. Cook until the crumbs are golden brown; then, transfer them to a bowl and wipe out the skillet.

Add to the skillet with the cauliflower. Cook, covered, over medium-high heat or until the florets are just starting the brown, about 5 minutes. Then, remove the lid, stir the cauliflower, and cook until the florets are fully golden brown, about another 10 minutes.

Push the cauliflower out to the sides of the pan, and add the oil, garlic, and lemon zest to the center. Cook until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Stir in the cauliflower and finish cooking, about another 3 minutes.
Garnish and serve.
Preheat oven to 450 F.
Melt in a large, oven-safe skillet over medium-high heat.
Place, cut side down, in the skillet and brown for 3-5 minutes. Transfer the pan to the oven and roast for 15 minutes. Flip the pears and roast for another 15 minutes. Transfer to a platter.
Bring to a vigorous simmer in the skillet, scraping the bottom of the pan to dissolve browned bits. Reduce to a syrup, about 10 minutes.
Stir into syrup and remove from heat. Add the sauce to the pears.
Garnish and serve.
Preheat oven 400 F.
Peel and cut into 1/2" dice. Cover with cold water in a large pot and bring to a boil. Uncover and cook until potatoes are easily pierced with a knife, about 15 minutes.
Combine in a small bowl and microwave until warm, about 30 seconds.
Add to potatoes along with dairy mixture and mash.
Add to potatoes and stir until combined.
Heat in a large skillet on medium-high until shimmering.
Saute until just starting to brown, about 4 minutes.
Add and stir to combine.
Add and cook until browned, about 4 minutes.
Add and toss to coat. Cook for 1 minute.
Add, stir to combine, and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer and simmer for 10 minutes or until slightly thickened.
Add to mixture and spread in the bottom of an 11X17 baking dish.

Top the mixture with the mashed potatoes, ensuring that a seal forms around the edges of the baking dish to avoid leaks during cooking. Create ridges in the potato topping with a fork. Place on a sheet pan lined with parchment paper and bake for 25 minutes or until the potatoes start to brown. Cool for 15 minutes and serve.
Knead together to form a stiff dough. Cover with a damp towel and rest for 15 minutes.
Toast; then, grind in a spice grinder.
Heat together in a medium skillet on medium-high heat until the cumin is lightly browned and fragrant.
Add to oil and stir to combine.
Add to oil with ground coriander mixture; stir to combine.
Add and cook for 5 minutes.
Stir into mixture.
Heat in a large dutch oven until the oil reaches 325 F.

Dust a work surface lightly with flour. Divide the dough into 8 pieces and roll each into a thin disc. Cut each disc in half, form the halves into cones, and fill each with 1-2 tbsp of the potato mixture. Using water to moisten the edges, seal the dough around the filling. Fry the samosas in batches of 4-6 until they are golden brown. Remove to paper towels and serve.
Combine and soak for 10 minutes.
Whisk together until well-combined.
Combine in the bowl of a stand mixer with the beater attachment. Combine and aerate slightly on medium-high speed, about 1 minute.

Add with the mixer running slowly; increase the speed and mix for 1 minute. Add the currants, brandy, and dry ingredients, and mix until the dough comes together. Gently knead it until it is homogenous.
Divide the dough into 2-ounce chunks, shape the chunks into balls, and place them on baking sheets lined with parchment paper. Rest in the refrigerator for one hour. Preheat the oven to 375 F.
Bake the cookies for 15-20 minutes, or until the top is firm but the center is still soft. Remove, cool for 5 minutes, and transfer to a wire rack.
Whisk together and spoon 1 tbsp over the top of each warm cookie.
Place a few pieces of candied lemon peel on each cookie, in the still-wet icing.
Preheat oven to 400 F.
Toast for 4 minutes on a sheet pan, agitating after 2. Cool and grind in a blender or food processor.
Bring to a boil in a medium saucepan. Add the almonds and simmer on low heat, stirring often. When the mixture thickens and threatens to boil, remove it from the heat. Steep for 3-12 hours.
Triple-layer the cheesecloth and strain the almond mixture through it. Squeeze to extract all the liquid possible.
Add and stir to combine. Cool, funnel into a squeeze bottle and refrigerate.
Combine in a small cup and stir to dissolve. Let sit for 8 minutes.
Combine in a separate large bowl.

Pour the liquid into the dry ingredients and combine with a heavy spoon. Knead the dough by hand for 2 minutes. Press the dough gently into a 12" diameter circle and move to a lightly greased baking sheet. Add sauce and toppings and bake at 500 F for 8-12 minutes, or until the crust is golden and crunchy.
Preheat oven to 350 F.
Cook in a 12-inch cast iron skillet on medium heat until the bacon is crisp and the fat has rendered out, about 10 minutes. Remove the bacon and set it aside; leave the fat in the pan.
Add to skillet and cook until the potatoes are soft and beginning to brown, about 25 minutes. Return the bacon to the skillet and stir to combine.

Whisk together in a large bowl until well-combined. Pour the egg mixture over the cooked potatoes in the cast iron skillet. Bake for 25-30 minutes or until the eggs are puffy and the center is set. Cool and serve immediately, or refrigerate for up to several days.

Cut the tops and bottoms off of the oranges, and cut them into eighths. Peel the fruit out of the remaining wedges, slice each wedge into two thin strips, and cover them with cold water. Let sit for one hour. Reserve the fruit for another use like juicing.

Drain the oranges and cover them with water by 1 inch. Bring them to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and cook for 10 minutes. Complete this blanching process a total of 4 times, and on the final time, cook the oranges until they are tender, about 30 minutes.

Drain the oranges and add the water and sugar to the pot without the oranges. Bring the water to a boil and cook until the mix reaches 220 F. Then add the orange peels and simmer until they are slightly translucent, about 45 minutes. Remove them from the heat and let them sit for at least 8 hours and up to a day.
Return the mix to a boil and cook until it registers 226 F. Let sit for at least 8 hours and up to a day.
Return the mix to a boil and cook until it registers 228 F. Let sit for at least 8 hours and up to a day.
Reheat just until the syrup liquefies; then, drain the peels in a colander and lay them out on wire cooling racks for at least 8 hours and up to a day.
Spread the sugar on a plate and roll the peels in the sugar to coat. Let sit for 1 hour and then use. Will keep for up to several months in an airtight container.
Place the cocktail glass in the freezer at least 15 minutes before preparing the cocktail.
Add to chilled glass.
Add to glass and stir gently to combine the liquids.
Garnish and serve.
Whisk together in a large bowl. Preheat oven to 400 F.
Add and stir just until ingredients are moistened - do not overmix.

Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface. Knead it a couple of times so that it becomes a cohesive mass, but do not knead more than that. Press the dough into a uniform 1/2" mat, and cut 2-inch rounds from it with a cookie cutter or a cup. Re-form the scraps to make additional biscuits.
Place parchment paper on a baking sheet and arrange the biscuits a few inches apart on the paper. Bake for 12-15 minutes or until the biscuits have risen and are slightly golden. Serve warm.

Cook in a medium saucepan over medium-high heat, breaking up with a spatula, until the sausage is browned and cooked all the way through. Transfer the sausage to a plate, leaving the drippings in the pan.
Add only if necessary to bring the total amount of drippings in the pan up to 3 tablespoons.
Whisk into drippings and cook until incorporated and lightly brown, about 1 minute.
Whisk in slowly and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer and cook, stirring regularly, for about 4 minutes or until the gravy is slightly thickened.
Stir in along with reserved sausage. Serve immediately.
Toss together and spread on a rimmed baking sheet. Bake at 425 F or until the croutons are crispy and golden brown, about 15 minutes.
Puree in a food processor; transfer to a large bowl.
Add to pepper puree along with reserved croutons; stir to combine.
Cook in a large skillet on medium heat until crisp, about 5 minutes. Remove the bacon to the pepper puree, leaving the bacon fat in the pan.
Add to bacon fat and cook until soft, about 7 minutes.
Add and cook until garlic is fragrant and beginning to soften, 1-2 minutes.

Transfer the pepper puree to a 13 X 9 baking dish; press down with a spatula so that the mixture is evenly distributed and the solids are submerged. Evenly distribute the onion mixture on top of the puree. Cover with foil and refrigerate for 2 hours or up to overnight.
Preheat oven to 450 F. Bake the casserole, uncovered, until the top is golden brown, about 40 minutes.

Make 8 small wells in the top of the casserole and crack an egg into each one. Place the baking dish back in the oven and cook for another 10 minutes, or until the whites are set and the yolks are still a little runny. Remove and cool for 10 minutes.
Garnish and serve.
Brown in a large skillet on medium-high heat until cooked through; remove from pan and reserve.
Bring to a boil on high heat.
Whisk in and return to a boil. Cover the pot and boil for 5 minutes or until thickened, whisking occasionally to prevent burning on the bottom. When cooked, remove from heat.
Add to grits and stir until completely incorporated.

Add to grits along with reserved sausage and stir to combine. Transfer to a lightly greased 13X9 baking dish. Preheat oven to 350 F or transfer mixture to the refrigerator for up to several days before baking.
Add the room-temperature baking dish to the oven and cook until set all the way through, 50-60 minutes. Cool and serve.
Whisk together in a medium bowl
Whisk together in a separate medium bowl

Whisk into the butter and egg mixture. Pour the wet ingredients over the dry and stir to combine. Let sit for 5 minutes. Cook the waffles in your waffle iron according to its  instructions and either keep warm in a heating blanket or low-temperature oven, or serve immediately.
Add to a stock pot and saute the onion, cut sides down, in the butter until it begins to significantly brown the bottom of the pan
Add to the pot and scrape the bottom with a spatula to deglaze. Cook until the liquid is thickened and most of the wine has boiled off, about 2 minutes.

Add to pot and bring to a boil. Continue to cook for the next 60-90 minutes or until the liquid has reduced by half. Strain, cool, and reserve in the refrigerator for up to a few days, or in the freezer for up to several months.
Combine in a small saucepan and cook just until the sugar melts into the juice
Stir into the hot lime juice and whisk until dissolved. Place in a small jar, seal, and run under cold water for five minutes or until cooled.
Whisk into mixture until well-incorporated and strain into a cream whipper.
Charge the cream whipper according to manufacturer instructions and move the whipper to the refrigerator for at least 4 hours. Dispense foam at serving time.
Preheat oven to 475 F.
Line a baking sheet with parchment paper and set aside

Toss together in a medium bowl and spread the combined mixture on the parchment paper. Place in the oven and roast for 30 minutes, tossing once in the middle of cooking. Remove the roasted mushrooms to a bowl and adjust the salt and pepper levels, if necessary.
Toss with the mushrooms and serve immediately.

Combine in the bowl of a stand mixer with the hook attachment. Mix on low speed for 4 minutes or until well-blended. Increase speed to medium and continue mixing for an additional 8 minutes, until the dough is elastic and able to pull away from the sides of the bowl.

Pound on a clean surface with a rolling pin or mallet to soften slightly. Add to the mixer in small increments; then, mix for 5 minutes or until the dough once again pulls away from the sides of the bowl.
Lightly oil a large bowl and scrape the dough into it. Cover with plastic wrap and leave at room temperature for 1 hour.
Uncover the dough and press down on it, folding it over itself to reduce its size. Cover the dough again and leave it for another hour.
Lightly flour a clean work surface. Uncover the dough and divide it into 14 equal pieces. Cover with plastic and rest for 15 minutes.

Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Uncover the dough and flour the work surface if necessary to prevent sticking. Gently press the dough to force out some of the gas and shape the dough into rounds (or any shape you prefer). Place the rolls on the pan, smooth side up. Cover with plastic wrap and rest for 90 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 425 F well in advance of the end of the 90 minute rest.

Combine and whisk together in a small bowl. Using a brush, coat the top of each roll with the egg wash. Transfer the rolls to the oven and bake for 20 minutes or until the crust is golden brown and the sides of the rolls are firm. Remove to a wire rack to cool; then, serve.
Preheat oven to 350 F.
Cut the chicken into 8 pieces and season all over with the salt and pepper.
Coat the chicken in oil on all sides.
Heat a large saute pan on medium-high heat and cook the chicken for 5-7 minutes per side, or until it is well-browned. Remove from heat.
Add to the saute pan and cover with aluminum foil or an oven-safe lid. Bake for 90 minutes. Remove from the oven, cool for 15 minutes, and serve.
Preheat oven to 400 F; wait about 20 minutes to let it heat up.
Toss together in a cast-iron skillet and place in the oven for a half hour. Stir halfway through. Remove the skillet from the oven and place on medium heat on the stovetop.
Add and cook, stirring occasionally, until the liquid has mostly cooked out of the tomatoes, about 5 minutes.
Add to a large saucepan and bring to a boil. When boiling, reduce to a simmer and cook for 5 minutes or until al dente. Using a strainer or a spider, move the pasta to the pan with the cauliflower.
Stir into the pasta mix.
Top the pasta with the breadcrumbs and return the pan to the oven for 15-20 minutes or until the cheese has melted and the crumbs are golden brown, about 15 minutes.
Garnish and serve.
Preheat oven to 375 F.
Scrub sunchokes clean and slice into 1/4 inch medallions with a mandoline.
Bring to a boil, add sunchokes, and reduce to a simmer. Cook for 8 minutes or until tender but still a little crisp. Drain and arrange in a baking dish prepared with butter.
Bring to a boil in a medium saucepan and pour evenly over sunchokes.
Add to top of dish and bake for 20 minutes, or until bubbling and starting to brown.
Add to cocktail shaker and shake once more for 30 seconds or until very well chilled.
Garnish the glass with the spices and serve.
Toss all ingredients together in a medium bowl.
Season and serve.

Combine in a large saucepan and cook gently, maintaining 150 F, for about one hour or until the chicken is cooked through. Remove the chicken, reserving the stock, and when the chicken is cool enough to handle, shred it with a fork or dice it.
Add to reserved stock and bring to a boil. Cook for 20 minutes or until the rice is just cooked.

Combine in a heat-proof bowl and whisk together until slightly foamy. Temper in the hot  broth mixture gradually by adding a half cup of it at a time to the egg mixture. When two cups of total liquid have been added to the eggs, return the entire mixture to the saucepan.
Add salt and cook for about 5 minutes on medium heat, stirring constantly, until the eggs thicken the mixture a little.
Add along with more salt and lemon juice, if necessary. Serve immediately.
Preheat oven to 325 F.
Add to a large saucepan and bring to a boil.

Combine in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Cover and bring to a simmer. Uncover and cook until the sugar reaches a mahogany-brown color. Pour caramel into a medium, oven-safe pie pan and swirl the pan to distribute it.
Combine in the same pan from the first batch of caramel. Follow the same procedure to caramelize the sugar.
Add to the caramel and bring to a simmer, stirring to dissolve the caramel. Move the mixture to the bowl of a blender.

With the blender running on low speed, add to the mix and process until well combined. Alternatively, if you are comfortable tempering eggs into a hot mixture, this can be done with a whisk. Pour the mixture into the prepared pie dish.

Prepare a rimmed baking sheet with foil and place the pie dish in it so that it is level. Place the baking sheet in the oven and add boiling water so that it reaches about a half inch up the sides of the baking sheet. Bake in the water bath until the custard is just set, about 45 minutes. Cool in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours.
Run a small knife around the periphery of the custard, and then overturn it on your serving dish. Sprinkle with extra salt and serve immediately, or keep in the refrigerator for up to a few days.
Combine in a large skillet over medium heat until the butter is melted.
Add to the skillet and cook until softened, about 6 minutes.
Stir into skillet until incorporated.
Add and bring to a simmer. Simmer for 45 minutes, remove the bay leaf, move to a bowl, and process with an immersion blender until smooth. Use immediately or freeze for up to a few months.
Place the beets in a row on a large piece of heavy-duty aluminum foil. Preheat your oven to 375 F.

Arrange around and on top of the beets in the foil; then, pull the edges of the foil together and crimp them shut to make a small, sealed enclosure. Place the foil pocket on a half sheet pan and move to the oven. Cook until the beets are tender throughout but still firm, about 45 minutes, or up to an hour if your beets are on the larger side. A knife should slide easily into the beets, all the way to the center.
Combine in a small bowl while the beets are cooking. Stir to until the mixture reaches a spreadable consistency, loosening with more lemon juice if necessary.
