When the beets are done cooking, refrigerate  them until they are cool enough to handle. Then, cut each beet horizontally into 4 slices and spread 1 1/2 teaspoons of the goat cheese filling between each layer. Reassemble the beets and serve.
Rest at room temperature for 1 hour.
Place a 12-inch cast iron skillet in the center rack in your oven and turn it up to 500 F.
With the oven fully preheated, move the skillet to your cook surface and place it over high heat for 5 minutes.

Coat the steaks with oil, salt, and pepper; then, place them in the now-very-hot pan and leave them there for 30 seconds. Flip them with tongs and cook for another 30 seconds. Move the skillet to the oven, cook for 2 minutes, flip the steaks, and cook for another 2 minutes. Remove the steaks to a wire cooling rack or colander set in a bowl, cover with foil, and rest for 5 minutes. Serve.
Pour into a hot skillet (such as one in which you have just cooked a steak), taking care to turn the heat off first so the cognac will not catch fire. Reduce for 30 seconds.
Add and whisk for 30 seconds or until well-incorporated.
Whisk in, one piece at a time, and continue whisking until the sauce thickens. Serve in small bowls along with steaks.

Combine in a large saucepan and add enough cold water to cover the potatoes. Cover and bring to a boil over high heat. Once the liquid is boiling, uncover the pot and boil until the potatoes are very tender, about 15 minutes. Drain them thoroughly and return them to the same pot.
Combine in a smaller saucepan while the potatoes are cooking and bring to a simmer over low heat, keeping it hot but not boiling until the potatoes are done cooking.

Add to the drained potatoes, pour on a quarter of the simmering buttermilk mixture, and mash with a potato masher or large fork. Add the remaining buttermilk mixture, stopping when the potatoes reach your desired consistency. Serve.
Add to a small skillet over low heat; cook until the butter stops foaming.
Crack into the pan and tilt it slightly so that the eggs set up in one side of the pan. Hold askew for 15 seconds; then, lower the pan carefully.
Season the eggs and continue to cook for another 60-90 seconds. When the white on the bottom is fully set but not quite opaque.
Whisk together until light and foamy.

Flip the egg carefully, either with a wide spatula or with a slight motion of the pan toward you that will flip the eggs up the sloped sides of the pan and over onto their other side. Cook briefly - about 10 seconds - then, move to a warm plate and serve.
Add to a medium skillet over high heat.

When the butter is foamy, pour the eggs straight into the center of the pan. Stir slowly with a heatproof rubber spatula while gently shaking the pan with your other hand. When there is no more liquid in the pan, transfer the eggs to a warm plate, rest for 1 minute, and serve. Note that the eggs will continue to cook after they leave the pan, so do not cook them past the point where the runny liquid is gone.
Add to a cocktail shaker and shake to combine.

Add and shake vigorously until well combined and creamy. Rest at room temperature for 1 hour; then, strain out the garlic, shake again to emulsify, and use immediately or refrigerate for up to a few months, bringing to room temperature and shaking with each use.
Combine in a small saucepan on medium-low heat and stir until the sugar is completely dissolved.
Add and remove the pan from heat. Move to a heatproof, airtight container, and refrigerate for at least 3 hours or until the mixture is below 40 degrees F.
Process in your ice cream maker according to instructions; then, serve immediately for soft-serve consistency, or refrigerate for at least 2 hours for a more set consistency.
Whisk together in a large mixing bowl. Preheat your oven to 450 F.
Work into the dry mixture with your fingertips until the mixture is coarse and crumby.
Mix in and stir until a sticky batter forms. Drop in 8 blobs on a half sheet pan.
Brush the butter on the dough blobs and sprinkle some sugar on each one. Bake for 15 minutes or until golden brown; then, move to a wire cooling rack and cool for 10 minutes.
Dress and serve.
Melt in a medium saucier on medium-high heat; cook until the foaming begins to subside.

Add and whisk vigorously; after 30 seconds, reduce the heat to low and continue to whisk. When the mixture begins to smell nutty or toasty, cook for another 2 minutes. Remove from heat, cool for 1 minute, and use immediately or refrigerate for up to 2 weeks.
Place a medium skillet over medium-high heat (do not use nonstick).
Season the fish and dredge it in the flour.

Add to the hot pan and let the butter foam and turn light brown. Add the fish and jitter the pan a little to make sure the fish does not stick. Cook until a light golden crust forms, about 2 minutes. If the oil starts to smoke, lower the heat a little bit. Gently flip the fish with a large metal spatula and cook (still jittering the pan) for another 2 minutes or until the meat starts to flake and separate. Remove the fish to a warm plate.
Add to the pan and fry the capers for about 30 seconds; then, remove from the heat.
Stir into the melted butter and cook until slightly thickened. Pour the sauce over the fish.
Garnish and serve.
Preheat oven to 450 F and place a sheet of parchment on a half sheet pan.
Rinse with cold water, drain, and pat dry.
Stuff the cavity of the fish, taking care not to overfill it.
Combine in a large bowl and mix with your hands until pasty. Lay down a half-inch thick layer of the paste on the parchment paper over an area wide enough to accommodate the whole bass.

Lay the fish on the bed of salt paste and use the remaining paste to completely cover the fish with a firm seal. Place in the oven and cook until a thermometer reads 130 F in the thickest part of the fish, about 35 minutes. Remove and rest for 10 minutes; then, transfer to a platter by sliding off the entire parchment, or move the entire baking rig to your serving table (placing on a hot pad).

When the fish has reached its final resting place, tap it gently with a mallet and remove large slabs of the salt paste. When the fish is mostly exposed, brush away the remaining salt. Carefully remove the fins (they are sharp).

Slice down the middle of the fish with a pie server or serrated knife, lift the skin off, and remove the flesh, working in multiple pieces if necessary. Pull the tail gently up and forward to remove the skeleton, which should come off in one piece. Remove the bottom fillet while leaving behind the skin.
Pass oil and salt to guests to use as seasoning and serve.
Preheat oven to 350 F.
Melt in a medium saucier over medium heat.
Stir into the butter. Decrease the heat to low and cook until the onion is translucent, about 4 minutes.
Add and cook, stirring frequently, until the rice smells nutty - about 4 minutes.
Combine in a small bowl and steep.
Add along with the steeped saffron, increase the heat, and bring to a boil.

Scatter on top of the rice. Wet a clean towel, place on top of the pan (with heat off so as to avoid lighting the towel ablaze), add the lid, and fold the corners of the towel over the lid. Transfer the entire contraption to the hot oven. Bake for 15 minutes. Remove the dish from the oven and rest, covered, for 15 more minutes. Remove the bay leaves and orange zest and turn the pilaf out onto a warm platter and fluff it with a large fork.
Garnish and serve.
Preheat oven to 375 F. Add 1 inch of water to the bottom of a large saucepan and bring it to a simmer.

Add to the bowl of a stand mixer, remove the bowl, and place it in the pan with the simmering water so that the bottom of the bowl does not touch the hot water. Stir with a rubber spatula until the chocolate is melted.
Add and stir to combine. Remove from heat and mount the bowl in the stand mixer, fitted with the paddle attachment.
Sift together by placing in a strainer over a paper plate and tapping the strainer until it is empty. Set the sifted powder aside.
With the mixer running on medium speed, add one at a time, adding the next egg only when the previous one is fully incorporated. Set the mixer speed to low.

Bending the paper plate to facilitate pouring into the blender, add the dry ingredients in three batches, scraping down the sides between each addition. Increase the mixer speed t high and beat for 5 minutes or until the mixture is creamy and lightens in color. Chill for 30 minutes.

Coat the 12 cups of a muffin pan with butter and then sprinkle or sift in the cocoa powder to coat the cups. Shake out the excess so that it will not burn in the oven. Spoon the batter into the cups and bake for 10 to 11 minutes, or until the outside is firmly set but a toothpick inserted into the cupcakes comes out gooey. Remove the muffins from the pan.
Melt together in a small saucepan, spoon over the still-warm muffins, and serve.
Add 1 inch of water to the bottom of a large saucepan and bring to a simmer over medium heat.

Add to a heatproof mixing bowl and set over the hot water. Stir until almost completely melted, but remove from heat while there are still a couple tiny chunks in the mix. Cool for 20 minutes or until the mixture is just lukewarm.

Combine in a small bowl and let sit for 10 minutes so that the gelatin can bloom. After blooming, gently heat the gelatin mixture with a few seconds in the microwave and add it to the cooled chocolate.

Add the bowl of a stand mixer and beat until fairly firm peaks form in the whipped cream. Stir a quarter of this whipped cream into the chocolate mixture to lighten it a little. Working in two doses, gently fold in the remaining whipped cream, taking care not to fold so aggressively that the cream collapses.
Spoon the mix into martini glasses and chill for at least an hour or up to a day or two if preparing in advance for service.
Preheat oven to 375 F with a rack in the middle.
Sift through a strainer and into a medium bowl, or add to the bowl and whisk to combine.
Add to bowl and work into dry good with fingertips; continue working until the mixture is coarse and crumby.

Add and lightly knead, just enough to bring the dough into a uniform ball. Do not overwork the dough or it will become chewy. On a floured surface, roll out the dough very thin, about 1/8 of an inch. Cut into 1/2-inch squares.

Line a half sheet pan with the parchment paper and place the dough squares on it, making sure that they do not touch. Bake for about 15 minutes or until the crackers are just starting to color around the edges. Then, turn off the oven, prop it open with a heatproof spoon, and leave the crackers for another 30 minutes. Remove, season with salt, and cool. Use immediately or store in an airtight container for up to a week.
Place the turkey in the refrigerator or a 38-degree cooler two or three days before roasting in order to thaw it.
Combine in a large stock pot and bring to a boil. Stir until the salt and sugar dissolve, cool to room temperature, and refrigerate.

Combine with the brining liquid in a medium-sized cooler. Remove any giblets or neck pieces from the thawed turkey and submerge it breast-side down in the brine the night before you plan to cook the bird. Seal the cooler for 12 hours, flipping the bird halfway through.
Preheat oven to 500 F. Remove the bird from the brine and rinse it thoroughly. Discard the brine.
Place the bird in a rack set in a roasting pan and pat it dry with paper towels.
Combine in a microwave-safe bowl. Microwave on high for 5 minutes and then add to the inside of the turkey.
Add to the turkey along with the apple mixture.

Lightly coat the bird with oil and place it in the oven on the lowest rack. Roast for 30 minutes. Reduce the oven temperature to 350 F and roast until the internal temperature is 155 F, about two and a half hours. Remove from the oven and rest under aluminum foil for at least 15 minutes before carving and serving.
Combine in a plastic container and macerate overnight at room temperature.
Combine in a spice grinder and grind to a fine powder.

Place in a large saucepan along with the contents of the plastic fruit container and the ground spices. Bring to a boil; then, reduce to a simmer and cook for 10 minutes, stirring often. Remove from heat and steep for an additional 15 minutes; then, either finish the recipe immediately or refrigerate for 2 days.
Preheat oven to 325 with a roasting pan in the bottom rack filled halfway with warm water.
Using a strainer, sift directly onto the fruit mixture. Stir the batter together quickly, taking care not to overwork it.
Stir in one at a time.
Fold into the batter. Move the batter to a nonstick loaf pan and bake for 1 hour or until the interior temperature reaches 200 F. Remove to a cooling rack.
Spritz the cake with brandy, wrap it in the cheesecloth, and move it to an airtight container. Every day or two, spritz it with more brandy. Consume within two weeks.
Preheat two medium-sized cast iron skillets on high heat for 5 minutes.
Spread the mustard on the bread.
Distribute evenly on the mustard.
Top off the sandwich.

Brush onto the bread, taking care not to soak it. Place, buttered side down, in one of the cast-iron skillets and turn the heat off on both skillets. Butter the remaining side and place the other skillet directly on the sandwich. Cook for 3-5 minutes between the hot skillets. Remove with a metal spatula, rest for 1 minute, cut with a bread knife, and devour.

Roast in a 450-degree oven for 20-40 minutes, turning once or twice, until the skin is entirely puffy and mostly blackened. Remove to a bowl, cover, and steam in its own heat for a few minutes until the skin can be easily removed. Remove the skin and seeds, finely chop, and reserve.
Combine in a food processor and pulse 10 times to combine.
Add along with the chopped roasted pepper and pulse 5 more times to combine. Use immediately or store in an airtight container for up to a week.
Cut apples in half and scoop out the cores with a spoon or a melon baller.
Toss with apples in a mixing bowl and set aside.
Add to the apples.
Add and fold in gently, taking care not to bruise the greenery or apples. Cover and refrigerate for an hour.
Arrange the salad on top of the romaine leaves and serve.
Combine in a medium bowl and stir to dissolve the salt and sugar.

Combine in a microwave-safe bowl. Apply the lid and leave a small gap for steam to escape. Microwave for 10 minutes, turning occasionally if your microwave does not have a rotating platter. Puree with an immersion blender and serve.
Add to the bowl and set aside.
Devein using scissors, add to the brine without removing shells, and refrigerate for 20 minutes.
Process in a food processor until nearly completely smooth; then, remove to the refrigerator.

Place a half sheet pan under the broiler in your oven and heat it for 5 minutes. Remove the shrimp from the brine, rinse under cold water, and dry thoroughly using paper towels. Clean out the bowl and move it to the freezer.

Add to the shrimp and toss to combine. Place the shrimp on the hot sheet pan and return the pan to the broiler for 2 minutes. Flip quickly and carefully and broil for another 1 minute. Move the shrimp to the chilled bowl and move the bowl to the freezer. Cool for 15 minutes, tossing every few minutes. Peel and serve with the sauce.
Preheat oven to 350 F with a rack in the middle.

Toss together in a large bowl. Position the mushrooms, with their open sides down, on a wire rack set in a sheet pan. Place in the oven and roast for 10 minutes or until the mushrooms are easily pierced with a knife.
Heat in a medium skillet on high heat until shimmering.
Add and saute while constantly stirring until nutty and brown, about 12 minutes.
Add and cook for less than a minute; just until fragrant.
Remove the pan from heat to prevent flaming, add the cognac and deglaze with the residual heat in the pan.
Add, stir to combine, and return the pan to heat. Cook for 1 minute and remove from heat.
Toss in and cool for 10 minutes. Position a rack underneath your oven broiler and turn it on. Overturn the roasted mushrooms so the open side faces up, add a tablespoon of filling to each.
Sprinkle on the filled mushrooms and move them to the broiler. Cook for 3 minutes or until slightly browned (check often because broilers can burn food very quickly). Cool until edible and serve.
Pulse in a food processor to combine.
Add and pulse until no unincorporated butter is evident.
Add and pulse until the mixture is coarse and crumbly.
Add and pulse a few times to roughly combine. Transfer the dough to a medium mixing bowl.

Knead the dough gradually by spritzing its surface, working in the added liquid, and repeating. Continue working until the dough holds its shape when squeezed, stopping at this point even if you do not use the entire bottle of liquid. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 20 minutes.
Add to a large skillet on medium heat. Cook, tossing often, for 2 minutes.
Add and cook while tossing for another 30 seconds.
Add and cook until the residual heat in the pan has melted the butter.
Add evenly to pears and cook for another 2 minutes or until the fruit has softened. Remove from heat.
Fold into the filling and cool to room temperature. Preheat your oven to 400 F.

Dust the parchment paper with flour, place the dough on it, and roll it out to a thickness of 1/4 inch. Cut around the edges to make a uniform circle and move the parchment and dough to an upside-down sheet pan.
Place in the middle of the dough so that a 3-inch margin is left around the edge. Spoon the cooked filling over the cake.

Add evenly over the filling. Lift the edges of the dough and fold them over the filling, working in a circle to fold over the entire unfilled portion of the dough. The dough will not completely cover the filling.
Beat together and brush onto the crust.
Sprinkle evenly over the tart and bake for 30 minutes or until the crust is golden brown and the filling is bubbly. Carefully remove from the oven, cool completely, and serve.
Bring to a boil in an electric kettle.
Grind somewhat coarsely in a hand burr grinder.

Place your V60 dripper on your carafe and place the filter inside the dripper. Add the ground coffee and pour water over it, swirling from the inside to the outside. When the water level recedes, add more, swirling from inside to out each time, and continue until you have either used all the water or have made enough coffee to satisfy your needs. Cool until drinkable and then consume with abandon.
Pulse in 10 separate 1-second bursts and remove to a large bowl.
Pulse in 10 separate 1-second bursts and remove to the bowl with the sirloin.
Add and mix gently together by hand.

Wrap your digital scale in plastic wrap to prevent contamination; then, use it to measure out 4 separate 5-ounce patties from the meat mixture. Shape them into patties, making them a little wider than they will need to be and dimpling them slightly in the center to account for the shape changes they will undergo once heated.

Heat a large cast-iron skillet or griddle on medium heat for 3 minutes. Place the patties on the hot surface, and space them apart by at least 2 inches, because steam escaping from each burger lowers the surrounding temperature and might prevent proper cooking of its neighbors if they are too close. Cook for 4-5 minutes per side, depending on your doneness preference, and then rest for 2 minutes. Note: as satisfying as it may be, never smash the burgers with your spatula.
Serve with condiments of your choice.
Preheat your oven to 325 F.
Pulse in a food processor until the mixture is all crumbs; then, move to a large bowl.
Pulse in a food processor until roughly chopped. Move to the bowl with the bread crumbs.
Add to the processor, pulse for 1 second 10 times, and move to the bowl.
Add to the processor, pulse for 1 second 10 times, and move to the bowl.
Add to the bowl and mix with your hands - use a folding motion, rather than a squeezing motion, in order to preserve the texture of the loaf.
Line a half sheet pan with the parchment paper and place the meat mixture on it (do not use a loaf pan). Shape the meat into a loaf and bake in the heated oven for 10 minutes.

Combine in a small bowl and whisk together. After the first ten minutes of cooking have passed, brush the glaze onto the loaf and cook for an additional 25 minutes or until the internal temperature of the loaf reaches 155 F. Cool for 10 minutes. slice, and serve.
Bring to a simmer in a medium saucepan on medium heat.
Whisk together in a large bowl until combined and slightly lightened in color.
Mix into the eggs and whisk vigorously until the mixture lightens in color and falls off the whisk in long ribbons.

Add to the eggs and whisk thoroughly to combine. Carefully pour in a half cup of the hot cream and whisk to combine. Repeat half-cup additions until about a third of the total cream mixture has been added; then, add all of the remaining cream and whisk to thoroughly combine it with the egg mixture. Take care to whisk the edges of the bowl to incorporate any of the yolk mixture that is clinging to the side. Return the mixture to the saucepan.

Place the saucepan on medium heat and cook until the mixture reaches 175 F and is slightly thickened from the gentle cooking of the eggs. Remove from heat and transfer to a heatproof bowl. Place in the refrigerator, uncovered, for a half hour.
Whisk in, cover with plastic wrap, and return to the fridge for another 4 hours or until the mixture reaches 40 degrees F.
Process in your ice cream maker according to directions. Serve immediately for soft-serve consistency, or place in the freezer for a few hours to firm up for service.
Preheat your oven to 325 F.
Crumble into your food processor and process until finely ground, about 30 seconds.
Add and pulse briefly to combine.
Add and process until the mixture resembles wet sand. Transfer the mixture into a glass pie dish and press evenly into the bottom and sides. Brown in the oven for 15-20 minutes or until golden.
Divide the gelatin and water evenly in two separate small containers.
Whisk together in a medium saucepan until well-incorporated
Whisk into the eggs until well-incorporated

Whisk in until well-incorporated. Cook on medium-low heat, stirring constantly, until the mixture reaches 170 degrees F and is slightly thickened and translucent. Remove from heat, incorporate one of the reserved gelatin mixtures, and let stand for 2 minutes. Pass 1 1/4 cups of the mixture through a strainer directly into the prepared pie shell and place the shell in the freezer to rapidly cool it.
Add to saucepan along with the other reserved gelatin mixture. Stir until the cream cheese melts from the residual heat in the pan, returning to heat briefly if the cream cheese does not melt.
Whip in a stand mixer until foamy but not stuff, about 1 minute.

Add to eggs and increase speed to medium-high. Whip until stuff and glossy - about 4 minutes. Add the cream cheese mixture and whip briefly to combine. Add to the cooled pie shell, mound slightly in the center, and refrigerate for at least 4 hours before serving.
Heat in a large skillet on high heat.
Cook until lightly golden, about 4 minutes.
Reduce heat to medium and cook until celery is tender, about 4 minutes.
Cook until flour is lightly toasted, about 2 minutes.
Whisk in slowly and cook until the flour has thickened, about 4 minutes.
Stir in and cook until very thick, about 6 minutes. Remove from heat, transfer to a heatproof bowl, and chill for 2 hours or until firm.
Pulse briefly in a food processor to make crumbs.

Remove a heaping tablespoon of the mushroom dough and shape it into a 1-inch ball. Roll the croquette in the flour, shake off the excess, roll it in the egg wash, roll it in the bread crumbs, and place on a baking sheet. Repeat until all the dough is used; then, lightly cover the baking sheet and refrigerate for 30 minutes.

Heat to 360 degrees in a dutch oven, and fry the croquettes in batches until they are golden, taking care not to fry too many at once because the heat will drop and the croquettes will become greasy. Adjust the seasoning of the croquettes with salt and pepper.
Pass to guests while serving the croquettes.
Combine in a large saucepan on medium heat. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the onion is softened, about 5 minutes.
Add and cook until fragrant, about 2 minutes.
Stir in and cook for 1 minute.

Stir in and bring to a simmer. Simmer vigorously, stirring occasionally to prevent burning on the bottom, until the lentils are soft and partially broken down, about 15 minutes. Then, whisk vigorously for 30 seconds or until the mixture is partially pureed.
Add and adjust salt if needed. Cover and keep warn, or refrigerate for up to 3 days.
Combine in a small dish and stir together. Drizzle a teaspoon or two of the mint butter on each serving of soup.
Garnish and serve.
Microwave until wilted, about 3 minutes. Chop and set aside 1/3 cup. Transfer the remainder to a blender.
As with the spinach: microwave until wilted, about 4 minutes. Chop and reserve 1/3 cup. Transfer the remainder to the blender with the spinach.
Melt in a large skillet on medium-high heat.
Add and cook until fragrant, about 30 seconds.
Add and cook until softened, about 3 minutes.
Add and cook for 3 minutes until just beginning to brown.
Stir in and cook until pan is dry and beginning to brown again. Remove from heat and transfer to blender, waiting, if necessary, until the mix is cool enough for your blender to handle.
Add to blender and process until smooth. Return to skillet.
Add along with reserved chopped greens and simmer for 5 minutes. Adjust salt and pepper levels if necessary.
Add and serve.
Microwave together for 1 minute, steep for 5 minutes, and then separate the mushrooms from the liquid, reserving both.
Pulse in food processor briefly to turn into crumbs and transfer to a large bowl.
Add to the bread.
Add to the food processor along with the reserved mushrooms and pulse a few times to chop and combine. Add to bread mixture.
Add to bread mix and combine well, taking care not to smash the mixture too aggressively. Divide into 16 portions and refrigerate for 15 minutes.
Puree in food processor.
Combine in a separate bowl and set aside.

Heat in a large skillet; then, brown the meatballs on all sides, working in batches if necessary. Remove the meatballs to a plate lined with paper towels; leave the fat in the skillet. Add the anchovy mix and cook for 30 seconds.

Add along with reserved mushroom liquid and pureed tomatoes. Bring to a simmer, add the meatballs, and cook for 12-15 minutes or until the meatballs are cooked through. Remove the meatballs, boost the heat, and reduce the sauce until it is thick enough to cling to the meatballs.
Garnish and serve.
Pat the chicken dry and season with the salt and pepper.
Add to a dutch oven on medium-high heat. When the oil is shimmering, add the chicken and brown for 3-4 minutes per side, working in batches if necessary.
Add to dutch oven and reduce heat to medium.
Add and cook until browned, about 5 minutes.
Add and cook until fragrant, about 1 minute.

Add and bring to a boil, scraping up any bits clinging to the bottom of the pan. Return the chicken to the pan, reduce the heat to medium-low, cover the pot, and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the chicken reaches 195 F internally. Flip the chicken 5 minutes into cooking. When the chicken is fully cooked, transfer it to a cutting board. Use an immersion blender to process to remaining liquid until it is smooth. Use forks to shred the chicken into bite-sized pieces and return it to the pureed sauce. Cook for 10 more minutes or until the sauce has thickened and is clinging to the chicken.
Stir into chicken.
Serve, passing all ingredients for guests to self-assemble.
Simmer for 35 minutes or until soft, skimming the surface of the liquid if scum forms. Remove half the lentils, process the liquid until smooth, and return the whole lentils to the soup.
Combine in a medium saucepan and simmer until translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add to onions and simmer gently for 5 minutes.
Add to a mortar and pestle and process together into a paste.

Melt in a small saucepan and add the garlic-coriander paste. Fry for 2 minutes or until the garlic starts to color. Stir into the soup along with the sauteed greens, remove the soup from heat (if still cooking), cover, and rest for 5 minutes.
Garnish and serve.
Preheat oven to 200 F.
Cut with a mandoline fitted with a thick-julienne attachment. Move to a large container filled with cold water.
Whisk together in a medium bowl.
Slowly whisk in, working until the batter is smooth. Refrigerate for at least 15 minutes or up to an hour.

Add to a large dutch oven on high heat. Drain the potatoes and thoroughly dry them with towels or a salad spinner. When the oil reaches 320 F, fry the potatoes in 4 batches for 3 minutes each batch, so that they are all pale and droopy. Remove each batch to a wire rack overturned over paper towels or newspaper, so that the fried food will not be in direct contact with the paper. Increase the oil heat to 350 F.

Dredge the fish in the cornstarch and shake off as much as possible. When the oil has heated to 350 F, dip the fish in the batter and lower it gently into the oil, taking care not to crowd the fat. Cook each piece until the batter sets on one side; then, flip the pieces and cook on the other side until fully golden brown. Move the fish into the warmed oven. When the fish is all cooked, heat the oil to 375 F.
Cook the reserved potatoes once again in the hot oil until they are golden brown and fully cooked. Remove and drain.
Season the fish to your liking and serve.
Broil, turning often, or cook directly over a glass flame until blackened all over. Set aside.

Combine in a large stock pot and add extra water if needed to cover the meat. Bring to a boil over high heat and continue to boil for 15 minutes. Drain the meat in a colander, discarding the water, and taking care to handle only when cool enough, remove any debris from the boiling process from the meat and bones. Return to the pot.

Add along with the charred onions and ginger, cover with water, and bring to a boil. Once boiling, reduce to a simmer and cook, skimming as scum forms on the surface, until the brisket and chuck are tender but not falling apart - about 90 minutes. Transfer the brisket and chuck to a bowl and cover them with cold water. Refrigerate until it is time to serve.

Simmer for another 4 hours, skimming as needed and adding additional water if the level dips below the solids. Strain the broth through a fine mesh strainer and discard the bones and aromatics, picking the meat from the oxtails and bones and reserving it if you so desire. Add additional water, if necessary, to bring the liquid total to 4 quarts. Carefully skim the fat from the surface of the broth.

Divide evenly among 6 serving bowls, or reserve some ingredients for guests to choose their own levels of each spice and flavor. Pour hot broth over noodles and serve immediately, allowing the hot broth to cook the sliced meat.

Place in the freezer for 5 minutes to firm up. When the mangoes are firm enough to peel with a potato peeler, peel their skins and then use the peeler to remove strips of flesh until you have reached the pit of the mango. If the flesh is too ripe to stand up to a peeler, you can cut it off with a knife and chop it into 1/2-inch chunks.
Combine in a cocktail shaker and shake to thoroughly combine. Set aside for a few minutes to let the shallot mellow.
Combine in a large bowl along with the sliced mango and the lemon dressing. Toss to combine and serve immediately.
Combine in a jar and shake to combine.

Place each slab bone-side up on a large sheet of heavy-duty aluminum foil and sprinkle the pre-mixed rub liberally on its surface. Wrap the ribs in the foil, leaving the seal loose on one end so that liquid can be poured in later. Refrigerate for at least 2 hours and up to overnight.

Combine in a mixing cup with a pour spout. Partially unroll the foil on each slab of ribs at the loose end, and pour the mixture in, dividing it evenly between the packages. Reseal the loose ends and preheat oven to 250 F, place the ribs on a half sheet pan, and place in the oven for 3 hours.

When the ribs are done cooking, unwrap the ends of the foil through which you poured the liquid, and very carefully tip so that the liquid flows into a medium saucepan. Turn the heat on high under the saucepan, and reduce the sauce, whisking occasionally, until it thickens to a barbecue-sauce-like consistency. Remove the sauce and skim any fat from the surface.

Unwrap the ribs completely and place them back on the half sheet pan. Brush them with some of the reduced glaze. Turn on your broiler and place the ribs under it for a couple of minutes or until the surface is browned and caramelized. Cut the ribs apart, if you like, and serve, passing extra sauce to guests.
Add to a large skillet on high heat and heat until just beginning to smoke.
Add to the oil and cook, stirring, until just beginning to turn soft - about 1 minute.
Add and cook until the shrimp is mostly pink.
Cook, stirring often, until the shrimp is completely cooked. Remove from heat.
Serve.
Pulse in the bowl of a food processor for about 30 seconds or until the butter is no longer evident.

Add and continue processing until the dough rides up on the blade, producing a silky, stringy dough - about 2 minutes. Transfer to a lightly greased mixing bowl, cover with plastic wrap, and rest for at least 2 hours or up to overnight (refrigerate if resting overnight).
Whisk together in a medium saucier until well-combined.

Whisk into the sugar mixture until very smooth.  Place the saucier on medium-low heat and cook, constantly whisking, until just starting to warm - about 3 minutes. Increase the heat to medium and cook, constantly whisking, until the mixture begins to thicken due to the gentle cooking o the eggs. When the mixture reaches the point where it is bubbling, cook it for another 1 minute, whisking vigorously. Remove from heat.

Whisk into the custard, transfer to a heatproof bowl, and cover with plastic wrap, pressing the wrap directly onto the surface to prevent a skin from forming. Refrigerate for 1 hour or until the mixture cools to room temperature, about 68 F. Cooling the custard in a wide, shallow vessel like a pie plate will speed the cooling process.
Fit a stand mixer with its paddle attachment and beat the custard until it is creamy and smooth.
Fold into the custard. Use immediately or refrigerate for up to 3 days.

Retrieve the dough and turn it out onto a thoroughly-floured surface. Roll the dough out to a thickness of 1/16 inch and brush away excess flour from the surface. Brush it with the egg wash; then, fold it in half and roll it once again to 1/16 inch thickness. Cut into 3-4 inch rounds using a cup or a cookie-cutter; then, re-roll the remaining scraps to 1/16 inch again and repeat.

Heat the oil in a large dutch oven until it reaches 360 F. Obtain cannoli forms, or heavy-duty aluminum foil rolled into firm tube shapes, and lightly grease the forms. Place each form on a dough round and fold the dough around the round so that the ends meet. Use a small bit of egg wash to firmly seal the rounds. Fry 3 or 4 t a time until they are blistered, pale, and golden brown, about 2 minutes per batch. Transfer the cooked shells to a baking sheet lined with paper towels. Carefully remove the forms while the shells are still hot. Fill immediately with a piping bag, or store the shells in an airtight container for up to a week.

Cover with cold water in a large stock pot and bring the water to a boil. Empty into a large colander as soon as the water boils. Wash the bones under cold, running water, removing the dark marrow and blood carefully so that the remaining bones are uniformly white and grey.
Heat in a cast-iron skillet until starting to smoke.
Add and cook, tossing occasionally, until deeply charred and almost blackened - about 15 minutes.

Add to the stock pot along with re reserved bones and charred vegetables, and cover with cold water. Turn on high heat and bring to a rolling boil. Skim scum off the surface as it forms for the first half hour, after which the scum should stop forming. Reduce the heat to a low simmer, cover the pot, and cook for 4 hours or until the fatback is completely tender.

Remove the fatback carefully with a slotted spoon. Place it in a sealed, heatproof container and move it to the refrigerator. Cook the broth for an additional 6-8 hours, adding extra water as necessary to keep the bones submerged.

At the end of the cooking period, increase the heat if necessary to reduce to broth to a total of 3 quarts. Strain the broth through a fine mesh strainer lined with cheesecloth into a clean pot. Skim and discard the fat from the broth. Finely chop the reserved fatback and whisk it into the broth. Serve with the noodles and condiments of your choice.
Preheat oven to 375 F.
Heat in a large skillet over medium-low heat.
Add and cook until very tender and beginning to brown, about 20 minutes.
Add and cook until beginning to tenderize, about 2 minutes.
Stir in and cook for 1 minute.
Stir in and cook until thickened, about 10 minutes.
Stir in.

Gently crack over the tomato mixture, forming a small well for each egg if necessary to help them stay in place. Adjust the seasoning if necessary and move to the oven. Bake just until the eggs set, 7-10 minutes.
Serve with the warm Shakshuka.
Combine in a medium saucepan and place over medium heat.

Wrap in cheesecloth or a spice bag, tie to secure, and add to the saucepan. Bring the mixture just barely to a boil; then, reduce to a simmer on lower heat. Simmer until the celery root is tender, 20-25 minutes. Remove the thyme and garlic and strain, reserving the liquid and the celery root. Transfer the celery root to a blender and puree - add the reserved liquid gradually until the mixture is smooth but not too loose.
Add with the blender running.
Season and serve.
Combine in a tall glass or a julep cup and swirl until the sugar is dissolved.
Place the mint in the glass and gently bruise it with a wooden spoon, taking care to spread the aromatic oils of the mint all over the inside of the glass without crushing it into mush.

Add, including enough ice to half fill the glass. Stir to chill the bourbon and combine it with the mint and sugar. Add more ice to fill the glass, and stir until the drink is well-chilled and the sides of the glass frost.
Garnish and serve.
Melt in a small saucepan until foamy but not beginning to brown.
Place in a blender, turn the blender on, and very slowly drizzle in the butter while the blender is running. Add a tiny bit more water if the mixture becomes too thick to blend.

Add to the egg mixture, adjusting the seasoning to your taste if desired. Move the newly made hollandaise sauce to a bowl and cover it with plastic wrap, pressing the wrap directly onto the surface of the sauce to prevent a skin from forming.

Place in a medium saucepan, adding water if necessary so that it fills the pan up to about 3 inches. Bring to a simmer; do not let the water boil, but instead heat it so that just a few bubbles are forming on the bottom.

Working with a maximum of 4 eggs at one time, swirl the water so that a small vortex forms in the middle, and gently ladle in one egg at a time. Let the swirling water form the egg and begin to set the white before adding the next egg. Let the eggs poach for 4-5 minutes each, or until the white is firmly set but the yolk inside is still runny. Remove the eggs and set them aside.
Split and toast in a toaster, toaster oven, or regular oven. Toast thoroughly so that the muffins will stand up to the moist eggs, yolks, and hollandaise.
Cook until golden brown and crisp at the edges, about 6 minutes.
Distribute the english muffins, two to a plate, and butter them. Arrange a slice of ham and a poached egg on each one, and top with a couple tablespoons of hollandaise.
Garnish and serve.
Place in a small cup or bowl and process with an immersion blender until smooth. Set aside.
Bring to a boil and keep hot.
Heat in a large, heavy dutch oven until shimmering.
Add to the oil and cook until softened but not browned, about 8 minutes.
Add and simmer until the pan is mostly dry, about 4 minutes.

Add and cook until the jalapeo is just softened, about 2 minutes. Add 1 tablespoon of the chipotle puree and let it simmer by itself in the center of the pot for 1 minute; then, stir to combine it with the vegetables.

Add, stir to combine, and bring to a boil. Boil for 15 minutes; then, reduce to a simmer, partially cover the pot, and boil for 90 minutes. Add water if necessary to loosen the mixture up so that it is not sludgy. Season with salt and freshly ground black pepper and continue cooking, if necessary, until the beans are totally soft. If necessary to achieve the desired consistency, slightly puree the mixture with an immersion blender.
Combine in a small bowl and let set for 30 minutes. Drain, rinse, and dry the onions. Reserve them in the refrigerator for later use.
Adjust the seasoning of the soup with vinegar and more of the chipotle puree.
Garnish and serve.
Heat in a large skillet until shimmering.
Add to the oil and saut for 5 minutes or until softened but not brown.
Add and cook for 2 minutes.
Add and cook for 5 minutes or until the wine has reduced by about half.
Add and cook, stirring to break up, for 5 minutes or until no pink remains in the color of the meat.

Stir in, cover the pot, reduce the heat to medium-low, and simmer for 12 minutes or until the potatoes are tender. Uncover, discard the bay leaves, adjust the seasoning, and serve (ideally with black beans and white rice)
Combine in bowl and stir to incorporate. Place in one or several jars, seal, and refrigerate for at least six hours or up to overnight.
Add and serve.
Stir in, cover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate for at least two hours to let the chia seeds hydrate and the flavors meld.
Stir together in a medium bowl.
Sprinkle on and serve.

Roughly chop the cucumbers and place them in a jar or bowl that can fit your immersion blender. Process the cucumber slices until they are completely pureed; then, pass the puree through a fine mesh strainer. Place 3/4 cup of the liquid in a saucepan.
Add to the cucumber water and heat just until the sugar dissolves.
Stir into the cucumber liquid; then, move the mixture to a heatproof jar, seal the jar, and run it under cold water for 5 minutes or until it is chilled back to room temperature.
Whisk into the cooled liquid until it is slightly foamy and the egg is well-incorporated.
Charge the cream whipper with the CO2 canisters; then, move it to the refrigerator for at least 2 hours to set up. Dispense foam as needed.
Combine in a medium saucepan and bring to a boil; then, cool back down to room temperature.
Place in a heavy-duty zip-top bag and add the marinade. Squeeze out excess air, seal the bag, and place in the refrigerator for at least 8 hours and up to 1 day.

Light the charcoal in a chimney starter and when it is lit, place it on the grill so that it occupies one side. Grill the chops until they register 135 F internally (for medium doneness). If the chops look like they might burn on the outside before cooking through, move them to the half of the grill not above the charcoal so they will cook more gently. Serve with rice.
Combine in a medium saucepan over medium heat and fry the garlic until it is lightly browned and crispy. Remove it and drain it on paper towels.
Heat in a dutch oven on medium heat until shimmering.
Add and cook until tender but not browned, about 5 minutes.
Add and cook until fragrant, 1 or 2 minutes.
Add and cook until browned all over.
Stir in and cook for 1 minute.
Add and stir until well-coated.
Stir in, scrape up any brown bits on the bottom of the pan, and bring to a boil. Cook for 20 minutes or until the rice is completely cooked and the liquid has thickened.
Stir in along with salt and pepper to taste.
Garnish and serve.
Whisk together in a medium bowl until the salt and sugar are dissolved.

Toss in the liquid and submerge. Let sit for 30 minutes. Drain, reserving the liquid, rinse the onions and radishes, and dry them lightly on paper towels. Use as garnish immediately or refrigerate for up to 2 days. The reserved brine can be used as the base for a vinaigrette.
Preheat oven to 500 F.

Toss together in a large bowl to thoroughly coat the asparagus. Line a half sheet pan with aluminum foil and place the spears on the foil in a single layer. Place in the oven and roast for 5 minutes; then, toss, and roast for an additional 5 minutes or until the tips are starting to brown. Serve immediately.
Combine in the bottom of a highball glass and stir to dissolve the salt.
Add to the glass and stir until well-chilled.
Garnish and serve.
Combine in a blender and puree until smooth.
Season liberally with salt and pepper and rest so that the meat comes to room temperature while you light the grill.

Light in a chimney starter, spread on your grill, add the grate, and cover. Let the grill preheat for 5 minutes. Grill 3-5 minutes per side or until well-browned all over; then, remove to a cutting board and rest for 10 minutes. Slice the steak thinly against the grain.
Arrange the arugula on a large platter, top with the tomatoes and tortilla chips. Add the steak, pour on the cilantro-lime dressing, and serve.
Heat your grill to high.
Cut the ends of the melon; then, stand it up on one end and slice off the rind on all sides so that what remains is a large, rectangular chunk of melon. Cut the melon rhomboid into six equal slices.
Toss together in a small bowl and move the shallots to the grill. Cook them for 2-3 minutes or until they are softened and charred. Remove them to the bowl they came from.
Toss with the shallots.
Brush onto the melon slices and move them to the grill, cooking them for 5 minutes or until they are nicely marked and warmed through.
Place each watermelon slab on a plate and equally distribute the grilled shallots, feta, olives, and mint. Adjust with salt and pepper to taste. Serve.
Combine in a small saucepan and bring to a boil to dissolve sugar. Remove from heat and cool for 15 minutes.
Add to the cooled syrup, cover the pot, and steep for at least 4 hours or up to overnight. Remove the greens.
Combine with  the syrup in a large shaker, shake to combine, strain, and serve.
Combine in a cocktail shaker and shake to combine.
Add and shake for 30-60 seconds or until very well chilled. Strain into a cocktail glass.
Garnish and serve.
Rub the lime wedge around the edge of a pint glass, spread the salt on a plate in a thin layer, and rub the rim of the glass in the salt to encrust it.
Add to the glass and stir to dissolve the salt.
Add to glass, filling with as much of the beer as possible. As you drink, top the glass off with the remaining beer.
Combine in a small bowl and set aside.
Place in a small saucepan and bring to a boil. Remove from heat and whisk in the gelatin mixture. Move the mixture to the refrigerator for 30 minutes, or until it just begins to gel.
Stir into the mix and move it to a mold of your choice. Refrigerate for at least 2 hours to set.
Combine in a medium saucepan and let sit for 10 minutes so that the gelatin will hydrate. Heat briefly, until the mixture reaches 135 F.
Combine in a large bowl.
Add to the hot milk mixture. When incorporated, slowly stir in the vanilla mixture.

Combine in a very large bowl and place the saucepan in it. Stir constantly until the mixture thickens to egg-nog consistency and registers 50 F on a thermometer. Distribute the mixture evenly among 8 ramekins, cover them with plastic wrap, and move them to the refrigerator. Chill for 4 hours or until set.

To unmold, place the water in a medium bowl and dip the ramekins in it, one at a time, for 3 seconds each. Run your finger around the edges; then, dip in for another 3 seconds. Invert a plate over the ramekin, overturn the ramekin on the plate, and tap gently to release. Serve.
Combine in a small jar and shake to thoroughly mix.
Whisk together along with 2 tablespoons of the spice mixture in a large bowl.

Cut the chicken into 10 pieces: 2 drumsticks, 2 thighs, 2 wings, and 2 halved breasts. Place the chicken in the bowl with the buttermilk mixture and coat each piece thoroughly. Move the contents of the bowl to a large zip-top bag and place it in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours or up to overnight.

Whisk together in a large bowl, along with the remaining spice mixture. Add 3 tablespoons of the chicken marinade and work it into the flour. Working one piece at a time, remove the chicken from the bag, let excess marinade drip off of it, and place it in the flour. Move the chicken around in the flour to coat it, and press the flour mixture onto each piece of chicken to get it to adhere in a thick layer. Preheat your oven to 350 F.

Heat to 425 F in a large dutch oven; do not let the temperature exceed 425 F or the oil will smoke and become unsuitable for cooking. Working one piece at a time, place the chicken in a strainer and lightly tap it to remove excess flour. Carefully lay it in the hot oil, and continue until all of the chicken is in the pan. Cook for 3-6 minutes on the first side, or until the first sides light brown and crispy. The temperature of the fat should drop to 300 F but not below. Flip the chicken and cook it for an additional 4 minutes. Remove to a paper towel-lined plate, and serve when cool enough to handle.
Preheat oven to 425 F.
Whisk together in a small bowl.
Combine in a food processor and pulse a couple of times to combine.

Scatter the cubed butter over the flour mixture and pulse until the mixture looks like coarse crumbs. Transfer to a large bowl. Add the buttermilk mixture and fold with a rubber spatula until just combined; then, transfer to a floured work surface and knead until the dough comes together in a ball. Add extra flour 1 tablespoon at a time, if necessary to firm up the dough.

Roll the dough into a 12-inch square. Fold the dough into thirds so that it is 4 inches wide; then, fold the dough rectangle in thirds again so you have a 4-inch square. Roll this square back out until it reaches 12 inches. Repeat the folding process and roll it out to 12 inches once more. Cut as many 4-inch rounds as will fit on the rolled-out sheet; then, form the dough scraps into a ball and roll the ball out into a sheet of the same thickness as the first batch of biscuits. Cut more 4-inch rounds from this sheet and move all of the cut biscuits to a half sheet pan lined with parchment paper or a silicon baking mat.

Brush the tops of the biscuits with the melted butter and place them in the oven. Bake for a total of 15 minutes, turning the pan around halfway through to encourage even cooking. Remove from the oven, move to a cooling rack, and cool for 5 minutes. Serve.
Pat the scallops dry on a layer of paper towels; then, salt them thoroughly on all sides. Top with another layer of towels and place the scallops in the refrigerator for 15 minutes.

Add the oil to a cast-iron skillet and heat the skillet on high heat until the oil begins to smoke. Remove the scallops from the fridge, pat them dry once more, and add them to the pan, spacing them so that their escaping steam will not interfere with the cooking of their neighbors. Cook for 1 minute without disturbing; then, flip them and cook for another minute. Move them to a plate lined with clean paper towels to drain them. Serve.
Halve and juice all the lemons. Pour the juice into a container and move it to the refrigerator.

Cut all the lemon rinds into 1-inch chunks. Combine with the sugar in a large bowl. Stir the rinds and sugar once every hour, and let them macerate for a total of three hours. The sugar should be completely dissolved.

Add to the lemon rinds along with 1 cup of the chilled lemon juice. Stir well, strain into a carafe or pitcher, and use immediately or refrigerate for up to a week. Adjust with extra water or lemon juice to taste when serving.
Combine all ingredients in a blender and pulse for 10 seconds. Refrigerate for at least an hour and up to two days.

Heat a small nonstick pan on medium heat. Add butter to the pan to coat the surface; then, add an ounce of batter to the middle of the pan. Swirl it to spread it around evenly within the pan. Cook for 30 seconds on one side, flip, and cook for an additional 10 seconds. Lay the crepes flat as they finish, and keep them under a towel to keep them warm. Serve with your favorite toppings and accoutrements.
Combine all ingredients in a blender and pulse for 10 seconds. Refrigerate for at least an hour and up to two days.

Heat a small nonstick pan on medium heat. Add butter to the pan to coat the surface; then, add an ounce of batter to the middle of the pan. Swirl it to spread it around evenly within the pan. Cook for 30 seconds on one side, flip, and cook for an additional 10 seconds. Lay the crepes flat as they finish, and keep them under a towel to keep them warm. Serve with your favorite toppings and accoutrements.

Place in a medium saucepan and add just enough cold water to cover the noodles. Bring to a boil and cook for 6 minutes or until the water is mostly absorbed and the noodles are al dente (i.e. mostly cooked but still a little firm in the middle).
Add and bring to a boil.
Add and cook for 2 minutes or until the cheese is melted and has reduced to a thick sauce.
Stir in along with more salt to taste. Serve.
Combine in a bowl and set aside.
Bring to a boil in a large stock pot.
Combine in a small bowl and stir to incorporate.
Press the prepared paprika mixture into all sides of each steak.

Add to a large skillet on high heat and cook until just starting to smoke. Add the meat and cook, turning once or twice, until the meat is cooked to an internal temperature of 115-125 F, depending on your preference for doneness. Transfer the meat to a plate and set it aside.
Add to the skillet used for the meat and lower the heat to medium. Cook the mushrooms for 8 minutes or until they are just starting to brown.
Add and cook until the onions and mushrooms are well-browned, about 6 minutes.
Add and cook until fragrant, about 1 minute.
Add and cook for 30 seconds or until mostly evaporated.

Add along with any juices that have collected on the plate with the meat. Cook until the liquid has reduced to just a few tablespoons and will coat the back of a spoon. Add the reserved broth and gelatin mixture and bring to a simmer. Pour the liquid off into a heatproof container with a handle so that you can pour the liquid.

Place in a large bowl and, constantly whisking, pour the hot liquid over the sour cream. Whisk aggressively (and carefully) until the mixture is fully incorporated. Return the sour cream mixture to the pan.

Add and bring to a boil on medium-high heat. Adjust the flavor with salt and pepper. Add the reserved steaks and cook until they are just warmed through, about 1 minute. Remove from heat and set aside.

Cook according to package directions. Drain, reserving 1 cup of the cooking liquid. Remove the steaks from the reserved liquid and set them aside on a cutting board; then, combine the sauce-and-onion mix with the pasta and stir to combine. Use the reserved pasta cooking liquid to loosen the mixture if it is too thick.
Thinly slice the reserved steaks. Evenly divide the pasta and cream sauce among 4 bowls, top with the sliced steak, and finish with extra sauce, sour cream, and parsley. Serve.
Combine in a small bowl and soak while preparing the rest of the salad. Drain, reserving the vinegar.
Combine in a salad bowl along with the pickled onion and 2 tablespoons of the pickling vinegar.
Add along with salt to taste and stir to thoroughly combine. Adjust with more vinegar and salt, if desired.
Add to the salad along with extra oregano and olive oil. Serve immediately.
Combine in a large bowl and cover with cold water by several inches. Let sit for at least  12 hours and up to 24. Drain and rinse.

Combine in a large pot and cover with water by several inches. Bring to a boil; then, reduce to a simmer and cook for 45 minutes, or until the beans are completely tender. Drain the beans, reserving the cooking liquid. If the liquid is less than 2 quarts, add cold water until it reaches the 2-quart mark.
Combine in the now-empty dutch oven and place on medium-high heat. Cook, stirring constantly, until the pancetta has released its fat.
Add to the pan and cook for 10-15 minutes or until the vegetables are softened but not browned.
Add and cook for 30 seconds or until fragrant.
Add and cook until the tomatoes have released their moisture and the mixture is beginning to fry and crackle.
Add along with the beans and reserved cooking water. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Add and simmer until pasta is tender, about 10 minutes.
Stir in and cook until the spinach is wilted, about 1 minute. Discard parmesan rind.
Garnish and serve.
Combine in a large heatproof bowl.

Combine the water and salt in a large pot and bring to a boil. Cook until the pasta is al dente. Remove the pasta with tongs and place it in the bowl with the cheese, reserving the liquid in the pot. Add 1/2 cup of the pasta liquid to the bowl and stir until the butter melts and the cheese melts. Continue until the texture is homogenous, adding a little splash of pasta water if the mixture becomes too dry. When the sauce is creamy, adjust the flavor with salt, and serve with extra grated cheese.
Preheat oven to 475 F.
Whisk together in a large bowl.
Whisk together in a medium bowl. Pour over the dry ingredients and mix with a rubber spatula just until the mixture is incorporated and pulls away from the sides of the bowl.

Line a half sheet pan with parchment paper and scoop quarter-cup portions of dough onto the sheet, spacing them an inch and a half apart. There should be a total of 12 biscuits on the pan. Place in the oven for 12-14 minutes, or until golden brown on the bottom and well-set.
Brush the tops of the biscuits with melted butter and serve.
Squeeze into a copper cup and drop the squeezed rind into the cup.
Add to the cup.
Add ginger beer to nearly the top of the copper cup and serve.
Combine in a coffee mug and whisk vigorously for about a minute, or until the yolk is foamy, rich, and thick.
Add to whipped yolk and whisk briefly to combine. Note that eating raw  or undercooked eggs can expose you to food poisoning risk.
Combine in a highball glass and stir to combine.
Garnish with the lime wedge and serve.
Melt in a large dutch oven over medium heat.
Add and cook until softened but not browned, about 5 minutes. If the mixture gets too dry, add a little olive oil to keep it lubricated. Add the remaining oil, if any, at the end of this step.
Add and bring to a simmer, stirring occasionally to prevent burning on the bottom.

Add and continue to cook until the Russet potatoes have completely broken down, 25-30 minutes. The greens should be very tender and the soup should have a creamy consistency - you can use a fork or potato masher to help the Russets break down.
Stir in, adjust seasoning to taste with salt and pepper, and serve.
Combine in a large bowl and stir until well-combined.
Add and stir gently to combine, trying to to break up the larger chunks of crab meat too much.
Line a sheet pan with the parchment and form the crab mix into medium-sized patties.

Add to a cast-iron skillet and heat until the butter is melted. Add the patties and cook, turning often to prevent burning, until they are cooked through and nicely browned on each side. Add more oil if the pan becomes dry; otherwise, the patties will burn.
Serve with the crab cakes.
Whisk together in a large bowl.
Combine with the marinade and toss well to coat. Refrigerate for at least one hour and up to overnight.
Preheat oven to 425.
Use to grease a rimmed baking sheet.

Add to the chicken and toss to combine. Remove the chicken and onion from the marinade and spread the pieces evenly across the pan. Roast the chicken for 30-40 minutes or until it is well-browned and cooked through. Remove, rest for a couple minutes until it is cool enough to handle, and cut into bit-sized pieces.
Serve with the warm chicken.
Slice the cucumbers lengthwise down the middle and use a spoon to scoop out the seeds and gelatinous substance inside. Slice them 1/8 inch thick with a knife or a mandoline.
Whisk together in a mixing bowl, add the cucumber, and stir to combine. Cover, refrigerate for at least one hour, and use.
Place a skillet over medium-low heat and preheat it for 5 minutes; then, add the butter and swirl it around the pan until it melts and covers the bottom.
Using a cookie cutter or the rim of a glass, cut a 3-4 inch hole from the center of the bread. Place both pieces of bread in the butter and toast them on both sides.
Lift up the bread and add the butter, swirling the pan to melt it. Replace the bread upside down so the other side begins to toast.
Crack into the hole in the larger piece of bread and place a lid on the skillet. Cook until the top of the egg is just set.
Garnish and  serve. Note that eating raw or undercooked eggs, while delicious, is a food safety hazard; therefore, consume an over-easy egg at your own risk.
Combine in a medium bowl and stir to incorporate.

Divide the chicken mixture evenly between the two tortillas, leaving half the tortilla empty and a half-inch border around the other half. Fold each tortilla in half, pressing firmly to seal in the filling.

Heat in a cast-iron skillet until the oil shimmers. Add the tortillas and cook, moderately agitating the pan to help distribute the oil and prevent sticking, for about 2 minutes. Once the first side is golden brown, flip the tortillas and cook for another 2 minutes. Season with salt to taste, dry briefly on paper towels, and serve.
Add to a cast-iron skillet and heat on medium-high until shimmering.
Add to the oil and cook just until the spinach is wilted, about 1 minute. Transfer to a bowl.
Add to spinach and stir to combine.

Divide the bean mix evenly between the two tortillas, leaving half of each tortilla empty and a half-inch border around the filled half. Fold the tortillas in half, and press them firmly to seal the contents.

Heat in the cast-iron skillet until shimmering. Add the tortillas and cook, gently agitating to distribute the oil and prevent sticking, for about 2 minutes. When the first side is golden brown, flip and cook for another 2 minutes. Drain briefly on a paper towel and serve.
Heat in a cast-iron skillet on medium-high heat until shimmering.
Add to the oil and cook until the zucchini is lightly browned, about 2 minutes.
Add and cook for another 2 minutes.
Add and cook for 30 seconds or until just starting to soften. Move the mixture to a bowl.
Add to bowl and stir to combine.

Divide the mixture evenly between the tortillas and spread it out, leaving half of each tortilla empty and a half-inch gap around the edge of the filled side. Fold each tortilla over itself and press to seal.

Add to the skillet and heat until shimmering. Add the quesadillas and cook until the first side is golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip and cook for an additional 2 minutes. Drain briefly on a paper towel, and serve.

Add to a large dutch oven, with the skins inside a strainer or colander atop the potatoes so they remain segregated. Bring to a boil over high heat and cook until the potatoes are tender, about 15 minutes. Discard the skins, drain the potatoes, and transfer them to a rimmed baking sheet.
Sprinkle over the potatoes and set aside to cool. Transfer to a large bowl once cool enough to handle.

Add to potatoes and stir with a rubber spatula to incorporate. Fold the mixture somewhat aggressively, so that the potatoes release some of their starch and thicken the liquid. Rest the mixture for at least a half hour, or refrigerate for up to a few days. Adjust the seasoning and serve.
Heat in a large stock pot on high heat until boiling. Meanwhile, preheat your oven to 450 F with a rack in the middle.
Add and stir to combine. Return the water to a boil and cook for 10 minutes or until the potatoes are tender all the way through.

Combine in a small saucepan on medium heat. Cook until the garlic just starts to turn golden%2C about 3 minutes. Drain the fat through a fine mesh strainer into a large bowl%2C reserving both the solids and the oil.

When the potatoes are done boiling%2C add them to the bowl with the reserved duck fat and toss to combine. A layer of thick paste should build up on the potatoes as you toss them. Transfer them to a large baking sheet%2C spread them evenly%2C and roast them in the oven for 20 minutes. Toss them with a spatula and roast for another 20 minutes. Toss once more and roast for a final 10-20 minutes or until they are golden and crispy all over. Remove to a large bowl%2C toss with the reserved rosemary and garlic%2C adjust the salt to your taste%2C and serve.
Combine in the bowl of a food processor and process until incorporated into a single ball; then, continue to process for an additional 30 seconds.

Pour into a 13 X 18 inch rimmed baking sheet. Spread it over the entire pan and add the dough. Press the dough gently and evenly over the surface of the pan, and do not worry if it does not make it all the way to the edges of the pan. Cover with plastic wrap and rest for 2-3 hours, or until the dough has slackened and spread out toward the edges of the pan. Remove the plastic wrap, lightly oil your hands, and gently stretch the dough to the edges of the pan, stretching it beyond the edges so that it achieves full coverage even when it stretches back. Set aside for 30 minutes while making the sauce. Heat your oven to 550 F with a rack in the bottom position.
Heat in a large saucepan over medium heat until the oil shimmers.
Add and cook for 1 minute.
Add and mash with a fork or potato masher
Add and bring to a simmer. Cook for 15 minutes and remove from heat. Season to taste with salt and red pepper flakes.

Spread the mozzarella on the surface of the pizza, sparingly apply the sauce, add the pepperoni, and add the pecorino. Cook for 10 minutes. When the pizza is golden brown and crispy on the bottom as evidenced by a gentle peek under the corner, remove it.
Add to the cooked pizza, slice, and serve.
Prepare your sous vide setup to 150 F.

Add to a sous vide bag or gallon zip-top bag. Seal sous vide bags according to manufacturer instructions; if using the gallon zip top bag, seal it most of the way and lower it carefully and slowly into the water until most of the air is expelled; then, finish the seal. Cook for at least 1 hour and up to 4; then, remove to an ice bath for 15 minutes.

Mix in a bowl and stir to combine with a rubber spatula. When the chicken is done and cooled, remove it from its bag and discard the lemon, tarragon, skin, and bones. Cut the chicken into 1/2-inch cubes and fold into the mayonnaise mixture. Like potato salad, the mix will benefit from an hour rest in the fridge to let the flavors meld, but you can serve it right away on sandwiches if you cannot wait.
Juice the lemons and set the juice aside for some other use.
Combine with the lemon rinds in a large bowl and toss to combine. Cover, wait for 45 minutes and then stir again. Complete this a few times - about 3 hours total - until the sugar is all dissolved.

Set the cheesecloth in a strainer over a large, nonreactive bowl. Place the lemons in the bowl of a potato ricer (or just use your hands) and squeeze them with a bit of elbow grease so they release the liquid and oils loosened by the sugar. Discard the cheesecloth and spent rinds and move the liquid to a bottle. Refrigerate it for up to 3 months.
Bring to a boil in a large pot.
Add to the boiling water, reduce the heat to low or a level that maintains a simmer, lid the pot, and cook the eggs for 11 minutes. Move the eggs to an ice bath to stop their cooking. Peel and serve.
Bring to a simmer in a large pot.
Lower gently into the pot of hot water. Cook for 6 minutes; then, serve immediately, or cool in an ice bath and serve at room temperature.

Combine in a large bowl and spread half the mixture evenly across the bottom of a large baking dish. Using a spoon or a lime, make 12 evenly spaced, shallow indentations in the crystals, each one large enough to safely house an egg yolk.

Gently place in the indentations, taking care not to puncture the yolks. Add the remaining salt and sugar mixture and gently distribute it so that it completely conceals each yolk. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for one week or until the yolks are as thick as parmesan cheese. Remove them, rinse off the crystals, and store in a plastic bag. They can be grated onto pastas, roasted vegetables, avocados, and whatever else you can fathom, using a microplane grater. If they turn out too sweet for your liking, you can replace some of the sugar with the same amount of salt.
Combine in a large pot and place on high heat. Bring to a boil and cook for 8-9 minutes or until al dente, preparing the rest of the meal while the pasta cooks.
Heat in a large skillet on medium heat.
Add to the heated pan and cook for about 1 minute, or until fragrant.

Drain the sardines and add the drained fish to the pan with the garlic. Stir to combine, breaking up the large chunks with a heatproof spatula. Drain the pasta, reserving the cooking liquid. Add the drained pasta to the sardine mixture in the pan.
Add to the pasta along with a quarter-cup of the pasta cooking liquid and stir vigorously to combine. If the pasta becomes dry and dense, add more cooking liquid a tablespoon at a time to loosen it.
Garnish and serve.

Combine in a small saucepan. Bring to a boil, watching carefully as sweetened liquids have a tendency to boil over. Lower the heat to a simmer, and cook for about 10 minutes or until the liquid thickly coats a rubber spatula.

Prepare the drinks as follows: pour 8 oz (1 cup) of seltzer into a highball glass, add 3/4 tsp of acid phosphate and 3 tbsp of syrup mixture to each glass, and stir to combine. Top with ice and serve.
Add to a blender, cover, and blend until completely smooth. Pass through a fine-mesh strainer and set aside.
Combine in a large, heatproof pitcher or punch bowl. Steep the tea for 2 minutes and remove. Place in the refrigerator until chilled enough to use in a cold drink.
Combine in the pitcher, stir to combine, and rest for 2 minutes so the flavors can meld. Serve.
Combine in a mortar and pestle and work into a paste. Set aside.
Heat in a large dutch oven until shimmering.
Add and cook for 15 seconds.

Add and cook for about 10 minutes or until the onions are well-browned. Every time the onions begin to brown the bottom of the pan, add a tablespoon of water and scrape up the brown bits - you will end up doing this 2 or 3 times. Do not skip the scraping-of-the-brown-bits as it is essential to developing the flavor of the dish. Once the onions are done, add the garlic paste from earlier and stir to combine.
Add, stir to combine, and cook for 30 seconds.
Add and mash up with a big fork or potato masher.
Add, stir to combine, partially cover the pot, and cook, stirring occasionally to prevent burning on the bottom, for 30 minutes or until the mixture is thick and stew-like.
Stir in and serve.
Combine in a large bowl, stir to dissolve the salt, and leave at room temperature for at least 8 and no more than 16 hours. Drain the beans, rinse them, and set aside.
Heat in a dutch oven on medium high heat until shimmering.
Add and cook until lightly browned, about 5 minutes.
Add and cook until the onions are lightly browning, about 8 minutes.
Add and cook for less than a minute, until fragrant.
Cook for 30 seconds or until fragrant. Add the beans and enough water to rise above the beans by about 2 inches.

Add, bring to a boil, and reduce to a simmer. Cover and cook for 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 hours or until the beans are completely tender. Remove the lid and cook for another 20 minutes or until the dish is creamy. If the beans dry out, add a cup of water and keep cooking. Discard bay leaves and thyme.
Divide among 6 plates and serve.
Heat in a medium skillet on medium-low heat until the pepper begins to sizzle, about a minute.

Place in a large skillet and cover with with water. Stir to combine and bring to a boil. Cook for 8-9 minutes or until al dente. Add the pasta and 3 tablespoons of the cooking liquid to the pepper and oil mixture.
Add to the pasta and stir to thoroughly incorporate. Add more pasta cooking liquid if necessary to loosen the mixture.
Add and adjust the salt of the dish to your taste.
Combine in a blender and pulse until uniform and smooth. Set aside. Preheat your oven to 300 F with a rack in the lowest position.
Heat in a large dutch oven until shimmering.

Salt and pepper the beef generously and add to the hot oil. Cook, turning every couple of minutes, until the beef is browned all over, a total of 10 minutes. Place the beef on a big plate and set aside.
Add and cook for 6 minutes or until tender and beginning to brown.
Add and cook until well-browned on all sides, 6-8 minutes. Add salt and pepper to taste and transfer to a bowl.
Add, with the onions cut-side down, and cook for 4 minutes, turning the non-onion veggies from time to time.
Add, scrape browned bits from the bottom of the pan, and cook for 3 minutes or until reduced by a quarter. Add the reserved broth mixture and set aside.
Cut the beef into 1 1/2" pieces and toss to combine with the flour.

Add to the dutch oven along with the beef and any beef juice that has accumulated. Partially cover and move to the oven for 90 minutes. The liquid should lightly simmer the whole time and the beef should be cooked and tender at the end of the 90 minutes. Use tongs to remove the spent carrot, onion, celery, onion, thyme, and bay once the beef is tender.

Add along with the reserved mushroom mixture. Cook for 45 -60 minutes or until the potatoes are tender. Remove the stew from the oven and cook on the stovetop to reduce and thicken the liquid, if desired.
Stir in, adjust salt and pepper to taste, and serve; alternatively, refrigerate for up to 5 days and then reheat and serve.
Rinse in a fine mesh strainer under running water until the water runs clear.
Combine in a big bowl, stir to dissolve the salt, and let sit for 15 minutes. Drain the rice.

Bring to a boil in a dutch oven on high heat. Add the rice and cook for 3-5 minutes or until the rice is al dente - mostly cooked but with a little crunch in the center. Drain the rice and rinse it under cold water for 30 seconds to stop the cooking. Wipe out the dutch oven.
Brush the bottom and a couple inches up the sides of the pot with the oil.
Whisk together in a large bowl. Add 2 cups of the cooked rice and stir to combine. Spread the mixture over the bottom of the oiled pot and press it down.
Stir into the remaining rice and mound it on top of the yogurt-prepared rice in the dutch oven.
Make 8 depressions in the rice mound and place a bit of butter in each one.

Drizzle evenly over the rice. Wrap the lid of the dutch oven in a towel and place it tightly on the pan, pressing lightly to seal the edges. Cook on medium-high heat until steam is escaping from the sides of the pot and the rice is sizzling. Take care that the towel does not catch fire.

Reduce the heat to medium-low and cook for an additional 35 minutes or until the rice is tender. Remove the pot from heat and place it on a damp towel set on a baking sheet (this will help loosen the rice from the bottom of the pan).

Stir into the rice mound, taking care not to disturb the crusty bottom. Season with salt as needed; then, spoon the loose rice onto plates. Gently break the crusty bottom part of the rice into slabs and add them to the rice plates. Serve.
Add the campari to the glass and top with the beer. Top up the glass as you drink.
Combine in a small saucepan on medium high heat and cook while stirring until the liquid boils. Reduce the heat to low and simmer for 10 minutes or until the rhubarb is nothing but strands.

Place the cheesecloth in a strainer set in a funnel over a medium-sized bottle. Pour the shrub over the strainer so the it drains into the bottle, and let it sit for about 30 minutes or until it stops dripping. Do not squeeze the rhubarb or the shrub will become bitter. Discard the solids, cool to room temperature, and refrigerate for up to 3 months.
Combine in the bowl of a food processor and pulse briefly to incorporate.

Add and pulse until dough gets clumpy and you cannot see any dry flour, about 30 quick pulses. Use a rubber spatula to redistribute the dough so that it is evenly spread across the bottom of the processor.
Sprinkle evenly over the dough and pulse 5 more times to combine and break up the dough. Transfer the dough to a large bowl.

Sprinkle over the dough and work it together with a rubber spatula. Once the dough is incorporated end uniform, divide the ball in half and shape each half into a 4-inch disk. Wrap the disks in plastic wrap and move it to the refrigerator for at least 2 hours so that the flour can absorb the water. Roll and bake according to your pie recipe.
Heat oven to 425 F with a rack in the lower position.
Whisk together in a large bowl.
Add to the sugar and toss to combine. Let sit for 5 minutes.

Divide the dough in half and roll each out into a disc large enough to cover the pie pan. Carefully transfer half the dough to the pie pan and ensure that it is pressed into the shape of the pan with no air space. Trim the edges. Add the rhubarb mixture and cover with the other dough half. Crimp to seal and cut a few slits in the top of the pie. Refrigerate for 20 minutes.
Beat together in a small bowl and brush onto the pie crust.
Sprinkle evenly over the top of the pie. Place in the oven for 20 minutes, and rotate the pie 180 degrees after 10 minutes to compensate for the fact that most ovens heat unevenly.
Turn the oven down to 350 F and cook for 20-30 more minutes, or until the filling is bubbling and the crust is completely golden brown. Remove, cool, and serve.
Place in a medium baking dish and toast in a 300-degree oven for about an hour or until the sugar just begins to turn ivory. Trust me, this step is worth the extra time.
Whisk together with the sugar in a 3-quart saucier until no lumps of cornstarch remain.

Whisk into the sugar mixture and place on medium heat. Gently and continuously whisk for 6 minutes or until the mixture begins to simmer; then, continue whisking for another minute to ensure all the cornstarch is fully hydrated. Transfer the mixture to a large bowl.

Whisk into the hot mixture, cover, and refrigerate until the mixture descends to 40 degrees fahrenheit - about 3 hours. Churn in your ice cream maker according to its instructions, transfer to a chilled container, and press a piece of plastic wrap directly onto the surface of the gelato to protect it from crystallization and off-flavors in your freezer. Move to your freezer for storage, and soften in the refrigerator briefly before serving to match the traditional style of gelato.
Combine in the bowl of a food processor. Grind to a fine powder, about 1 minute.

Add and lightly stir to remove any air pockets. Process for about 2 minutes or until the mixture resembles greek yogurt. It is easy to overwhip and turn the mixture into butter, so be careful to stop processing when the consistency is right.
Preheat oven to 350 F with a rack in the lower position.
