Add anise%2C peppercorns%2C and cloves to now empty skillet. Toast until fragrant%2C about 1 minute%3B transfer to spice grinder with seeds.
Add thyme%2C marjoram%2C bay leaf%2C and cinnamon to spice grinder. Grind all seeds and spices into a fine powder. Transfer to a large bowl%3B set aside.

To serve%2C place two tortillas on a serving plate. Top with two fried eggs. Spoon salsa all over the top%2C leaving the yolks exposed. Sprinkle with cotija cheese and more chopped cilantro. Serve immediately with refried beans.
Combine rice and almonds in blender. Blend on high speed%2C stopping to shake jar as necessary until roughly powdered%2C about 30 seconds.

Add remaining ingredients to blender and blend on high speed for a further 1 minute. Refrigerate and let steep overnight. The next day%2C strain through a fine mesh strainer. Add more sugar%2C cinnamon%2C and vanilla to taste. Serve chilled over ice.

Stem chiles and shake seeds into a small bowl. Tear chiles into large pieces%3B set aside. Place 4 tablespoons of reserved chile seeds and sesame seeds in a small cast iron skillet set over medium heat. Toast seeds%2C stirring occasionally%2C until lightly brown%2C about 2 minutes. Transfer seeds to a spice grinder.
Cut a small%2C shallow X in the bottom of each peach. Dip each into a pot of boiling water for 30 seconds%2C and then into a bowl of cold water for a minute. The peels should slide right off.

Halve peaches and remove pits%2C then cut each half into quarters %28i.e. 8 chunks from each peach%29. Place peach chunks and water in a large pot and bring to a boil. Simmer until peaches are tender%2C about 15 to 20 minutes%2C stirring occasionally to ensure they cook evenly. Puree in a blender or with an immersion blender.

%3Cstrong%3EBrown the Butter:%3C/strong%3E In 3-quart stainless steel saucier, melt butter over medium-low heat until fluid. Increase to medium and simmer, stirring with a heat-resistant spatula while butter hisses and pops; adjust heat as needed, so that dairy solids will not scorch before all the water can boil away. Continue cooking and stirring, scraping up any brown bits that form along the pan, until butter is golden yellow and perfectly silent (an indication the water has entirely boiled away). The entire process should take about 15 minutes; substantially shorter or longer times may indicate improper heat settings.

Return the peaches to the large pot, add the sugar and lemon juice and bring the mixture to a good strong simmer/gentle boil, cooking them at this level for 30 to 40 minutes, stirring occasionally in the beginning and more often near the end, as it thickens up and the fruit masses risk scorching on the bottom of the pot.
Drizzle a ribbon of sauce across the surface%3B when that ribbon holds its shape before dissolve into the pot%2C it is done.

%3Cstrong%3EToast the Sugar:%3C/strong%3E Adjust oven rack to middle position, preheat to 350%C2%B0F (180%C2%B0C), and place the sugar in a 10-inch stainless steel skillet. Toast in the oven until fragrant and pale gold, like white sand, stirring thoroughly every 20 minutes or so to circulate sugar away from the edges of the pan. The whole process will take about 1 hour, but it can vary significantly depending on oven temperature accuracy, skillet size and shape, and frequency of stirring. Pour warm sugar into a 2-quart glass baking dish (or similar) to speed cooling and let it cool to approximately 70%C2%B0F (21%C2%B0C) before use. The cooled sugar can be used right away, or it can be stored in an airtight container indefinitely.

Let peach butter cool (unless you’re canning it, in which, follow the directions below). If you’re not canning it, keep it in an airtight container in the fridge. It should be good for at least two weeks.

%3Cu%3ETo can your peach butter:%3C/u%3E First, sterilize your jars, either by boiling them in a large, deep pot of water (which should cover the jars completely) for 10 minutes or washing them in lots of hot soapy water, rinsing and drying the parts well and then place the jars only in a 200 degree oven for 20 minutes. Then, divide your hot piping hot peach butter between your jars, leaving a little room at the top. Wipe the rims clean with a dry towel and cover the jars with their lids. Submerge the jars in a large, deep pot of boiling water for 10 minutes, either in a removable basket or using tongs to dip and remove them. Let cool completely on towels, a process that can take overnight. If canned properly, the peach butter should last indefinitely at room temperature.

Pour the butter into the bowl of a stand mixer%2C along with all the toasty brown bits%2C and cool until thick%2C creamy%2C and opaque%2C or approximately 70%C2%B0F %2821%C2%B0C%29. This can be done passively over the course of several hours%2C or in about 20 minutes with a cold-water bath using a few ice cubes. Alternatively%2C the brown butter can be refrigerated up to a week in an airtight container and then warmed to about 70%C2%B0F %2821%C2%B0C%29 before use.

Adjust oven rack to lower-middle position and preheat to 350%C2%B0F %28180%C2%B0C%29. Lightly grease three 8-inch anodized aluminum cake pans and line with parchment. If you don%27t have three pans%2C it%27s okay to bake the cakes in stages%3B the batter can be held at room temperature during this time.
Whisk together in a small bowl. Set aside.

Combine in a medium saucepan and bring to a boil over medium heat. Stir in cornstarch slurry and cook until thickened%2C about 1 to 2 minutes. Remove from heat and use immediately or store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the Cake:%3C/strong%3E In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, combined the cooled brown butter, the cooled toasted sugar, baking powder, vanilla, water, salt, and baking soda. Mix on low speed to roughly incorporate; then increase to medium and beat until soft, fluffy, and pale, about 8 minutes. About halfway through, pause to scrape the bowl and beater with a flexible spatula.

With the mixer still running, add eggs one at a time, letting each fully incorporate before adding the next. Reduce speed to low and sprinkle in about 1/3 of the cake flour, then drizzle in 1/3 of the milk. Repeat with remaining flour and milk, working in thirds as before.

When the batter looks smooth, scrape the bowl and beater with a flexible spatula; then fold the batter once or twice from the bottom up to be sure everything is well-combined. The batter should look creamy and thick but not stiff.

Divide evenly between prepared cake pans. Stagger pans together on one oven rack and bake until puffed%2C firm%2C and pale gold%2C about 35 minutes. If oven has uneven heat%2C pause to rotate the pans after about 16 minutes. Alternatively%2C bake two layers at once and finish the third later.

Cool cakes directly in their pans until no trace of warmth remains and then run a butter knife around the edges to loosen. Invert onto a wire rack%2C peel off the parchment%2C and return cakes right side up %28covered in plastic%2C the cakes can be left at room temperature for a few hours%29. Frost and serve.

Heat 1/2 tablespoon %287ml%29 vegetable oil in a wok over high heat until smoking. Add half of rice and cook%2C stirring and tossing%2C until the rice is pale brown and toasted and has a lightly chewy texture%2C about 3 minutes. Transfer to a medium bowl. Repeat with another 1/2 tablespoon oil and remaining rice.

To make dough: Place flour and salt in a large mixing bowl and make a well in the center. Add water, egg and vegetable oil and mix, slowly incorporating flour until soft dough forms. Turn soft dough out onto floured surface and knead until smooth and elastic, about 8 minutes. Cover with a clean kitchen towel and let rest for 1 hour.

Return all the rice to the wok and press it up the sides, leaving a space in the middle. Add 1/2 tablespoon (7ml) oil to the space. Add onion, carrot, scallions, and garlic and cook, stirring gently, until lightly softened and fragrant, about 1 minute. Toss with rice to combine. Add soy sauce and sesame oil and toss to coat. Season to taste with salt and white pepper.

Push rice to the side of the wok and add remaining 1/2 tablespoon (7ml) oil. Break the egg into the oil and season with a little salt. Use a spatula to scramble the egg, breaking it up into small bits. Toss the egg and the rice together.
Add frozen peas and continue to toss and stir until peas are thawed and every grain of rice is separate. Serve immediately.

Boil a large stock pot of water, and working in batches, cook pierogies until they rise to the top of the boiling water. Serve with any or all of: sour cream, bacon, sliced onion, and scallion, along with cold beer.

Assemble pierogies: Divide dough in half, reserving other half under a kitchen towel. Divide halved dough into 24 evenly sized pieces. Roll each piece into a round about 1/8-inch thick. Wet edges of dough and place a rounded teaspoon worth of filling in center of round. Close dough around filling creating a semicircle sealing edges with fingers. Repeat with all remaining dough (there may be some filling left).

To make filling: Peel potatoes and cut into 1 inch pieces. Boil in salted water until potatoes are tender, about 10 minutes. Drain potatoes and place in a large bowl and mash with a potato masher or fork, slowly adding grated cheese. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
Light 1 chimney full of charcoal. When all charcoal is lit and covered with gray ash%2C pour out and spread coals evenly over half of coal grate.
In a large saucepan, melt butter over medium-high heat. Add onion and garlic and cook, stirring often, until softened and translucent, about 5 minutes; lower heat as necessary to prevent browning.

Preheat a gas or charcoal grill to medium heat and place eggplants directly over heat source. Cook%2C turning occasionally with tongs%2C until eggplants are completely tender and well charred on all sides%2C 30 to 40 minutes. Wrap with foil and let rest 15 minutes.
While coals heat%2C combine mayonnaise%2C sour cream%2C cheese%2C chili powder%2C garlic%2C and cilantro in a large bowl. Stir until homogeneous and set aside.
When grill is hot, place corn directly over hot side of grill and cook, rotating occasionally, until cooked through and charred in spots on all sides, about 8 minutes total.
Transfer corn to bowl with cheese mixture and use a large spoon to evenly coat corn on all sides with mixture. Sprinkle with extra cheese and chili powder and serve immediately with lime wedges.

Add cauliflower%2C stock%2C and thyme. Cover%2C bring to a simmer%2C and cook%2C adjusting heat to maintain simmer%2C until cauliflower is tender%2C 5 to 6 minutes. Uncover and continue to simmer%2C stirring occasionally%2C until liquid is reduced by about three-quarters%2C about 20 minutes. Discard thyme sprig.

Using a blender or immersion blender%2C blend cauliflower and liquid to form a very smooth puree. Season with salt. %28You can adjust puree consistency as needed%3A Thicken by cooking down further while stirring often over low heat in a wide nonstick skillet%2C or thin by whisking in liquid%2C such as stock%2C cream%2C or water.%29 Serve warm.

Open foil package. Working with one eggplant at a time%2C use a sharp paring knife to slit each eggplant open lengthwise. Carefully scoop out soft flesh with a large spoon and transfer to a strainer set in a large bowl. Once all eggplant is scooped%2C pick out any stray bits of skin and blackened flesh and discard.

Transfer eggplant to a salad spinner, distributing it evenly around the perimeter. Spin gently until all excess moisture is extracted. Discard all drippings, wipe out large bowl, and return eggplant to bowl.

Add garlic and lemon juice to eggplant and stir vigorously with a fork until eggplant breaks down into a rough paste, about 1 1/2 minutes. Stirring constantly and vigorously, add tahini, followed by the olive oil in a thin, steady stream. The mixture should become pale and creamy. Stir in parsley and season to taste with salt, plus more lemon juice if desired.

Transfer to a serving bowl%2C drizzle with more olive oil%2C and serve with warm pita bread or vegetables for dipping. Baba ganoush can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 4 days. Let baba ganoush warm to room temperature before serving.
In a large bowl, beat eggs vigorously with a large pinch of salt until frothy. Set aside.

Meanwhile, in a 10-inch nonstick or well-seasoned carbon steel skillet, heat oil over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add potatoes and onions; they should gently (but not vigorously) bubble in the oil. Regulating heat to maintain a gentle bubbling, cook, stirring occasionally, until potatoes and onions are meltingly tender, about 25 minutes. Set a fine-mesh strainer over a heatproof bowl and drain potatoes and onions of excess oil. Reserve oil.

Transfer potatoes and onions to a medium heatproof bowl and season generously with salt, stirring well to combine. Beat eggs vigorously to re-froth, then scrape potato and onion in and stir until thoroughly combined. Set aside for 5 minutes.

Meanwhile, wipe out skillet. Add 3 tablespoons (45ml) reserved frying oil to skillet and set over medium-high heat until shimmering. Scrape egg mixture into skillet and cook, swirling and shaking pan rapidly, until bottom and sides begin to set, about 3 minutes. Using a heatproof spatula, press the edges in to begin to form the tortilla%27s puck shape. Continue to cook, adjusting heat to prevent bottom of tortilla from burning, until beginning to set around edges, about 3 minutes longer.

Working over a sink or garbage can, place a large overturned flat plate or lid on top of skillet, set hand on top (using a dish towel if you are sensitive to heat), and, in one very quick motion, invert tortilla onto it. Add 1 more tablespoon (15ml) reserved oil to skillet and return to heat. Carefully slide tortilla back into skillet and continue to cook until second side is beginning to firm up, about 2 minutes. Use rubber spatula to again press the sides in all around to form a rounded puck shape. Continue to cook tortilla until lightly browned on second side but still tender in the center when pressed with a finger, about 2 minutes longer. If desired, you can flip tortilla 2 to 3 more times during these last minutes of cooking, which helps to cook the center more evenly and reinforce the shape.
Carefully slide tortilla out of skillet onto a clean plate %28or invert it onto a clean plate using same method as before%29 and let stand at least 5 minutes before serving with aioli.

Adjust oven rack to center position and preheat oven to 350%C2%B0F. Spread black beans in a single layer on a foil-lined rimmed baking sheet. Place in oven and roast until beans are mostly split open and outer skins are beginning to get crunchy, about 20 minutes. Remove from oven and allow to cool slightly.

While beans roast%2C heat 2 tablespoons oil in a medium skillet over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add onion and poblano and cook%2C stirring frequently%2C until softened%2C about 5 minutes. Add garlic and cook%2C stirring constantly%2C until fragrant%2C about 2 minutes. Add chipotle chili and its adobo sauce and cook%2C stirring%2C until fragrant%2C about 30 seconds. Transfer mixture to a large bowl.
Place cashews in the bowl of a food processor and pulse until chopped into pieces no larger than 1/3-inch, about 12 short pulses. Add to bowl with onions and peppers.

When beans are slightly cooled, transfer to food processor. Add cheese. Pulse until beans are roughly chopped (the largest pieces should be about 1/3 of a full bean in size). Transfer to bowl with onion/pepper mixture. Add mayonnaise, egg, and bread crumbs and season with salt and pepper. Fold together gently but thoroughly with hands. Patty mixture can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to three days at this stage.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the Spinach:%3C/strong%3E Heat olive oil and butter in a large saucepan over medium heat until melted. Add shallots and garlic, season with salt and pepper, and cook, stirring frequently, until softened and fragrant, about 1 minute. Add a few large handfuls of spinach and cook, stirring, until wilted. Continue adding spinach a handful at a time until it is all in the pot. Cook, stirring frequently, until spinach expels its moisture and most of that moisture evaporates, leaving a dry bottom as you stir. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
Transfer spinach to a fine mesh strainer set over the sink and press out excess moisture with a rubber spatula. Let spinach continue to drain as you prepare the ricotta mixture.
%3Cstrong%3EFor the Ricotta%3A%3C/strong%3E Combine ingredients in the bowl of a food processor. Season with salt and pepper. Process until completely smooth%2C about 1 minute.
Combine all ingredients in a mixing bowl and whip with a hand mixer until fluffy and firm. Overwhipped cream will gradually form butter%2C so don%27t overwhip. This can also be done in a stand mixer.

Transfer mixture to a large bowl but do not wipe out food processor. Transfer spinach to food processor and pulse until finely chopped, 10 to 12 short pulses. Add spinach and remaining ricotta to the ricotta mixture and fold gently to combine.

Form bean mixture into 6 patties as wide as your burger buns. Heat 1 tablespoon oil in a large non-stick or cast iron skillet over medium heat until shimmering. Add 4 patties and cook%2C swirling pan occasionally%2C until well browned and crisp on first side%2C about 5 minutes. Carefully flip and cook until second side is browned%2C about 5 minutes longer%2C adding cheese if desired. If cooking more than 4 burgers%2C cook in batches%2C keeping cooked burgers on a rack set in a rimmed baking sheet in a 200%C2%B0F oven while second batch cooks.
Spread top and bottom buns with chipotle mayonnaise or other condiments as desired. Add toppings to top or bottom bun as desired. Place patties on bottom buns, close burgers, and serve immediately.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the White Sauce%3A%3C/strong%3E Heat butter in a medium saucepan over medium heat until melted. Add flour and increase heat to medium high. Cook%2C stirring butter and flour with a whisk until pale and golden blond%2C about 1 minute. Whisking constantly%2C slowly drizzle in milk. Continue to cook%2C whisking frequently%2C until mixture comes to a boil and thickens. Remove from heat and add mozzarella and gruyere. Whisk until smooth. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

%3Cstrong%3ETo Assemble:%3C/strong%3E Adjust oven rack to lower middle position and preheat oven to 400%C2%B0F. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add pasta sheets a few at a time and cook until barely tender, about 45 seconds. Transfer to a fine mesh strainer and run under cool water until well chilled. Transfer to a clean kitchen towel in a single layer. Continue until all pasta is par-cooked and dried.

Drizzle a small amount of white sauce over the bottom of a lasagna pan or large casserole. Add a layer of noodles. Top with 1/12th of spinach mixture and 1/12th of remaining white sauce. Continue layering pasta, spinach, and white sauce until you lay down the top sheet of pasta.
Spread remaining spinach mixture evenly over the top. Sprinkle with remaining mozzarella and gruyere and drizzle with remaining white sauce. Spread into an even layer with a rubber spatula.

Cover tightly with aluminum foil. Bake for 20 minutes. Remove foil and continue baking until bubble and lightly browned, about 20 minutes longer. Let rest at room temperature for 5 to 10 minutes, then slice and serve.

Preheat broiler. Place tomatoes%2C cut side up%2C on a rimmed baking sheet and sprinkle evenly with 1 teaspoon salt. Add jalapeno%2C garlic%2C and onion to baking sheet. Place baking sheet in broiler and cook until tomatoes%2C jalapeno%2C garlic%2C and onion have slightly blackened%2C about 20 minutes%2C flipping jalapeno and garlic half way through. Remove from broiler and let sit until cool enough to handle%2C about 10 minutes.
Stem and seed  jalapeno and peel garlic. Transfer tomatoes%2C jalapeno%2C garlic%2C and onion to the work bowl of a food processor fitted with a steel blade. Pulse until mixture is finely chopped.

Transfer to a medium bowl. Stir in cilantro and lime juice. Season with salt and sugar to taste. Let rest in refrigerator for at least 30 minutes before serving. Store in an airtight container up to a week.

Working one at a time%2C fry corn tortillas until lightly browned but still pliable%2C about 15 seconds per side. Transfer to a paper towel to drain and stack them as you work. Cover with foil or a clean kitchen towel to keep warm.

When tortillas are cooked%2C reheat skillet over medium-high heat until oil is shimmering %28add more oil if necessary%29. Fry eggs%2C using a spoon to baste the tops with hot oil as they cook in order to help set the upper whites while keeping the yolk completely liquid. Fry until crisp on the bottom%2C whites are set%2C and yolks are golden%2C 1-2 minutes. Season with salt and pepper and slide onto a clean plate.

Place potatoes in a medium saucepan and cover with 2 quarts water. Add vinegar and 2 tablespoons salt and bring to a boil over high heat. Cook until potatoes are tender, about 7 minutes. Drain and set aside.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the aioli%3A%3C/strong%3E combine egg yolks%2C mustard%2C lemon juice%2C garlic%2C and 2 teaspoons water in bowl of food processor. Run processor until homogenous%2C about 5 seconds. Scrape down sides of bowl. With processor running%2C slowly add canola oil in thin%2C steady stream%2C stopping to scrape down sides as necessary. Sauce should thicken and come together. Transfer sauce to a large bowl set in a heavy pot lined with a towel. Whisking constantly%2C slowly drizzle in olive oil. Season to taste with salt%2C lemon juice%2C and black pepper. Set aside.

Heat oil in a 12-inch non-stick or cast iron straight-sided saute pan over medium-high heat to 350 F. Add potatoes in single layer and cook%2C shaking the pan and flipping the potatoes with a spatula or tongs occasionally until golden brown and crisp%2C about 5 minutes. Remove from heat. Using slotted spoon or wire-mesh spider%2C transfer potatoes to bowl lined with paper towels. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

Pile potatoes in a large bowl%2C drizzle with aioli%2C sprinkle with paprika and scallions%2C and serve%2C passing extra aioli tableside. Extra aioli will keep in the refrigerator for at least 1 week.
Add oregano and chili strips and cook until fragrant%2C about 15 seconds.
Add tomatoes and chipotle chilies with their sauce and bring to a simmer. Reduce heat to maintain a gentle simmer for 10 minutes.
Puree mixture with a hand blender or in a standing blender until a loose puree is formed. Stir in cilantro%2C soy sauce%2C and lime juice and season to taste with salt and pepper. Set aside.
Heat remaining 3 tablespoons oil in a medium cast iron or non-stick skillet over medium heat until shimmering.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the Filling:%3C/strong%3E Heat oil in a 12-inch skillet over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add onions and cook until softened and beginning to brown around the edges, 5-7 minutes. Add jalape%C3%B1os and garlic and cook until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add chili powder, oregano, cumin, coriander, and chipotle powder and cook until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add ground chuck and cook, breaking apart with a wooden spoon or potato masher, until browned throughout, about 5 minutes.
Stir in chicken stock and diced tomatoes and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer and cook until liquid thickens%2C about 15 minutes. Stir in cilantro and lime juice and season with salt to taste.
Spoon meat mixture into taco shells and garnish with preferred fixings. Serve immediately.
Combine in a medium bowl and toss to coat. Let rest for 30 minutes.

Remove and discard jalape%C3%B1o slices. Set aside 1 cup of macerated strawberries for garnish. Transfer remaining strawberries and any exuded juices and syrup into a blender. Add lemon juice. Blend on high speed until smooth, about 1 minute. Strain through a fine mesh strainer into a pitcher. Discard solids. Add reserved strawberries and cold water and whisk to combine. Add ice. Serve in ice-filled glasses garnished with a strawberry and a jalape%C3%B1o slice.
In a medium bowl, beat eggs with a disposable plastic or reusable wooden fork just until last traces of white are mixed in; season with salt and pepper.

In a perfectly unscratched 8-inch nonstick skillet, melt butter, swirling over moderate heat, until fully melted and foamy but not browned. Add eggs and stir rapidly with fork, tines up, while shaking pan to agitate eggs; make sure to move fork all around pan to break up curds and scrape them from bottom of skillet as they form. Stop stirring as soon as eggs are very softly scrambled and creamy (but still loose enough to come together into a single mass), 1 to 2 minutes.

Using fork, gently spread egg in an even layer around skillet and scrape down any wispy bits around the edges. The top surface should be loose and creamy, but if it looks too liquid and raw, cook undisturbed for another few seconds. (If it still flows, you can swirl skillet to send loose egg to the edges, where it will set more quickly.)

Remove from heat, tilt skillet up by its handle, and, using fork, gently roll omelette down over itself until it is nearly folded in half. Using fork, push omelette to edge of skillet so that lower edge of egg begins to just barely overhang; use fork to fold overhanging edge of egg up, closing omelette.

Hold skillet right over plate and turn omelette out onto it. It should be almond- or cigar-shaped%2C with the seam on bottom%3B if it%27s not%2C lay a clean kitchen towel over it and use your hands to adjust its shape and position%2C then remove towel. Serve. %28To make another omelette%2C wipe any eggy bits out of skillet and repeat.%29

Combine potatoes%2C carrots%2C half of peas%2C favas%2C corn%2C and vegetable stock %28or water with stock base%29 in a pressure cooker. Bring to high pressure and cook for 15 minutes. Release pressure by running a stovetop pressure cooker under cold tap water or by using the quick steam release on an electric pressure cooker.

Bring soup to a simmer. Using a potato masher or a stick whisk%2C mash vegetables until broth is thickened but some large pieces still remain. Add remaining fresh peas and fava beans and simmer until cooked through%2C about 5 minutes. Season to taste with salt and pepper and serve%2C making sure to include one piece of corn in each bowl %28along with a fork to pick it up%29%2C and sprinkle each serving with cilantro.

In a blender, combine almonds with water and garlic and blend at high speed until milky; you may need to stop and scrape down sides of blender jar once or twice. Add bread and blend until very smooth. Season with salt, then blend in vinegar and olive oil. If using a less powerful blender, you may want to pass the soup through a fine-mesh strainer at this point; with a high-powered blender, that won%27t be necessary.
Transfer soup to a sealed container and refrigerate until very well chilled, at least 2 hours and up to 2 days.

%3Cstrong%3ETo Serve:%3C/strong%3E Cut up grapes into smaller pieces and toss with almonds, mint, and just enough olive oil to coat. Season garnish with salt. Shake or stir soup well. Check consistency and thin with cold water, if desired. Adjust seasoning, adding more salt and/or vinegar, if desired. Pour into chilled serving bowls. Spoon grape garnish on top, lightly drizzling more olive oil onto each serving in a decorative manner. Serve.

Heat olive oil in a large saucepan or saucier over medium heat until shimmering. Add leek and celery. Season with salt and cook, stirring, until vegetables are softened but not browned, about 5 minutes. If pan starts to look dry at any point, add a small splash of olive oil. Add garlic and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add zucchini and cook, stirring, for 1 minute. Add half of basil, stir to combine, and add water.

Bring to a simmer and cook, stirring occasionally, until zucchini is tender but still bright green, about 10 minutes. Add remaining half of basil and blend soup using a handheld immersion blender or a countertop blender until it is as rough or as smooth as you like it. Season to taste with salt, black pepper, and lemon juice and serve, drizzling with additional olive oil at the table.
Combine in a medium bowl and stir with a fork until homogenous. Season to taste with salt and pepper and set aside.

Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a large pot over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add the butternut squash, season with salt and pepper, and cook, stirring occasionally, until lightly browned, about 4 minutes. Remove and set aside. Add the remaining oil and heat until shimmering. Add the onion, carrot, pepper, and a pinch of salt  and cook, stirring, until softened, about 2 minutes. Add the curry powder and chili flakes and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add the quinoa and toast until fragrant, about 1 minute.

Heat remaining olive oil in a large Dutch oven over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add leek, onion, carrot, and celery and cook, stirring frequently, until softened but not browned, about 5 minutes. Add half of parsley-lemon mixture and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add lentils and stir until coated in oil. Add bay leaves and stock. Bring to a boil, reduce to a bare simmer, cover with lid slightly cracked, and cook until lentils are completely tender and falling apart, about 1 hour, adding water as necessary (lentils should be fully covered at all times).

Using a hand blender, blend soup until as smooth as desired. Alternatively, transfer half of soup to a standing blender, blend until smooth, and fold back into remaining soup. Whisk in lemon juice and season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve, drizzling extra lemon-parsley mixture on top of each serving. Soup can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.

Add the broth and adjust heat to maintain an active boil and cook until the quinoa is done%2C about 9 minutes. Stir in the kale and squash%2C until the kale has wilted and the squash tender but not mushy%2C about 2 minutes more. Stir in lemon juice%2C season with salt and pepper%2C divide between serving bowls%2C and top with the cilantro. Serve with toasted pita.
Combine in a large bowl and set aside.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the soup%3A %3C/strong%3EHeat olive oil in a large saucepan over medium-low heat until shimmering. Add leeks%2C onions%2C and garlic and cook%2C stirring frequently%2C until softened but not browned%2C about 8 minutes. Add mushrooms and cook%2C stirring frequently%2C until excess liquid evaporates and mushrooms start to sizzle%2C about 10 minutes.

Add flour and stir to incorporate. Cook for 30 seconds. Add sherry or white wine and cook%2C stirring constantly and scraping bottom of pan%2C until thick and syrupy%2C about 1 minute. Add soy sauce and miso and stir to incorporate. Add broth and soaked mushrooms. Add bay leaves and thyme sprigs. Bring soup to a simmer and adjust heat to maintain a bare bubble. Let simmer for 30 minutes.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the shiitake chips%3A %3C/strong%3ECombine remaining sliced shiitake mushrooms with the vegetable oil in a medium non-stick skillet. Heat over medium-low heat and cook%2C flipping mushrooms and stirring frequently%2C until dehydrated and well-browned. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate with a slotted spatula and season immediately with salt. Let cool.

Add torn bread slices to soup and soak for 30 seconds. Discard bay leaves and thyme and transfer soup to a blender. Close blender and blend%2C starting on low speed and slowly getting faster. Once blender is at full speed%2C slowly drizzle in olive oil. Continue blending until completely smooth. Rinse out pot and pour soup back into it through a chinois or fine mesh strainer. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
Serve soup topped with crispy shiitake mushrooms%2C scallions%2C and a drizzle of extra-virgin olive oil.

Combine in the bowl of a mortar and pestle%2C including only the stems of the cilantro and reserving the leaves. Sprinkle with about 1 teaspoon of salt. Pound into a rough paste and set aside. Thinly slice remaining half of jalapeno and set aside for garnish.

Whisk sugar%2C cornstarch%2C and salt together in a 3-quart saucier. When no lumps of cornstarch remain%2C add milk and whisk to combine. Cook over medium heat%2C whisking constantly but not vigorously%2C until it begins to simmer. This will take about 6 minutes%2C if the process seems to be moving slowly%2C simply turn up the heat. When the mixture comes to a boil%2C set a timer and continue cooking and whisking for exactly 1 minute. This ensures the cornstarch is fully hydrated.

Open 1 can of coconut milk and carefully spoon off 3 tablespoons of the solid fat from the surface and place it in a large Dutch oven with 1 tablespoon of vegetable oil. Heat over medium-high heat%2C stirring frequently%2C until coconut fat separates and solids start to sizzle%2C about 4 minutes. Continue cooking%2C stirring constantly%2C until solids turn pale golden brown%2C about 1 minute longer. Add the pounded garlic/ginger mixture and cook%2C stirring%2C until aromatic%2C about 30 seconds. Add sliced scallions and turmeric and cook%2C stirring%2C until lightly softened%2C about 1 minute.

Add the remaining contents of both cans of coconut milk along with stock. Add sweet potatoes. Bring to a boil%2C and reduce to a bare simmer. Cook until sweet potatoes are totally softened%2C about 15 minutes.

Combine in a medium skillet set over medium heat. Cook%2C tossing and stirring frequently%2C until peanuts are a deep golden brown%2C about 8 minutes. Immediately transfer to a bowl to prevent scorching.

Transfer 1/2 cup of peanuts to a cutting board and roughly chop. Reserve for garnish. Transfer half of the remaining peanuts to the now-empty mortar and pestle. Sprinkle with 1 teaspoon sugar and a pinch of salt. Pound to form a rough paste%2C then transfer to pot of soup. Repeat with the other half of the remaining peanuts.

When potatoes are fully softened%2C blend soup until mostly smooth but a little texture remains using a hand blender directly in the pot or by transferring to a countertop blender in batches. Bring to a simmer%2C stir in kale%2C and cook until kale is completely wilted and tender%2C about 5 minutes. Stir in lime juice. Season soup to taste with salt%2C pepper%2C and hot sauce. Stir in cilantro%2C reserving some for garnish. Serve soup with rice%2C sprinkled with cilantro%2C chopped peanuts%2C scallions%2C and sliced chilies.

Transfer mixture to a large bowl%2C then whisk in the remaining milk and cream. Bearing in mind that the gelato will taste substantially less sweet once frozen%2C season with an additional pinch of salt%2C if desired. Cover and refrigerate the gelato base until cold%2C thick%2C and no warmer than 40%C2%B0F%2C about 3 hours.

In a microwave-safe bowl%2C melt the chocolate with a few 15-second bursts at normal power%2C pausing to stir well between each addition. Add the coconut oil%2C and continue stirring until fully melted. For fine chips that partially homogenize into the gelato%2C cool to about 90%C2%B0F before use.

If using fava beans and peas in their pods%2C shuck beans and peas from pods%2C keeping beans and peas separate. Discard pods. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil and prepare an ice bath. Working with one vegetable at a time%2C blanch favas%2C peas%2C asparagus%2C snap peas%2C and broccoli in boiling water for 1 minute each%2C transfer to ice bath to cool%2C then transfer to a paper towel-lined tray and pat dry. Remove and discard skin from each individual fava bean. Set vegetables aside. Empty pot%2C refill it with fresh water%2C season generously with salt%2C and return to a boil.

Churn the gelato base in an ice cream maker according to the manufacturer%27s directions. Meanwhile%2C place a quart-sized container and flexible spatula in the freezer. When gelato looks fluffy and thick%2C add the cooled and melted chocolate%2C or the pre-made chocolate chips%2C and churn until well combined. Shut off the machine and%2C using the chilled spatula%2C scrape gelato into the chilled container. Cover with plastic wrap pressed directly against the surface of the gelato%2C and freeze until thick enough to scoop%2C about 4 hours. Bring partially to room temperature for a more authentic%2C soft texture.

Gelato is typically served at about 16%C2%B0F%2C but most American freezers run at 0%C2%B0F. For the most authentic presentation%2C soften gelato to 16%C2%B0F in the refrigerator before serving. In a squat container%2C like a yogurt tub or a square storage container%2C this will take about 45 minutes. The timing will vary substantially depending on the size%2C shape%2C and material of the container %28such as a metal loaf pan or glass baking dish%29%2C so check on the gelato frequently to ensure it does not melt.

Meanwhile%2C in a 3- to 4-quart saucier or a 12-inch skillet%2C heat butter%2C olive oil%2C garlic%2C and pine nuts over low heat until gently sizzling. Cook%2C swirling pan constantly%2C until pine nuts just start to brown and garlic aroma is very strong. Do not let butter brown%3B remove it from heat occasionally if it starts to sizzle too rapidly. Discard garlic cloves. Add blanched vegetables to pan and toss to combine. Remove from heat.

When water is boiling%2C add pasta and cook until just shy of al dente%2C about 1 minute total for most fresh pasta. Drain pasta%2C reserving 1 cup cooking liquid. Transfer pasta to pan with vegetables and add creme fraiche%2C lemon zest%2C lemon juice%2C basil%2C and parsley. Set over high heat and cook%2C stirring and tossing constantly and adjusting the consistency as necessary with a few splashes of the starchy pasta water%2C until liquid reduces to a creamy sauce. The sauce should coat the pasta and leave a creamy trail on the bottom of the pan when you drag a wooden spoon through it.

Off heat, stir in a generous shaving of fresh Parmigiano-Reggiano and season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve immediately, drizzling with olive oil and sprinkling with freshly ground black pepper and grated Parmigiano-Reggiano at the table.

Whisk together in a 3-quart stainless steel saucier. Cook over medium-low heat%2C whisking gently but constantly%2C until warm%2C about 3 minutes. Increase heat to medium and continue whisking until thick and steaming-hot%2C about 2 minutes longer. When the custard begins to bubble%2C set a timer and continue whisking for exactly 30 seconds to neutralize a starch-dissolving enzyme found in egg yolks.

Place tomatoes in a colander set over a bowl and season with 2 teaspoons kosher salt. Toss to coat. Set aside at room temperature to drain, tossing occasionally, while you toast the bread. Drain for a minimum of 15 minutes.

Combine in a 2-quart saucepan. Place over medium high heat%2C cover and allow to cook for 3 to 4 minutes. Uncover%2C clip a candy thermometer onto the side of the pan and continue to cook until the mixture reaches 240 degrees F%2C approximately 7 to 8 minutes. When the mixture reaches this temperature%2C immediately remove from the heat.

Strain through a nonreactive sieve into a nonreactive container%2C then whisk in cream%2C rum%2C and vanilla. Cover and refrigerate until no warmer than 40 F%2C then churn in an ice cream maker according to the manufacturer%27s directions. Meanwhile%2C place a 1-quart container and flexible spatula in the freezer.

When the ice cream looks thick and light, shut off the machine and, using the chilled spatula, scrape ice cream into the chilled container. Enjoy as soft-serve, or cover with plastic pressed directly against surface of ice cream, then close lid and freeze until firm enough to scoop, about 4 hours.
Combine the in the bowl of a stand mixer. Have the whisk attachment standing by.

Turn the mixer fitted with the whisk attachment to low speed and%2C while running%2C slowly pour the sugar syrup down the side of the bowl into the gelatin mixture. Once you have added all of the syrup%2C increase the speed to high. Continue to whip until the mixture becomes very thick and is lukewarm%2C approximately 12 to 15 minutes. Add the vanilla during the last minute of whipping.

Combine the confectioners%27 sugar and cornstarch in a small bowl. Lightly spray a 13 by 9-inch metal baking pan with nonstick cooking spray. Add the sugar and cornstarch mixture and move around to completely coat the bottom and sides of the pan. Return the remaining mixture to the bowl for later use.

When ready, pour the mixture into the prepared pan, using a lightly oiled spatula for spreading evenly into the pan. Dust the top with enough of the remaining sugar and cornstarch mixture to lightly cover. Reserve the rest for later. Allow the marshmallows to sit uncovered for at least 4 hours and up to overnight.

Turn the marshmallows out onto a cutting board and cut into 1-inch squares using a pizza wheel or knife dusted with the confectioners%27 sugar mixture. Once cut%2C lightly dust all sides of each marshmallow with the remaining mixture%2C using additional if necessary. Store in an airtight container for up to 3 weeks.

Meanwhile%2C preheat oven to 350 F and adjust rack to center position. In a large bowl%2C toss bread cubes with 2 tablespoons olive oil. Transfer to a rimmed baking sheet. Bake until crisp and firm but not browned%2C about 15 minutes. Remove from oven and let cool.

Remove colander with tomatoes from bowl with tomato juice. Place colander with tomatoes in the sink. Add shallot, garlic, mustard, and vinegar to the bowl with tomato juice. Whisking constantly, drizzle in the remaining 1/2 cup olive oil. Season dressing to taste with salt and pepper.

Combine toasted bread, tomatoes, and dressing in a large bowl. Add basil leaves. Toss everything to coat and season with salt and pepper. Let rest for 30 minutes before serving, tossing occasionally until dressing is completely absorbed by bread.
Combine the oil and basil in a bowl. Add the mozzarella and season to taste with salt and pepper. Cover and let marinate for at least 30 minutes in the refrigerator.
Add tomatoes and vinegar to the mozzarella and toss to combine. Season to taste with more salt and pepper if desired, and serve immediately

Place wakame and hijiki in separate small bowls. Cover with boiling water and let rest until rehydrated and tender, about 5 minutes. Drain and press with paper towels. Roughly chop wakame. Add wakame and hijiki to a large bowl.

Add tuna%2C onion%2C scallion%2C sesame seeds%2C soy sauce%2C sesame oil%2C honey%2C and crushed red pepper to bowl. Season with a small pinch of kosher salt and gently fold to combine. Taste and adjust with more soy sauce%2C sesame oil%2C honey%2C or crushed red pepper as desired. Let sit 5 minutes at room temperature%2C then serve on its own or on top of steamed rice.
Whisk together in small bowl.
Combine in a large bowl and toss to thoroughly mix. Let rest five minutes%2C then transfer to a large colander and rinse thoroughly under cold running water.

Combine cabbage%2C carrot%2C and onion in a large bowl. Sprinkle with sugar and salt and toss to combine. Let stand five minutes%2C then transfer to a large colander and rinse thoroughly under cold running water.

Transfer vegetables to a salad spinner and spin dry. Alternatively, transfer to a large rimmed baking sheet lined with a triple layer of paper towels or a clean kitchen towel and blot mixture dry with more towels. Return to large bowl.
Pour dressing over vegetables and toss to coat. Adjust seasoning to taste with salt, pepper, and/or sugar.

Combine shallot, garlic, mustard, vinegar, and water in a large bowl and whisk to combine. Whisking constantly, slowly drizzle in olive oil. Alternatively, place all ingredients in a tightly sealing jar, seal, and shake vigorously until emulsified. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Vinaigrette will keep in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

Transfer rinsed mixture to a salad spinner and spin dry. Alternatively, transfer to a large rimmed baking sheet lined with a triple layer of paper towels or a clean kitchen towel and blot mixture dry with more paper towels. Return to large bowl and set aside.
Combine in a medium bowl and whisk until homogenous.

Heat olive oil in a Dutch oven or large saucepan until shimmering. Add 2 cups of asparagus and chili flakes%2C and cook until lightly browned%2C about 4 minutes. Season with salt and pepper and set aside.
Pour dressing over cabbage mixture and toss to coat. Taste and adjust seasoning with more salt, pepper, sugar, and/or vinegar if desired.

In the same saucepan, add the farro and stock and bring to a simmer. Season with salt and cook until farro is tender, about 30 minutes; add water if necessary to keep farro covered. Drain farro and transfer to a large bowl. Stir in peas and kale and let stand until peas are tender and kale is wilted.

Meanwhile%2C in a medium bowl%2C whisk together the remaining olive oil along with the lemon juice and mustard. Season with salt and pepper. Fold vinaigrette into farro%2C add the cooked asparagus%2C almonds%2C scallions%2C feta%2C and remaining 1/4 cup raw asparagus. Let stand 5 minutes%2C then toss and serve.

Place watermelon chunks in a large bowl. Finely chop lemon zest. Add lemon juice and half of zest to bowl with watermelon. Add oil%2C mint%2C and arugula and toss until watermelon is evenly dressed. Season lightly to taste with salt and pepper.

Combine eggs, mayonnaise, lemon juice, celery, scallions, and parsley in a medium bowl. Using your hands, squeeze eggs through your fingers, mixing contents of bowl until reduced to desired consistency; alternatively, smash and mix with a firm whisk. Season generously with salt and pepper. Serve with sliced radishes, lettuce, and bread to make sandwiches, or store in a sealed container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

Transfer salad to a wide, shallow bowl or a large plate and spread out evenly. Crumble feta over the top. Sprinkle with remaining lemon zest. Drizzle with more olive oil and a few grinds of black pepper. Serve immediately.

Trim tops of chiles and discard seeds. Place on a microwave safe plate and microwave on high power until pliable and fragrant%2C about 15 seconds. Cut chilies into thin strips using kitchen shears or a sharp knife.
Heat 1 tablespoon oil in a medium saucepan over medium high heat until shimmering.
Add onions and garlic and cook%2C stirring%2C until softened and just starting to brown%2C about 5 minutes.

Transfer shredded pork to pot and toss with sauce. %28If making ahead to serve over the course of several meals%2C store pork and sauce separately%2C adding sauce only to the portion you are serving immediately.%29 Season to taste with more salt%2C sugar%2C liquid smoke%2C or vinegar. Serve.

Transfer pork to a large bowl%2C reserving liquid in pot. Using a ladle%2C skim off excess fat and discard. Add reserved sauce and remaining vinegar to pot and whisk to combine. When pork is cool enough to handle%2C shred with two forks.
Cook noodles according to package directions. Drain and transfer to a large bowl of ice water. Agitate noodles until thoroughly chilled. Set aside while you make the dressing.

In a large bowl%2C combine peanut butter%2C soy sauce%2C chili sauce%2C lime juice%2C sesame seed oil%2C garlic%2C honey%2C and water. Whisk until homogeneous. Drain noodles thoroughly and add to bowl.
Place in jar of a blender. Puree.
Season cucumber slices with kosher salt and set in a fine mesh strainer or colander over the sink or a bowl. Set aside while you prepare the rest of the vegetables.
Toss to combine. Serve immediately%2C topped with roasted peanuts.
With the blender running%2C slowly pour in vegetable oil. Use immediately or transfer to an airtight container and store in refrigerator for up to two weeks.
Meanwhile, place red onions in a 1- to 2-quart container and cover with hot tap water. Set aside while you prepare the rest of the vegetables.

If using fava beans and English peas in their pods%2C shuck the beans and peas from their pods%2C keeping them separate. Discard the pods. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil and prepare an ice bath. Working with one vegetable at a time%2C blanch the vegetables in the boiling water for 1 minute each%2C transfer to the ice bath to cool%2C then transfer to a paper towel-lined tray and pat dry. Remove and discard the skins from each individual fava bean. Set vegetables aside.

In a large bowl%2C whisk together lemon juice and mustard. Whisking constantly%2C slowly drizzle in olive oil. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Drain%2C rinse%2C and dry the cucumber and red onion. Add blanched vegetables%2C cucumber%2C onion%2C arugula%2C pine nuts%2C and mozzarella to the dressing%2C and toss to combine%2C adjusting seasoning with salt and pepper.

To serve%2C spread a spoonful of greek yogurt on the bottom of individual plates%2C or cover the bottom of a large serving platter with the yogurt. Drizzle the yogurt with olive oil%2C then pile the salad on top. Serve immediately.

In a medium bowl%2C mash blue cheese with a whisk. Whisk in mayonnaise%2C sour cream%2C buttermilk%2C and lemon juice until a smooth%2C slightly lumpy dressing forms. Season with pepper. %28The blue cheese will likely make the dressing salty enough%2C but taste and add salt if necessary.%29 Serve.
Scoop out melon leaving about 1/4-1/2 inch of red flesh. Peel off outer green with vegetable peeler and then cut into 1-inch cubes.

Combine and bring to a boil over medium-high heat in a medium saucepan %282-quart%29. Hold the boil for 60 seconds then carefully add the watermelon. Return to a boil and turn off the heat. Remove the pan from the heat and cool for 30 minutes.
%3Cstrong%3EFor the dough%3A %3C/strong%3ECombine in the bowl of a stand mixer and whisk at medium speed.
Move the pickles to a 2-quart jar using a canning funnel and ladle. Pour on as much of the pickling juice as possible. Cover the jar and leave at room temperature for another one and half hours.
Refrigerate overnight and consume within a month. These pickles must be refrigerated.
Add and continue whisking until combined.

Remove the whisk attachment and replace it with a dough hook. Add another 4 ounces of flour and knead on low speed for 5 minutes. At this point the dough should feel soft and moist but not sticky. If it is sticky%2C add a bit more flour one ounce at a time. Knead on low for another 5 minutes or until the dough clears the sides of the bowl.

Remove the whisk attachment and replace it with a dough hook. Add another 4 ounces of the remaining flour and knead on low speed for 5 minutes. At this point the dough should feel soft and moist but not sticky. If it is sticky, add a bit more flour (one ounce at a time). Knead on low for another 5 minutes or until the dough clears the sides of the bowl.

Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface%3B and form dough into a smooth ball. Transfer to a large bowl that has been lightly lubed with vegetable oil.  Rotate the bowl so that the dough ball is evenly covered. Cover with a clean kitchen towel and set aside until the dough doubles in volume%2C about 3 hours %28exact times will vary%29.
%3Cstrong%3EFor the filling%3A %3C/strong%3ECombine in a medium bowl and set aside.
%3Cstrong%3EFor assembly%3A %3C/strong%3EGrease up a 9 by 13-inch glass baking dish with the cold butter.
Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface and gently shape into a rectangle with the long side nearest you. Then use a rolling pin to shape into 18 by 12-inch rectangle.

Brush the dough with the melted butter%2C leaving a 1-inch border along the top edge. Sprinkle the brown sugar mixture over the exact same region as the butter. Gently press the filling into the dough.

Heat olive oil in a large skillet over high heat until shimmering. Add mushrooms and cook%2C stirring occasionally%2C until they%27ve released all their liquid and are browned%2C about 10 minutes total%2C reducing heat if oil starts to smoke excessively. Lower heat to medium%2C and stir in butter and shallots. Cook%2C stirring often%2C until butter is melted and shallots soften and turn translucent%2C about 4 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Add sherry and cook until mostly evaporated. Remove from heat and keep warm.

Beginning with the long edge nearest you, roll the dough away from you into a tight cylinder. Firmly pinch the seam to seal and roll the cylinder seam side down. Very gently squeeze the cylinder to create even thickness.
Using a serrated knife, gently cut the cylinder into 2-inch rolls; yielding 8 pieces.
Arrange rolls cut side down in the baking dish; cover tightly with plastic wrap and store in the refrigerator overnight, or up to 16 hours.

%3Cstrong%3ETo cook%3A %3C/strong%3EHeat the oven to 200 degrees F. When the oven has reached temperature%2C turn it off and place the rolls in the turned-off oven. Let the rolls rise until they look slightly puffy%2C about 30 minutes.

Without taking the rolls out of the oven, increase the oven temperature to 350 degrees F and let the rolls continue to bake for 25 to 30 minutes, or until the internal temperature reaches 190 degrees F. Remove the rolls and let cool while you make the icing.

Whisk the cream cheese in the bowl of a stand mixer until creamy. Add the milk and whisk until combined. Sift in the powdered sugar%2C and whisk until smooth. Spread over the rolls and serve immediately.
Whisk together in a small bowl. Season with salt and pepper. Alternatively%2C add dressing ingredients to a jar%2C cover%2C and shake until emulsified.

Combine in a zip-top bag and mush to combine. Remove air from zipper-lock bags by closing the bags%2C leaving the last inch of the top un-sealed. Slowly lower into a pot of water%2C sealing the bag completely just before it fully submerges. If using a vacuum bag%2C seal according to manufacturer instructions. If using a true sous-vide setup%2C cook the chicken to 150 F using manufacturer instructions.

In a large bowl, toss kale with just enough dressing to lightly coat. Add warm mushrooms and toss again. Add more dressing, as needed, to lightly coat all ingredients. Top with goat cheese, if using, and serve. Extra dressing can be kept in the refrigerator for another use.

Bring 1/2 cup reserved tomato water to a boil, then pour over bulgur in a small heatproof bowl and let stand until bulgur is softened, about 1 hour (bulgur may still have a slight bite, but will continue to soften in the salad). Drain bulgur of any excess liquid and pat dry with paper towels.
Toss to combine in a large bowl. Transfer to a fine mesh strainer or colander set in a bowl and allow to drain for 20 minutes. Reserve liquid.
Toss to combine. Transfer to a large mixing bowl lined with paper towels and let stand for 20 minutes. Blot parsley with towels to remove excess moisture.

Place potatoes in a large pot and add enough cold water to cover by 1 inch. Season generously with salt, set over high heat, and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer and cook until potatoes are easily pierced with a fork, 10 to 15 minutes. Drain potatoes and transfer to a large bowl. Let cool.

While chicken cooks%2C grind Sichuan peppercorns in a mortar and pestle until a rough powder is formed. Add sugar%2C remaining 3 cloves garlic%2C and sesame seeds and pound until a rough paste is formed. Add sesame paste%2C soy sauce%2C and vinegar and pound until a smooth paste is formed. Stir in chili oil and sediment. Set dressing aside.

When chicken is cooked, remove from bags and discard garlic, scallions, and ginger. Stir 2 tablespoons of juices from the bag into the dressing. Remove skin and bones from chicken and discard. Shred meat and transfer to a large bowl. Add dressing and sliced scallions. Toss chicken to coat in dressing and adjust seasoning with salt and pepper. Serve immediately, sprinkled with more scallions and sesame seeds and drizzled with additional chili oil if desired.

In a large mixing bowl, stir together tomatoes, parsley, mint, bulgur, scallions, olive oil, lemon juice, coriander seed, and cinnamon until well combined. Season with salt and pepper. Serve tabbouleh with romaine leaves.
Combine in a medium bowl. Mix well%2C then let stand for 10 minutes. Drain any accumulated water%2C then gently squeeze cucumbers with paper towels to blot up any excess liquid.
Mix well in a small bowl

Combine quinoa and 2 cups water in a small saucepan. Bring to a boil, stir, reduce heat to low, cover, and cook for 7 minutes. Shut off heat and let rest until water is absorbed, about 5 minutes longer. Transfer quinoa to a fine mesh strainer and rinse under cold water until thoroughly chilled. Let drain for 10 minutes.

Mash potatoes with a masher or a large fork, allowing some small lumps to remain. Add cucumbers, carrots, onions, eggs, scallions, and mayonnaise mixture. Mix well and season with salt. Serve right away. The salad can be refrigerated up to 1 day.
While quinoa cooks%2C combine tomatoes and cucumbers in a colander set in the sink. Season with salt and toss to coat. Let drain in sink until ready to combine with quinoa.

In a large bowl%2C toss drained quinoa%2C drained tomatoes and cucumbers%2C and all remaining ingredients. Season to taste with salt. Let rest overnight in a sealed container in the refrigerator. Salad can be stored in a sealed container in the refrigerator for up to 5 days

Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat oven to 350%C2%B0F. In a large bowl, massage kale with 3 tablespoons olive oil, making sure to coat all surfaces, kneading with your hands to help break down the tougher pieces, about 2 minutes. Set aside while you prepare the croutons and the dressing.

Combine bread pieces with remaining olive oil in the bowl of a food processor. Pulse until broken down into pea-sized pieces. Season to taste with salt and pepper and pulse once or twice to combine. Transfer to a rimmed baking sheet. Place in oven and bake until croutons are pale golden brown and crisp, about 20 minutes.

Wipe out food processor bowl. Combine mayonnaise%2C anchovies%2C garlic%2C cheese%2C Worcestershire sauce%2C and lemon juice in the food processor bowl and process until smooth. Season to taste with salt and pepper if necessary.
When croutons are cooked, add onions, dressing, and half of croutons to large bowl with wilted kale. Toss with hands until thoroughly coated. Serve sprinkled with remaining croutons.

If using fava beans and peas in their pods%2C shuck the beans and peas from their pods%2C keeping them separate. Discard the pods. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil and prepare an ice bath. Working with one vegetable at a time%2C blanch the veggies in the boiling water for 1 minute%2C transfer to the ice bath to cool%2C then transfer to a paper towel-lined tray and pat dry. Remove and discard the skins from each individual fava bean. Set vegetables aside.
Tear the bread into small pieces and transfer to the bowl of a food processor, mini-chopper, or blender. Pulse until reduced to fine bread crumbs.

Heat butter in a small skillet over medium heat until melted, then add bread crumbs and cook, stirring and tossing frequently, until golden brown and crisp, about 5 minutes. Add half of shallots and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Remove from heat, add half of parsley and half of chives, and toss to combine. Season mixture to taste with salt and pepper.

In a large bowl, whisk together lemon juice, lemon zest, and remaining shallot, parsley, and chives. Slowly drizzle in the olive oil, whisking constantly. Add the blanched vegetables, toss to combine, and season to taste with salt and pepper. Divide the vegetables between four serving plates or bowls, making a small indentation to place the egg.
Transfer the poached eggs to the skillet with the bread crumbs and turn them carefully to coat in crumbs. Place the eggs on top of the salad and spoon any remaining crumbs on top. Serve immediately.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the Beets%3A%3C/strong%3E Preheat oven to 375 F. Fold a 12- by 24-inch sheet of aluminum foil in half to form a square. Crimp together foil on 2 sides of square to form a pouch with an opening on one side. In a medium bowl%2C toss together beets%2C 1 tablespoon olive oil%2C and salt and pepper to taste until beets are coated. Add to pouch and crimp remaining side to seal. %28If using beets of multiple colors%2C roast in separate pouches.%29 Transfer to a rimmed baking sheet and place in oven. Roast until beets are completely tender and a toothpick or cake tester inserted into a beet through foil meets little to no resistance%2C about 1 1/2 hours. Remove from oven and allow to cool. When beets are cool enough to handle%2C peel by gently rubbing skin under cold running water. Cut beets into 1 1/2-inch chunks. Beets can be cooked and stored in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.
%3Cstrong%3EFor the Horseradish Creme Fraiche%3A%3C/strong%3E In a small bowl%2C stir together creme fraiche and horseradish. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Refrigerate until ready to use.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the Dressing:%3C/strong%3E In a small bowl, combine lemon juice, tarragon, chives, shallot, and honey. Slowly drizzle in olive oil while stirring vigorously with a fork. Season dressing to taste with salt and pepper.

%3Cstrong%3ETo Serve%3A%3C/strong%3E In a large bowl%2C toss beets with dressing. Spoon half of creme fraiche mixture on the bottom of a serving plate. Place beets on top and drizzle with remaining creme fraiche mixture. Sprinkle with pistachios and serve.

Bring a large saucepan of heavily salted water to a boil and prepare an ice bath. Add snap peas to boiling water and cook until crisp-tender, about 2 minutes. Using a slotted spoon or mesh strainer, transfer snap peas to ice bath to chill.
Meanwhile, in a medium bowl, whisk together yogurt, olive oil, mayonnaise, lemon juice and zest, mint, and shallot. Season with salt and pepper.

Drain snap peas thoroughly, then blot dry with clean kitchen towels or paper towels. Transfer to a serving bowl and toss with dressing until evenly coated. Check seasoning and add more salt if necessary, then serve right away.

Combine all ingredients except for avocados in a large bowl and mix well. Cover and chill at least 30 minutes and up to over night. Right before serving, add avocados and fold gently, being careful not to mash avocados. Garnish with more chopped cilantro if desired. Serve at room temperature.
Whisk together in small bowl.
Combine in a large bowl and toss to combine. Let stand five minutes%2C then transfer to a large colander and rinse thoroughly under cold running water.
Cook the noodles and wakame in boiling water according to the package directions, about 4 minutes, then rinse thoroughly under cold water, mixing the noodles well. Drain.

Transfer vegetables to a salad spinner and spin dry. Alternatively, transfer to a large rimmed baking sheet lined with a triple layer of paper towels or a clean kitchen towel and blot mixture dry with more towels. Return to large bowl.
Pour dressing over vegetables and toss to coat. Adjust seasoning to taste with salt, pepper, and/or sugar.
While the noodles are cooking, combine miso paste, sesame oil, vinegar, ginger, peanut oil, and water in a large bowl. Whisk until homogenous. Set aside.

Toss kale with 2 tablespoons dressing and divide between four serving bowls. Toss noodles with another 2 tablespoons dressing and add on top of noodles. Top bowls with bean sprouts, avocado, cilantro, nori and sesame seeds. Drizzle with more dressing, and serve with additional dressing on the side. Unused dressing can be stored in a sealed container in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.

Add half of sauce mixture and chicken stock. Cover Dutch oven%2C transfer to oven%2C and cook until pork is just starting to turn tender%2C about 4 hours. Remove lid and continue cooking until a knife or fork shows very little resistance when twisted inside the meat and a dark bark has formed%2C about 1 hour longer.
Add onion and cook%2C stirring and scraping up browned bits from the bottom of the pan%2C until softened%2C about 2 minutes.

Turn off burner and add bourbon. Relight burner. Carefully ignite the bourbon with a long match or lighter. %28Stand back and make sure there is nothing flammable above it%3B it will produce tall flames.%29 Let cook until flames die out%2C about 2 minutes.

Cut the cucumbers in half lengthwise. Use a teaspoon to scrape out the seeds, then cut into thin slices. Toss the cucumbers with the salt in a colander. Let drain in the sink for at least 30 minutes, then tap the colander on the base of the sink to release any remaining water. Lay a clean dish towel flat on the counter, and then dump the cucumbers over top. Use the edges of the towel to blot the cucumbers dry.
Meanwhile, soak the red onions in a small bowl of ice water for at least 10 minutes, then drain in a fine mesh strainer.

In a medium bowl%2C combine the cucumbers%2C onions%2C white wine vinegar%2C olive oil%2C vegetable oil%2C sugar%2C pepper and mint. Taste and adjust seasoning if necessary. Cover and let stand in refrigerator for at least 20 minutes. Serve cold.
Whisk together all ingredients in a medium bowl. Set aside.
Combine in a large bowl and toss with a large pinch of salt. Set aside.

In a large pot of salted boiling water%2C cook pasta until very tender%2C about 15 minutes. Drain pasta and transfer to a large bowl. Add vinegar and stir until completely absorbed. Let pasta stand until cool%2C about 10 minutes.
Add dressing and stir until well coated. Stir in celery, shallots, and scallions. Season with salt and pepper. Cover and chill in refrigerator for at least 1 hour before serving.
Whisk together and pour over cabbage. Toss to combine and season with more salt and pepper as desired. Transfer to refrigerator and let rest for 30 minutes or up to 3 days before serving.

Heat oil in a Dutch oven over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add pork and cook%2C turning occasionally%2C until well browned on all sides%2C about 5 minutes total. %28Pork will brown fast because of the sugar. Do not let it burn.%29
Adjust oven rack to lower position and preheat oven to 300%C2%B0F %28150%C2%B0C%29.
Combine salt%2C sugar%2C cayenne pepper%2C coriander%2C fennel seed%2C paprika%2C ground cumin%2C and black pepper in a small bowl and mix until homogeneous.
Season pork with 2 to 3 tablespoons spice mixture%2C making sure to rub it on all sides. Reserve remaining spice mixture.
Whisk together ketchup%2C molasses%2C Worcestershire sauce%2C liquid smoke%2C mustard%2C hot sauce%2C and vinegar in a medium bowl. Whisk in remaining spice mixture. Set aside.

Add rice, salt and 3 1/2 cups water to a pot and bring to a boil. Turn heat down to low, cover and simmer until rice is done, about 50 minutes. Transfer rice to strainer to drain any excess water, then set aside to cool.
Combine in a medium bowl. Season to taste with salt and pepper%2C then serve.
Place flour in one shallow bowl or pie plate and beaten egg in a second. Combine parmesan and breadcrumbs in third and season to taste with salt and pepper.
Dredge veal in flour, then egg. Allow excess egg to drip off, then transfer to breadcrumbs. Turn to coat evenly, pressing crumbs so they adhere. Transfer scallopini to a large plate.
Preheat oven to 350%C2%B0F.  Line a sheet pan with parchment paper%3B set aside.

Roll the dough into small balls%2C about 1-inch in diameter. Fill a separate small bowl with sugar%2C and roll each ball in the sugar until it is completely coated. Place dough balls on the prepared baking sheet.

Bake for about 8-10 minutes%2C until the cookies begin to slightly crack on top.  %28They will crack more while cooling.%29  Remove from the oven and let cool for 4-5 minutes. Then transfer the cookies to wire racks to cool completely.
Serve warm and enjoy%2C or store in a sealed container for up to 4 days.  Or freeze for up to 3 months.
Transfer the dough to an airtight container and refrigerate for at least 2 hours%2C or until the dough is completely chilled.
Mix in the eggs %28one at a time%29 and molasses%2C and beat on medium-low speed until each is combined. Gradually add in the dry ingredient mixture and beat until it is evenly incorporated.
In a medium bowl%2C whisk together flour%2C soda%2C cinnamon%2C cloves%2C ginger and salt. Set aside.

Using a separate mixing bowl%2C either with a stand mixer or a hand mixer%2C cream together the softened butter and sugars on medium-high speed until the mixture is light and fluffy and a pale yellow color%2C about 2 minutes%2C scraping down the sides occasionally as needed.
Cool cookies for 5 minutes on the baking sheet%2C then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.
Cookies stay fresh covered at room temperature for up to 1 week.

Bake the cookies for 11-12 minutes. If the cookies aren%E2%80%99t really spreading by minute 9%2C remove them from the oven and lightly bang the baking sheet on the counter 2-3x. This helps initiate that spread. Return to the oven for a couple more minutes. The cookies will be thick regardless%2C though%E2%80%93 they deflate a little as they cool%21

Add oil to a small skillet and heat over medium-high heat until shimmering and corner of veal dipped in oil immediately starts bubbling. Carefully add one piece of veal to hot oil. Cook, swirling pan occasionally until golden brown on first side, about 1 1/2 minutes. Carefully turn with tongs and cook until second side is golden brown, about 1 minute longer. Adjust heat as necessary to prevent oil from burning—veal should bubble steadily. Transfer veal to paper towel-lined plate and season immediately with salt.  Drain on a paper towel. Repeat with second veal scallopino
Toss arugula, tomatoes, basil and extra parmesan shavings in a medium bowl with olive oil and lemon juice. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve veal and salad immediately.

Preheat oven to 375 F. Fold a 12- by 24-inch sheet of aluminum foil in half to form a square. Crimp two edges to form a pouch. Toss beets%2C 1 tablespoon olive oil%2C rosemary%2C and salt and pepper to taste in a medium bowl until beets are coated. Add to pouch and crimp remaining edge to seal. %28If using multiple colors of beets%2C roast in separate pouches.%29 Transfer to a rimmed baking sheet and place in oven. Roast until beets are completely tender and a toothpick or cake tester inserted into a beet through foil meets little to no resistance%2C about 1 1/2 hours. Remove from oven and allow to cool. When beets are cool enough to handle%2C peel by gently rubbing skin under cold running water. Cut beets into 1 1/2%E2%80%93inch chunks. Beets can be cooked and stored in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.

Place pistachios in a mortar and pound with pestle until lightly crushed but not totally pulverized. (You can also chop them with a knife.) Transfer half of nuts to a large bowl and reserve the rest for garnish.
Combine in a large bowl with pistachios and whisk to combine. Drizzle in remaining 3 tablespoons olive oil while whisking constantly. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

Place tofu in a large colander and set in the sink. Pour 1 quart boiling water over tofu and let rest for 1 minute. Transfer to a paper towel-lined tray and press dry. Heat olive oil in a large nonstick or cast iron skillet over medium-low heat until shimmering. Add tofu and cook%2C turning occasionally%2C until golden brown and crisp on all surfaces%2C about 10 minutes total. Sprinkle with half of za%27atar and toss to coat. Transfer tofu to a paper towel-lined plate to drain. Scrape remaining contents of pan into a medium bowl and set aside to cool slightly.

Toss beets and citrus with vinaigrette in a large bowl %28if using red beets%2C toss them separately from everything else%29 and season to taste with salt and pepper. Spread half of ricotta over a serving platter%2C place dressed beets and citrus on top%2C dollop with remaining ricotta%2C sprinkle with reserved pistachios%2C and serve.

Add 2 tablespoons reserved grapefruit juice%2C tahini%2C miso paste%2C lemon juice%2C and honey to bowl with reserved oil from cooking. Add 1 more tablespoon olive oil. Whisk until smooth%2C adding more grapefruit juice or water as necessary to achieve a smooth%2C pourable consistency about the texture of heavy paint. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
Combine tofu, grapefruit segments, and avocado in a large bowl. Add remaining tablespoon olive oil and remaining za%27atar, season with salt, and gently fold together.
Add greens and half of dressing and gently fold to combine. Serve immediately%2C drizzling remaining dressing on top.
Preheat oven to 350%C2%B0F %28177%C2%B0C%29. Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. %28Always recommended for cookies.%29 Set aside.

Scoop and roll balls of dough%2C about 5 Tablespoons of dough each%2C into balls. Roll each ball very lightly in granulated sugar%2C then generously in the confectioners%E2%80%99 sugar. Place 3 inches apart on the baking sheets.
Remove cookie dough from the refrigerator and allow to sit at room temperature for 15 minutes. You can preheat the oven during this time.

In a large bowl using a hand-held mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment%2C beat the butter%2C granulated sugar%2C and brown sugar together on medium high speed until fluffy and creamed%2C about 2 minutes.
Beat in egg and vanilla on high speed. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed.

On low speed%2C slowly mix the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until combined%2C then beat in the chocolate chips. The cookie dough will be thick and sticky. Cover dough tightly with aluminum foil or plastic wrap and chill for at least 2 hours and up to 3 days. Chilling is mandatory for this cookie dough. I always chill mine overnight.
Whisk the flour%2C cocoa powder%2C baking soda%2C and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside.

Bake until the snickerdoodles begin to spread%2C about 5 minutes%2C then reduce temperature to 350%C2%B0F %28175%C2%B0C%29. Continue baking until firm around the edges but steamy in the middle%2C about 6 minutes longer. Cool directly on half sheet pan until the crumb is set%2C about 8 minutes. Enjoy warm%2C or store in an airtight container for up to 3 days at room temperature.

For the Cinnamon Sugar%3A Mix sugar with ground and grated cinnamon in a small bowl%2C adding more spice if you prefer. %28It should taste very intense to offset the mild dough.%29 Roll each portion of dough into a smooth and sticky ball%2C then tumble in cinnamon sugar until fully coated.

Arrange on a parchment-lined aluminum half sheet pan%2C leaving 2 1%2F2 inches between balls%2C then flatten into 2-inch disks about 1%2F2 inch thick. Generously cover with the remaining cinnamon sugar%2C creating a thick layer that will crack and crinkle in the oven.

Combine parsley, basil, oregano, garlic, vinegar, and honey in the bowl of a food processor and process until a paste forms. With the machine running, drizzle in the olive oil to form an emulsion. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Vinaigrette is best used immediately, but can be stored in a sealed container in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.

Place the wild rice in a saucepan, cover with plenty of water, bring to a boil, and then turn down to a gentle simmer and cook for 35 minutes, until the rice is cooked but still firm. Drain, rinse under cold water, and set aside to dry.

Combine in a saucepan%2C cover%2C and cook over the lowest possible heat for 15 minutes. Remove from the heat%2C place a tea towel over the pan%2C replace the lid%2C and set aside for 10 minutes. Uncover and allow to cool down completely.
Bring a small saucepan of water to a boil and add the quinoa. Cook for 9 minutes%2C then drain into a fine sieve%2C refresh under cold water%2C and set aside.
Combine in a small pan. Cook over medium-low heat for about 5 minutes%2C stirring frequently. Transfer to a small plate as soon as the pine nuts begin to color and set aside.

Heat the sunflower oil in a large saute pan and add the onions%2C 1/4 teaspoon salt%2C and some black pepper. Cook over high heat for 5 to 8 minutes%2C stirring often%2C so that parts of the onion get crisp and others just soft. Transfer to paper towels to drain.
Combine in a large bowl%2C mix well%2C and set aside for at least 10 minutes before serving.

Cut tomatoes into an assortment of slices and chunks and spread over a large plate in a single, slightly overlapping layer. Tuck chunks of mozzarella into the tomato pieces. Drizzle generously with extra-virgin olive oil. Sprinkle with coarse sea salt and black pepper. Tear basil leaves into small pieces with your fingertips and spread them on top. Serve immediately.

Drain chickpeas and place in a large pot with bay leaf, carrot, onion, and the segmented celery stalk. Cover with cold water by 2 inches, season with salt, bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and cook until the chickpeas are tender but still hold their shape, about 1 hour. Discard bay leaf, carrot, onion, and celery. Drain and rinse under cold running water until chilled. Let drain in a colander set in the sink while you prepare the rest of the salad.

Place pepitas on a large plate and microwave on high power for 2 minutes. Stir and microwave for a further 2 minutes. Continue stirring and microwaving at 30 second intervals until lightly toasted and fragrant. Alternatively, toast in a dry skillet over medium heat, stirring constantly, until lightly toasted and fragrant.

Combine chickpeas, carrots, toasted pumpkin seeds, garlic, olive oil, vinegar, and dill in a large bowl and toss to coat. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve immediately, or for better results, store overnight in a covered container in the refrigerator. Salad will keep for up to 3 days.
To rehydrate seaweed: Place seaweed in large bowl filled with water.  Let soak for 10 to 15 minutes, or until seaweed is supple. Working by handfuls, squeeze seaweed of residual water.

Place seaweed on cutting board and chop into rough half-inch slices. Dress seaweed in oil%2C vinegar%2C salt%2C and sugar.  Adjust seasonings to taste%2C depending on how tangy you like your seaweed.  Sprinkle with sesame seeds and serve cold or at room temperature.  Leftover seaweed may be kept in refrigerator for up to four days.

Adjust oven rack to lower-middle position and preheat oven to 400 F. Line a 9- by 13-inch baking dish with foil and butter spray with cooking spray. Add carrots%2C olive oil%2C vinegar%2C and honey. Season lightly with salt and generously with pepper and toss to combine. Transfer to oven to roast%2C stirring periodically%2C until edges are starting to char and carrots are softened but still have some crunch%2C about 25 minutes.
Remove from oven, toss with lemon juice and let cool to room temperature. Add feta, season with additional cracked black pepper, toss and serve.
In a mixing bowl, combine 2 tablespoons of olive oil, cayenne, oregano, 1 teaspoon salt, and 1/2 teaspoon pepper. Add the shrimp and coat with the mixture. Set aside for 10 minutes.
Whisk together and set aside.
To a large mixing bowl, add orzo, cucumber, tomatoes, red onion, olives, artichoke hearts, and parsley. Stir to combine.
