Heat the remaining tablespoon of oil in a 10-inch cast iron or stainless steel skillet over high heat until shimmering. Add the shrimp and cook without moving until lightly browned, about 2 minutes. Flip and cook until just cooked through, 1 to 2 minutes longer. Transfer to a small bowl and toss with lime juice.
In a large serving bowl, combine the arugula, shallot, pine nuts, avocado, tomatoes and basil. Add dressing, season with salt and pepper, and toss to combine. Serve immediately, topped with shrimp.
Pour olive oil into orzo mixture. Juice the entire lemon into the same bowl. Add salt and grind pepper to taste. Stir gently to combine. Add feta. Stir again. Serve cold or at room temperature.

Prepare an ice bath. In a medium or large pot of salted boiling water and working in batches%2C cook broccoli florets until just barely softened and bright green%2C 1 minute. Using a strainer%2C transfer immediately to ice bath and repeat with remaining broccoli florets. Once broccoli is fully chilled%2C drain very well.
Put the red onion in iced water for 10 minutes while you prepare the other ingredients.

Meanwhile%2C in a blender%2C combine pistachios with vinegar%2C Dijon%2C garlic%2C and vegetable oil. Blend at high speed%2C stopping to scrape down the blender jar sides if necessary%2C until pistachios are mostly pureed with only some small chunks left. Add basil leaves and blend until finely chopped. Add olive oil and blend at the slowest speed until incorporated. Season with salt and pepper.

Lightly crush or chop remaining pistachios. In a large salad bowl, combine drained broccoli florets, broccoli stems, crushed pistachios, radicchio, and a generous shaving of Parmesan cheese. Stir dressing well (or mix it briefly in the blender at slow speed to stir), then add just enough to lightly coat all the salad ingredients. Toss well and season with salt and pepper. If more dressing is needed, add more. Top with more fresh shavings of Parmesan and serve.

Place the diced mangoes in a bowl and add half the lime juice and salt. Taste for balance and add more of both if necessary. Add the chile%2C then drain the onion and add it along with the cilantro leaves. Stir everything gently to combine and then leave in the fridge for 5 minutes to chill and marinate.

Combine the arugula%2C fennel%2C fennel fronds%2C and orange segments in a large bowl. In a small bowl%2C whisk mustard%2C honey%2C and vinegar. Whisking constantly%2C drizzle in olive oil. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Dress salad as desired %28not all the dressing needs to be used%29. Serve immediately. Extra dressing can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 1 month.
Serve in individual large glasses or bowls.

Combine hamachi, onion, scallion, cucumber, avocado, chili, lemon zest, sesame seeds, soy sauce, and olive oil in a medium bowl. Season with a small pinch of kosher salt and gently fold to combine. Taste and adjust with more soy sauce, olive oil, or salt as desired. Let stand 5 minutes at room temperature, then serve on its own or on top of steamed rice.
Combine in a large bowl. Toss until evenly coated. Allow to rest at room temperature until kale is lightly wilted%2C about 1 hour.

Meanwhile, place onions in a medium bowl and cover with cold water. Allow to rest for 15 minutes. Rinse in several changes of water then carefully dry with a salad spinner lined with paper towels. Combine onions with sumac and sesame seeds. Season to taste with salt.

Combine lemon juice, garlic, and mustard in a small bowl. Once kale is wilted, toss kale, lemon juice mixture, and chickpeas in a large bowl. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve salad topped with sumac onions.
In a small bowl%2C whisk together blood orange juice%2C vinegar%2C shallot%2C and honey. Whisking constantly%2C slowly drizzle in olive oil%2C then season with salt and pepper to taste.
Put spinach, pistachios, and oranges in a large bowl. Add vinaigrette. Season with salt and pepper and toss until salad is evenly coated. Serve immediately

Drain chickpeas and place in a large pot with bay leaf, carrot, onion, and the segmented celery stalk. Cover with cold water by 2 inches, season with salt, bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and cook until the chickpeas are tender but still hold their shape, about 1 hour. Discard bay leaf, carrot, onion, and celery. Drain and rinse under cold running water until chilled. Let drain in a colander set in the sink while you prepare the rest of the salad.

Combine cumin and vinegar in a large bowl. Whisking constantly, slowly drizzle in olive oil. Add shallot, sliced celery, parsley leaves, and drained chickpeas. Toss to coat with dressing and season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve immediately, or for better results, store overnight in a covered container in the refrigerator. Salad will keep for up to three days.
Combine in a large bowl and massage to soften slightly. Taste and season with more salt or lime juice to taste. Serve immediately.

In a pot of salted boiling water, cook pasta until very tender throughout, 2 to 3 minutes longer than al dente stage according to package. Drain in a colander, then chill under cold running water. Let drain well, then drizzle lightly with olive oil and toss to coat. Set aside.

Meanwhile, in a medium skillet, heat 3 tablespoons olive oil with garlic over medium heat until garlic begins to sizzle lightly. Increase heat to high and add tomatoes. Cook, tossing frequently, until tomato skins split, burst, and release some juices, about 5 minutes; you can gently press on some of the tomatoes with a wooden spoon to help them along, but avoid mashing them. Season with salt and pepper.

In a large bowl, toss pasta with tomatoes, garlic, and their sauce, along with the remaining 3 tablespoons olive oil and basil. Season with salt and pepper. Once cooled, add mozzarella, if using, and toss to combine. Serve at room temperature, adding additional olive oil as necessary to refresh noodles. Pasta salad can be made up to 1 day in advance without basil and kept refrigerated; return to room temperature, toss in basil, and refresh with more olive oil before serving.

Wash and peel carrots%2C taking care to scrub out any dirt lodged between the carrot tops and the crowns of the carrots. Trim carrot tops%2C leaving only 1 inch attached on each. Using a vegetable peeler%2C peel carrots lengthwise to create long strips. Cover strips with a damp kitchen towel and set aside. Once most of each carrot has been peeled and only a slender core remains%2C split remaining carrot in half lengthwise. Repeat with the rest of the carrot cores and set aside in a shallow dish%2C along with dill.
Combine in a small pot. Bring to a boil and pour over carrot pieces. Set aside to pickle at least 1 hour at room temperature and up to overnight in the fridge.

Hull and quarter strawberries%2C then slice quarters crosswise into very thin pieces. In a mixing bowl%2C combine strawberries with sugar and cointreau and let stand in refrigerator for at least 2 hours and up to 2 days.

Just before serving the salad%2C melt ghee or butter in a small saute pan over medium heat. Add cinnamon%2C bay leaf%2C and star anise and toast until fragrant%2C about 5 minutes. Remove spices and add currants to the hot fat. Transfer hot fat and currants to a large bowl. Stir in yogurt and 2 tablespoons pickling liquid and season with salt and pepper to taste.
Drain pickled carrots and fold into the salad along with the dill. Toss the strips and split pieces gently to combine. Serve right away.
Combine in a medium bowl
Combine in a small bowl and stir until no lumps are left.
Add yogurt mixture into carrot mixture. Stir thoroughly to combine. Let sit a few hours in refrigerator so flavors can meld%2C though you can serve immediately if desired. Serve.

In a large bowl, whisk together lemon juice and mustard. Slowly drizzle in three tablespoons olive oil, whisking constantly. Season with salt and pepper. Add scallions, bell peppers, and radishes, and set aside. In a separate bowl, toss the green beans with the remaining tablespoon olive oil and season with salt and pepper.

Light one chimney full of charcoal. When all the charcoal is lit and covered with gray ash%2C pour out and arrange the coals over half the charcoal grate. Set cooking grate in place%2C cover grill and allow to preheat for 5 minutes

Hull remaining strawberries and puree at high speed in a blender until very smooth%2C about 30 seconds. Strain through a fine mesh strainer to filter out all seeds and fibers%2C then measure and reserve 1 1/2 cups puree.

Add the green beans to the grill directly over the coals%2C placing them perpendicular to the grill grates or using a thin-grated vegetable basket if you have one to prevent them from falling into the grates. Cook%2C turning occasionally%2C until blistered%2C charred%2C and tender-crisp%2C about 3 minutes.

To make tonic water, combine the syrup with carbonated water, mixing one part syrup to four parts water. Do not combine them in a large batch unless you intend to use all the tonic water at once. Instead, combine syrup and fresh carbonated water for each individual use.
Transfer beans to the bowl with the dressing/scallion/radish/pepper mixture. Add parsley and toss to combine. Season the salad with salt and pepper. Serve immediately or at room temperature.

Place onions in a small bowl and cover with cold water. Set aside. Combine tomatoes and peppers in a colander set over a bowl and season with 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt and a few grinds black pepper. Allow to rest at room temperature for 20 minutes. You should end up with about 2 tablespoons juice in the bowl. If excess juice is collected, discard all but 2 tablespoons.

Add mustard and vinegar to vegetable juices. Slowly whisk in olive oil. Add tomatoes, peppers, cheese, drained onions, and basil to bowl and toss to combine. Season to taste with salt and pepper and serve.
Preheat the oven to 400 F. Line a baking sheet with aluminum foil. Remove the leafy stems and roots of the beets and peel each one with a vegetable peeler. Cut the beets in 1 1/2-inch chunks.

Place the cut beets on the prepared baking sheet and toss with the olive oil and salt. Roast for until the beets are tender when pierced with a thin-bladed knife, 35 to 40 minutes, tossing once with a spatula midway through.
Meanwhile%2C combine the vinegar and maple syrup in a small skillet. Cook over medium heat until the liquid is reduced by about half.

Strain mixture through two layers of cheesecloth placed in a fine-mesh sieve. Strain again if there are still particles to be removed. Place the tonic syrup in a sealable glass container and refrigerate for at least two hours before use.
Toss the glaze with the roasted beets and chill until ready to serve.

With a paring knife%2C remove the core from two of the quarters and slice them as thinly as possible. Place the slices in a bowl%2C squeeze lemon juice over them%2C and toss to coat to prevent discoloration. Reserve the remaining apple half for another use.
In a small bowl, combine the vinegar and honey. Whisking constantly, slowly drizzle in the olive oil. Season dressing to taste with salt and pepper.

When ready to serve, toss the arugula and the apples with just enough dressing to coat the leaves. Divide the salad among four plates. Sprinkle each salad with pomegranate seeds, sliced almonds and crumbled goat cheese.
Toss all ingredients together in a large bowl. Cover and refrigerate for at least 15 minutes to allow flavors to blend. Season to taste with salt, pepper and honey. Serve cold.

In a small saucepan, combine vinegar, water and salt and bring to a boil. Place garlic, bay leaf, peppercorns and red chili flakes in the bottom of a jar that can hold at least 1 1/2 pints. Pack trimmed artichoke hearts into the jar where you%27ve placed the spices. Pour hot pickling liquid over the artichoke hearts and tap gently to dislodge any air bubbles.
Pour olive oil into jar until the artichoke hearts are covered. Place a lid on the jar and shake to help distribute oil. Let jar sit on counter until cool. Once cool, refrigerate.
Let artichokes marinate for at least 24 hours before eating. Marinated artichokes will keep for at least one week in the refrigerator.
Heat olive oil in a medium sauce pan over medium-low heat. Add onions and cook%2C stirring frequently%2C until soft and translucent%2C about 5 minutes.

Add quinoa to onions and continue cooking%2C stirring constantly%2C for 3-4 minutes. Add vegetable broth and stir in salt. Turn heat up to high and bring to a boil. Cover pan tightly with lid%2C turn heat down to low and simmer for 17-20 minutes%2C until liquid is absorbed and quinoa is cooked. Transfer cooked quinoa to mixing bowl and chill in refrigerator.
When quinoa is cool%2C add all remaining ingredients. Toss together and adjust seasoning as necessary. Serve.
Reduce heat to medium-low and cook for 45 minutes. Remove from heat and let mixture steep for 20 minutes.

In a medium mixing bowl%2C toss half the shredded Brussels sprouts with the salt. Knead and squeeze salted sprouts%2C softening them and releasing their liquid%2C about 2 minutes. Zest tangerine and reserve removed zest%3B then%2C juice the tangerine and add the juice to the salted sprouts. Toss to coat%2C cover%2C then transfer to the refrigerator for at least 15 minutes and up to 4 hours.
In a small bowl, combine shallot, Dijon, vinegar, and the finely grated zest of reserved tangerine peel. Whisk in olive oil, season with salt and pepper, then set aside.

In a small skillet, toast hazelnuts over medium-high heat, stirring and shaking pan constantly, until skins are just beginning to take on a light roasted, campfire smell (being careful not to burn them or darken them to the point of developing an unpleasant flavor), about 4 minutes. Let cool slightly. Transfer nuts to a zipper-lock bag, then gently crush under the weight of a heavy pan or skillet to form large broken chunks.

Remove salted sprouts from refrigerator. Knead and squeeze once more%2C then drain and squeeze well to remove any excess moisture. Transfer to a serving bowl. Toss with remaining shredded raw Brussels sprouts and toasted hazelnuts. Whisk dressing%2C then drizzle all over salad%2C stopping when you%27ve lightly coated all the salad%2C even if there is dressing left over. Season with salt and pepper%2C then add crumbled goat cheese%2C toss gently to combine%2C and serve right away.

Drain chickpeas and place in a large pot with bay leaf, carrot, onion, and celery. Cover with cold water by 2 inches, season with salt, bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and cook until the chickpeas are tender but still hold their shape, about 1 hour. Discard bay leaf, carrot, onion, and celery. Drain and rinse under cold running water until chilled. Let drain in a colander set in the sink.

Meanwhile, adjust rack to 4 to 5 inches below broiler and preheat broiler to high. Place chilies on a foil-lined broiler pan and broil, turning occasionally, until completely blackened on all surfaces, about 15 minutes total. Crimp foil to seal around the chilies and set aside for 10 minutes.

Meanwhile, cook bacon in a medium skillet over medium-high heat, stirring frequently, until completely crisp. Remove from heat and stir in shallots and garlic. Immediately transfer to a large bowl. Add olive oil and 2 tablespoons lime juice and whisk to combine.
When chilies are cool enough to handle, peel using your fingers. Discard skin, stems, and seeds and slice flesh into thin strips.

When beans are cooked and drained, add to bacon mixture. Add chili strips, cotija, scallions, and cilantro and toss to combine. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve immediately with lime wedges, or for better results, store overnight in a covered container in the refrigerator. Salad will keep for up to three days.

Combine shallot%2C garlic%2C mustard%2C vinegar%2C water%2C and tarragon in a tall%2C narrow container. Using an immersion blender%2C blend until tarragon is finely chopped and incorporated into dressing base. Transfer to a large bowl. Whisking constantly%2C slowly drizzle in olive oil. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Set aside.

In a large cast iron skillet, heat 3 tablespoons vegetable oil over high heat until lightly smoking. Add just enough mushrooms to barely fill skillet without crowding. Season with salt and cook, stirring occasionally, until mushrooms are tender and browned, about 5 minutes. Transfer cooked mushrooms to a baking sheet in an even layer and allow them to cool to room temperature. Repeat with remaining mushrooms in as many batches as needed, adding more oil to the pan before each batch.

In a large bowl, combine watercress with cooled mushrooms and cheese. Season lightly with salt and pepper. Dress and toss with just enough vinaigrette to lightly coat salad ingredients, adding more vinaigrette as needed. Serve right away. Extra vinaigrette can be kept refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.

Place currants and balsamic vinegar in medium microwave-safe bowl and cook in the microwave for 30 seconds to plump up the currants. Whisk in the honey. Whisking constantly, slowly drizzle in olive oil. Season to taste with salt and pepper. In a large bowl, toss the kale and pine nuts. Add the dressing with the currants to the shredded kale, little by little, until adequately dressed. Spoon out the currants if you have dressing left over. Return salad to refrigerator for at least 20 minutes and up to overnight to soften kale leaves. Serve, topped with grated parmesan.
Heat grill to moderate heat. Place baguette halves on grill, cut side down, and grill until lightly toasted. Transfer to cutting board and let cool. Cut into 1 1/2-inch cubes and reserve.
Rub chicken with 1 tablespoon oil and season with salt and pepper. Grill both sides until just cooked through (160°F). Transfer to cutting board and let rest 10 minutes. Cut into 1 1/2-inch cubes.

Place tomatoes%2C cucumbers%2C onion%2C olives%2C basil%2C bread%2C and chicken in a large bowl. Whisk remaining oil%2C red wine vinegar%2C balsamic vinegar%2C salt%2C and pepper in a medium bowl until combined.

Zest lemon and lime and place in medium saucepan. Juice lemon and lime and add juice to saucepan, along with water, cinchona bark, citric acid powder, lemongrass, and sugar. Bring to a boil on high heat.

In a clean mixing bowl%2C whisk together 1 1/2 cups strawberry puree with half and half%2C corn syrup%2C and sugar until fully combined. Add salt to taste%2C and%2C if mixture is too sweet%2C a few drops of lemon juice.

Chill in refrigerator or ice bath until base is very cold%2C at least 45 F%2C then churn in ice cream maker according to manufacturer%27s instructions. In the last minute of churning%2C retrieve strawberry mix-ins from the refrigerator%2C strain off syrup%2C and add mix-ins to the churn%3B reserve strawberry syrup for another use %28it makes a great daiquiri%29. Transfer ice cream to airtight container and chill in freezer for at least 4 hours before serving.
%3Cstrong%3EFor the Batter%3A%3C/strong%3E Combine in a large bowl%2C mixing by hand until the vanilla bean seeds are well dispersed.

Using a cookie scoop%2C divide dough into 2-tablespoon portions. If you like%2C these can be transferred to a zipper-lock bag and refrigerated for up to 1 week%2C or frozen for up to 3 months%3B soften to about 68%C2%B0F %2820%C2%B0C%29 before baking.
Add to dry ingredients and whisk until smooth.
Cut into 1-inch chunks and puree at high speed in a blender%2C starting with 1/4 of the melon and adding more chunks once the first batch has been pureed.
Add lime juice and salt to taste%3B blend to combine. Refrigerate for one hour.
Top the soup with vinegar and feta. Serve.
Reduce speed to low%2C add flour%2C and mix to form a stiff dough.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the Waffles%3A%3C/strong%3E Set waffle iron to medium and preheat until the indicator is ready. For an 8-inch square machine%2C scrape in roughly half the batter. For a 7-inch Belgian machine%2C scrape in about one-third. Close lid and cook until waffle is golden brown but still steaming%2C 4 1/2 to 6 minutes depending on the depth and heat of your machine. Serve immediately%2C with copious amounts of maple syrup%2C and griddle remaining batter as before.
Add the egg and continue beating until smooth.
Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat to 400%C2%B0F %28200%C2%B0C%29.

Combine butter%2C coconut oil%2C sugar%2C salt%2C baking powder%2C and vanilla in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment. Mix at low speed to combine%2C then increase to medium and beat until soft%2C fluffy%2C and pale%2C about 5 minutes%2C although the exact timing will vary. Halfway through%2C pausing to scrape the bowl and beater with a flexible spatula%2C and then resume mixing on medium speed.
When the oil is hot%2C add the mustard seed. Once the seeds start to pop%2C add the garlic mixture and stir to incorporate. Cook for one minute and then remove from heat.
Toss the roasted squash with the cooked mix and serve with a squeeze of lemon and extra salt to taste.
Heat the coconut oil over medium heat in a saute pan.

Combine the garlic and coconut in a mortar and pestle or a small food processor. Grind until the garlic is completely broken down%3B then%2C remove the chiles from the rehydrating water and add them. Grind until the chiles are mostly broken down.
While the squash cooks%2C rehydrate the arbol chiles in a small mixing bowl with very hot water - this should take about three to five minutes.
Drizzle the squash with the grapeseed oil and season it with salt. Roast for 30-45 minutes%2C turning the pieces halfway through cooking. The squash should be tender and starting to brown.
Wash%2C slice%2C and seed the squash%3B then%2C cut it into half-inch-thick rings and wedges. Arrange the wedges on the sheet pan.
Serve%2C passing extra cilantro%2C sliced onion%2C yogurt%2C and lime%2C along with any pickles or other accompaniments to your liking.
Line a sheet pan with parchment paper and preheat the oven to 400 F.
Add the Garam Masala%2C fenugreek%2C amchur%2C and cilantro. Stir well and cook for two more minutes.
Add the butter%2C paneer%2C and lime juice. Continue to cook for 1 minute%3B then%2C turn off the heat.
Add the chickpeas%2C bring to a simmer%2C and cook for 15 minutes%2C stirring regularly.
Add the ginger and Serranos and stir again to combine%3B then%2C add the dried spice mix reserved before.
Add the water and the cooked potatoes %28crumbling some of the potatoes with your hands as they go in produces a more varied texture%29.
Add the asafoetida and stir well.
In a small bowl%2C mix the ground coriander%2C paprika%2C turmeric%2C black pepper%2C and sea salt. Set aside.
Place a large saucepan on medium heat and add the vegetable oil and cumin seed. Let them crackle for 20 seconds.
Boil the potatoes in salted water until they are tender. Drain and cool them%2C and cut into bite-sized pieces.

Roast uncovered for 45 minutes in the preheated oven. Remove drippings from the baking dish using a turkey baster%2C and place in a saucepan. Whisk in the flour%2C and cook over medium-low heat%2C stirring constantly%2C until thickened. Serve gravy with partridge.

Remove the partridge pieces%2C and wrap each one with two slices of bacon. Secure with toothpicks. Pour enough of the drippings from the skillet into a baking dish to cover the bottom. Place the partridge pieces into the dish along with the chicken broth%2C white wine%2C shallots%2C garlic%2C salt and black pepper.
Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Place the slices of bacon in the skillet and fry until they have released their juices%2C but are not crispy. Remove the bacon and set aside.
Place the partridge breast halves into the pan%2C and brown them quickly%2C about 2 minutes per side.
Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F %28165 degrees C%29.
Stir in butter until melted. Remove from heat. Discard thyme sprigs.
Spoon sauce onto serving plates%2C arrange quail on top%2C and serve. You can garnish with minced parsley%2C if desired.
Add honey to sauce%2C stirring to combine%3B taste%2C then add more honey as desired to balance the tartness of the plums %28this will depend on the plums you have%29.

Add water or stock to pan%2C bring to a simmer%2C then cook until liquid has reduced and plums have broken down to form a thick sauce. Add any juices that have collected below quail. Season with salt.
Add shallot and thyme to skillet and cook%2C stirring%2C until shallot is softened%2C about 3 minutes.
Add plums and cook%2C stirring%2C until starting to look pulpy%2C about 4 minutes.
Transfer quail to a plate or wire rack set over a rimmed baking sheet to rest.
Season quail all over with salt.

In a large cast iron skillet%2C heat oil over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add quail. If quail are spatchcocked%2C cook them skin side down until well browned%2C about 5 minutes%2C then flip and cook other side until desired doneness is reached %28quail can be served from medium-rare to well done%2C as desired%3B they are too small to accurately use a thermometer%2C so feel free to cut into the meat to check doneness%29. If using deboned quail%2C cook on both sides%2C turning frequently%2C until browned on both sides and desired doneness is reached%2C about 4 minutes per side for medium.
Stir in butter until melted. Remove from heat. Discard thyme sprigs.
Spoon sauce onto serving plates%2C arrange quail on top%2C and serve. You can garnish with minced parsley%2C if desired.
Add honey to sauce%2C stirring to combine%3B taste%2C then add more honey as desired to balance the tartness of the plums %28this will depend on the plums you have%29.
Add plums and cook%2C stirring%2C until starting to look pulpy%2C about 4 minutes.

Add water or stock to pan%2C bring to a simmer%2C then cook until liquid has reduced and plums have broken down to form a thick sauce. Add any juices that have collected below quail. Season with salt.
Add shallot and thyme to skillet and cook%2C stirring%2C until shallot is softened%2C about 3 minutes.
Transfer quail to a plate or wire rack set over a rimmed baking sheet to rest.
Season quail all over with salt.

In a large cast iron skillet%2C heat oil over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add quail. If quail are spatchcocked%2C cook them skin side down until well browned%2C about 5 minutes%2C then flip and cook other side until desired doneness is reached %28quail can be served from medium-rare to well done%2C as desired%3B they are too small to accurately use a thermometer%2C so feel free to cut into the meat to check doneness%29. If using deboned quail%2C cook on both sides%2C turning frequently%2C until browned on both sides and desired doneness is reached%2C about 4 minutes per side for medium.

Remove foil and continue to cook%2C flipping and basting potatoes occasionally%2C until they are very soft and glazed in a rich brown syrup%2C about 30 minutes longer. Let cool slightly%2C then serve.

Cover baking dish with aluminum foil and place in a cold oven. Turn on oven to 250%C2%B0F %28120%C2%B0C%29 and allow it to come up to temperature. Cook%2C stopping to flip and baste potatoes with syrup every 20 minutes%2C until tender throughout%2C about 1 hour 15 minutes. %28Exact cooking time will depend on your oven%2C baking dish%2C and the size of your potatoes%2C so check frequently.%29
Stir in cider vinegar%2C cinnamon%2C allspice%2C and ginger%2C then pour syrup all over potatoes%2C spooning it over them as necessary to wet them completely.
In a small saucepan%2C combine brown sugar%2C butter%2C water%2C and salt and bring to a boil%2C stirring often%2C until syrup registers 230 F on an instant-read thermometer.
Stir in vinegar. Cook briefly%2C stirring to distribute the vinegar%2C and serve immediately.

Slice the sweet potatoes crosswise into half-inch-thick rounds. In a 9- by 13-inch baking dish%2C arrange sweet potato rounds in an even layer%2C overlapping where necessary to fit them all. Set aside.
Add cherries and water%3B cook%2C covered%2C until Brussels sprouts are crisp-tender%2C 1-2 minutes.
Stir in walnuts%3B cook and stir until water is evaporated.
In a glass measuring cup%2C measure buttermilk then add baking soda%2C mix together and let sit.
Add sugar to butter and use a spatula or wooden spoon to mix into butter. Add eggs. Add buttermilk/baking soda to the butter/sugar/egg mixture and mix just until combined.
In a separate bowl%2C whisk together cornmeal%2C gluten-free flour%2C xanthan and salt. Add to wet ingredients and stir. Pour into greased 13x9-inch pan.

Bake at 375 F for 30-35 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in center comes out with crumbs only and top of cornbread doesn%27t sink in if pressed with fingertip. Let cool at least 5 minutes or longer%2C until desired temperature for serving.
Whisk the cream mixture until stiff peaks form. Transfer to a pastry bag and pipe decoratively around the surface of the tart.
Remove the tart from the tart pan%2C slice into wedges%2C and serve with additional whipped cream.
In a large skillet%2C heat oil over medium heat. Place Brussels sprouts in pan%2C cut side down%3B cook 4-5 minutes or until bottoms are browned.
Transfer 2 tbsp puree to a medium bowl along with the cream and sugar. Cover and refrigerate.
Transfer the remaining puree to the prepared crust %28which may still be warm%29 and smooth into an even layer. Rest at room temperature for 4 hours.

Add butter to berry puree and process until fully combined%2C about 30 seconds. Strain the mixture through a fine mesh strainer set over a bowl%2C and press down with a spatula to extract all the liquid.
While the berries cook%2C whisk yolks and cornstarch in a bowl until smooth.

Transfer the hot cranberries to a food processor. Add the yolk mixture and process until smooth%2C about 1 minute. Scrape down the bowl sides as needed. Let the mixture cool in the carafe of the food processor until it has formed a skin and registers about 125 degrees F.
For the crust%3A Preheat the oven to 350 F with a rack in the middle position.
Whisk almond flour%2C cornstarch%2C sugar%2C and salt in a bowl until well combined.
Add the melted butter and almond extract and stir with a wooden spoon until a uniform dough emerges.

Crumble 2%2F3 of the dough on the bottom of a 9-inch tart pan with a removable bottom. Press the dough into an evening thickness on the bottom of the pan. Sprinkle the remaining dough around the edges of the pan and press it into the corners and wall of the tart pan. Place the pan on a baking sheet and and bake for 20 minutes or until the curst is golden brown. Rotate the pan halfway through baking.

For the filling%3A bring cranberries%2C sugar%2C and water%2C and salt to a boil in a medium saucepan over medium high heat%2C stirring occasionally. Adjust the heat as necessary to maintain a gentle simmer. Cover and cook until all the berries have burst and are starting to shrivel%2C about 10 minutes.

Remove the pan from the heat and continue to stir until it has almost cooled. Whip the heavy cream lightly and fold it into the custard. Add the ground cardamom. Cool completely in the fridge and then freeze in an ice cream maker following the manufacturer%27s instructions.
Steep saffron threads in 2 tablespoons of the cream mixture. Once saffron has diffused and liquid has cooled%2C add it back to the other ingredients.
Chill a highball glass in the freezer until it is frosty.
Add the salt to a shallow bowl or plate. Rub half a cut lime on the lip of the glass and then rub the glass on the salted dish to apply salt. Add ice to the glass.
Add all of the liquid ingredients except the soda to the glass and gently stir to incorporate.
Add the grapefruit soda and serve.

Put the half and half%2C vanilla bean pods and contents%2C and cardamom pods into a heavy pan and bring slowly to a boil. Remove from heat%2C cover%2C and let infuse for 20 minutes. Remove the cardamom pods.

Beat the egg yolks and sugar until thick and pale. Gently reheat the half and half and beat a little of it into the egg yolks. Pour the egg mixture into the cream and return the pan to a low heat. Stir until the custard is thick enough to coat the back of a spoon%3B it should read about 170 degrees F. Do not let it boil%2C or you%27ll get pieces of scrambled egg.

Whisk  water%2C salt%2C and sugar together in large bowl until sugar and salt dissolve. Add chicken%2C cover%2C and refrigerate for 1 hour. Remove chicken from brine and pat dry with paper towels. Set wire rack in rimmed baking sheet and line plate with triple layer of paper towels.

Place 1/2 cup cornstarch in large zipper-lock bag. Beat egg%2C baking powder%2C and baking soda together in medium bowl%3B stir in buttermilk %28mixture will bubble and foam%29. Whisk remaining 1/2 cup cornstarch%2C cornmeal%2C garlic%2C paprika%2C cayenne%2C and 1 teaspoon salt together in shallow dish.

Working with half of chicken at a time%2C place chicken in bag of cornstarch%2C seal bag%2C and shake bag to coat chicken. Using tongs%2C remove chicken pieces from bag%2C shaking off excess cornstarch%2C dip in buttermilk mixture%2C then coat with cornmeal mixture%2C pressing gently to adhere. Place dredged chicken on prepared wire rack%2C skin side up. Cover loosely with plastic wrap and let sit 30 minutes.

Meanwhile%2C add oil to large Dutch oven until it measures about 2 inches deep%2C and heat over medium-high heat to 350 degrees. Adjust oven rack to middle position and heat oven to 200 degrees. Carefully place half of chicken in pot%2C skin side down%2C cover%2C and fry%2C stirring occasionally to prevent pieces from sticking together%2C until deep golden brown%2C 7 to 11 minutes. Adjust burner%2C if necessary%2C to maintain oil temperature between 300 and 325 degrees. %28After 4 minutes%2C check chicken pieces for even browning and rearrange if some pieces are browning faster than others.%29 Turn chicken pieces over and continue to cook until breast pieces register 160 degrees and drumsticks and/or thighs register 175 degrees%2C 6 to 8 minutes. %28Smaller pieces may cook faster than larger pieces. Remove pieces from pot as they reach correct temperature.%29 Drain chicken briefly on paper towel%u2013lined plate%2C then transfer to clean wire rack set in rimmed baking sheet and keep warm in oven.
Return oil to 350 degrees and repeat with remaining chicken. Serve.
Chill an Old Fashioned glass or small tumbler in your freezer.
In a mixing glass%2C combine sugar%2C bitters%2C and water. Mix until sugar is dissolved%2C and add rye. Add plenty of ice%2C and stir for about 30 seconds.

Pour pastis into your chilled glass%2C and rotate glass until the inside is well coated%3B discard the excess. Strain the liquid from your mixing glass into the serving glass. Twist a piece of lemon peel over the drink. Serve.

Add a fried egg to it: Heat a small skillet over medium-high heat and swirl in one to two teaspoons bacon fat or butter. Crack one egg into the skillet and reduce heat to medium. I like to cover the skillet with a small lid at this point, as it seems to help the egg cook faster and more evenly. In one minute, you should have a perfect sunny-side-up egg. Season with salt and pepper, serve on top of a pile of bacon corn hash.

Bump up the heat a little and add the corn to the skillet. Saute the potatoes and corn together until the corn gets a bit brown but stays fairly crisp, about 4 to 5 minutes. Add the drained bacon, and stir the mixture together until its evenly warm, about 1 more minute. Remove the skillet from the burner and sprinkle the scallions (reserving a couple spoonfuls if youd like to use them as fried egg garnish) over the hash. In two minutes, they should be warm and mellowed. Season with more salt or pepper to taste, if needed.

Heat the pan to medium/medium-high, making sure the bacon fat is nicely sizzly, then add your potatoes all at once in a single layer. Sprinkle them with 1/2 teaspoon table salt and several grinds of black pepper. Let them cook for a few minutes in one place and get a bit golden underneath before turning them over and moving them around. Repeat this process until the potatoes are browned on all sides; this takes about 20 minutes. Pour off any excess fat at this point.

Toss bacon into a large skillet over medium heat, no need to heat the pan first. Let rest for a few minutes until it starts sizzling, then move the bits around so that they begin to brown evenly. Again, wait a couple minutes before shuffling the pieces around; youre looking for them to get evenly golden and crisp. This should take about 10 minutes. Remove the bacon bits with a slotted spoon, leaving the drippings in the pan and transferring the bacon to paper towels to drain.

Bake the bread for 30 to 35 minutes%2C until it%27s light golden brown. Test it for doneness by removing it from the pan and thumping it on the bottom %28it should sound hollow%29%2C or by measuring its interior temperature with a digital thermometer %28it should register 190%C2%B0F at the center of the loaf%29.
Remove the bread from the oven%2C and cool it on a rack before slicing. Store the bread in a plastic bag at room temperature for several days%3B freeze for longer storage.
Gently deflate the dough and transfer it to a lightly oiled work surface. Shape the dough into an 8%22 log.

Place the log in a lightly greased 8 1%2F2%22 x 4 1%2F2%22 loaf pan%2C cover the pan loosely with lightly greased plastic wrap%2C and allow the bread to rise for about 60 minutes%2C until it%27s domed about 1%22 above the edge of the pan. A finger pressed into the dough should leave a mark that rebounds slowly. Towards the end of the rise%2C preheat your oven to 350%C2%B0F.

Transfer the dough to a lightly greased bowl%2C cover the bowl%2C and allow the dough to rise until puffy though not necessarily doubled in bulk%2C about 1 to 2 hours%2C depending on the warmth of your kitchen. If you%27re using a bread machine%2C allow the machine to complete its cycle%2C then leave the dough in the machine until it%27s doubled in bulk%2C perhaps an additional 30 minutes or so.

To make the dough%3A In a large bowl%2C combine all of the ingredients and stir until the dough starts to leave the sides of the bowl. Transfer the dough to a lightly greased surface%2C oil your hands%2C and knead it for 6 to 8 minutes%2C or until it begins to become smooth and supple. Or mix and knead the dough using an electric mixer or food processor%2C or in a bread machine set to the dough or manual cycle.

Make finishing oil: Heat 2 to 3 tablespoons olive oil in a small sauce- or frying pan over medium-low heat with remaining clove of garlic, rosemary, a pinch or two of salt and pepper flakes, until sizzling; pull it off the heat as soon as the garlic is going to start taking on color. Drizzle this over bowls of pasta e ceci and eat it right away.

In a medium-large heavy-bottomed pot or deep saute pan, heat 2 tablespoons olive oil until it shimmers. Add 2 smashed cloves of garlic and cook, stirring until it becomes lightly, barely browned but very fragrant. Stir in the tomato paste, salt, and pepper and cook them with the garlic for 30 seconds or so. Add the chickpeas, pasta, and boiling water. Stir to scrape up any browned bits on the bottom of the pot, lower the heat, and simmer until the pasta is cooked and a lot of the liquid has been absorbed, about 15 to 20 minutes. Taste and adjust seasoning and ladle into bowls.

When all chicken pieces are browned%2C add raisins and blended almond and garlic. Cook%2C stirring frequently%2C until it forms a fragrant paste%2C about one minute. Return chicken and onions to dutch oven%2C and add yogurt. Stir well%2C and reduce heat to low. Cover dutch oven and cook until chicken is cooked through and tender%2C 25 to 30 minutes. Serve with a sprinkling of chopped cilantro.

Add cardamom%2C cinnamon%2C and bay leaves to dutch oven%2C and stir constantly until fragrant%2C about 30 seconds. Add as many chicken pieces as will fit in one layer%2C and brown lightly on both sides%2C about two minutes on each side. Transfer browned chicken pieces to a plate and set aside.
Place ginger%2C garlic and %C2%BC water in blender. Process until smooth.
Add almonds%2C two more tablespoons of water%2C and process until smooth.
Whisk together yogurt%2C garam masala%2C coriander%2C cayenne%2C and a pinch of salt in medium-sized bowl.

Pour oil into large dutch oven set over medium heat. Add onions and cook until they are well browned%2C stirring often%2C about ten minutes. Remove onions with slotted spoon%2C trying to leave as much oil in dutch oven as possible. Set onions aside.

Add dried chiles to large heavy-bottomed Dutch oven or stock pot and cook over medium-high heat, stirring frequently, until slightly darkened with intense, roasted aroma, 2 to 5 minutes. Do not allow to smoke. Remove chiles to small bowl and set aside. Alternatively, place dried chilies on a microwave-safe plate and microwave on high power in 15-second increments until pliable and toasted-smelling, about 30 seconds total. Transfer to a 2-quart microwave-safe liquid measuring cup or bowl. Add water and chipotle chilies, cover with plastic wrap, and microwave on high power until gently simmering, about 5 minutes. Remove from microwave and set aside. Transfer chilies and liquid to blender and blend, starting on the lowest possible setting and gradually increasing speed to high (make sure to hold the lid down with a clean kitchen towel or a potholder to prevent it from blowing out). Blend until smooth, about 1 minute.
Drain chickpeas, reserving liquid from can. Transfer chickpeas to a food processor and pulse until just roughly chopped, about three 1-second pulses. Set aside.
Roughly squeeze tomatoes through your fingers into approximate 1/4-inch pieces. Add to chickpea water along with any juices.

Heat oil in a large saucepan or Dutch oven over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add onions and cook, stirring frequently, until softened but not browned, about 4 minutes. Add garlic, cumin, and dried oregano and cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add pureed chilies, soy sauce, and marmite and cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add reserved chickpea/tomato water mixture and stir to combine. Add chopped chickpeas and kidney beans. Stir to combine.

If beans are sticking out of the top, add reserved kidney bean liquid until just barely submerged. Bring to a boil over high heat, reduce to a bare simmer, and cook, stirring occasionally, until thick and rich, about 1 1/2 hours, adding more reserved kidney bean liquid as necessary if chili becomes too thick or sticks to the bottom of the pan.

When cooked, add vodka or bourbon and stir to combine. Season to taste with salt and whisk in masa in a slow steady stream until desired thickness is reached. For best results, allow chili to cool and refrigerate for at least one night and up to a week. Reheat to serve.
Serve, garnished with cilantro, chopped onions, scallions, avocado, lime wedges, and warm tortillas as desired.

Remove orange and onion halves. Increase heat to medium and simmer%2C stirring frequently%2C until reduced to a thick%2C creamy sauce that clings to the beans%2C about 10 minutes. Season to taste with salt. Serve over rice or as a side with fresh cilantro and a dash or two of hot sauce.
Pour oil into large dutch oven. Turn heat to medium and add onions, bell peppers, jalapenos, and pinch of salt. Cook, stirring often, until onions are soft but not brown, about 5 minutes.

Add whole can tomatoes with their juice, beer, beans, white wine vinegar, garlic, coriander, cumin, and chipotle chilies in adobo. Turn heat to high and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to medium-low, and let simmer for 30 minutes. Stir every 5 minutes or so. Using wooden spoon, break up tomatoes into small chunks. Season with salt to taste.
Ladle chili into bowls and garnish with scallions and sour cream.
Season with additional lemon juice%2C salt%2C and pepper to taste and serve immediately.

Place beans in a large pot or dutch oven and add water until beans are submerged by 3 to 4 inches. Add the garlic and onion%2C squeeze in orange juice%2C then add the squeezed orange halves. Cover and place over high heat until water comes to a boil%2C then uncover pot and reduce heat to a bare simmer. Cook until beans are completely tender and creamy%2C 1 to 2 hours%2C stirring occasionally%2C and adding water if tops of beans become exposed.
Add the lemon zest to the pan and saut%C3%A9 for 30 seconds.
Add the chard leaves and the lemon juice. Saut%C3%A9 for about 2 minutes or until the leaves are wilted.
Add the chard leaves and the lemon juice. Saut%C3%A9 for about 2 minutes or until the leaves are wilted.
Season with additional lemon juice%2C salt%2C and pepper to taste and serve immediately.
Strip the leaves from the stalks of the chard%2C and thinly slice the stalks.
Melt the butter in a large saucepan on medium heat until foaming. Add the sliced stalks and minced garlic and simmer for 1-2 minutes or until very fragrant.
Melt the butter in a large saucepan on medium heat until foaming. Add the sliced stalks and minced garlic and simmer for 1-2 minutes or until very fragrant.
Add the lemon zest to the pan and saut%C3%A9 for 30 seconds.
Season with additional lemon juice%2C salt%2C and pepper to taste and serve immediately.
Strip the leaves from the stalks of the chard%2C and thinly slice the stalks.
Strip the leaves from the stalks of the chard%2C and thinly slice the stalks.
Melt the butter in a large saucepan on medium heat until foaming. Add the sliced stalks and minced garlic and simmer for 1-2 minutes or until very fragrant.
Add the lemon zest to the pan and saut%C3%A9 for 30 seconds.
Add the chard leaves and the lemon juice. Saut%C3%A9 for about 2 minutes or until the leaves are wilted.
Add lemon juice to taste%2C starting with 1 tablespoon %2815ml%29%2C then adding more until desired tartness is reached. Season with salt and pepper.
Serve spaghetti right away%2C topping each serving with additional grated lemon zest and cheese.
Add grated cheese and toss and stir rapidly until sauce thickens%3B if it becomes too tight and dry at any time%2C add more pasta-cooking water to loosen it sufficiently.
Lower heat to low%2C add lemon zest and garlic%2C and cook%2C stirring%2C until fragrant%2C 1 to 2 minutes.
Meanwhile%2C in a medium pot of boiling salted water%2C cook pasta until just shy of al dente. Reserve about 1 cup %28240ml%29 of the starchy pasta water%2C then drain pasta.

Add pasta to butter mixture%2C along with 1%2F2 cup %28120ml%29 reserved pasta water. Increase heat to medium-high and cook%2C stirring and tossing to coat%2C until pasta is glazed in a satiny%2C emulsified sauce.
Twist a piece of lemon peel over the drink and use as garnish.
In a large skillet%2C melt butter over medium heat until foaming.

Adjust oven rack to 6 to 8 inches below broiler element and preheat broiler to high. Heat oil in a large cast iron skillet over high heat until shimmering. Reduce heat to medium and wipe out excess oil with a paper towel.

Place tortilla in skillet with the rougher textured-side facing down. Spread sauce evenly over tortilla all the way to the edges. Spread mozzarella and half of Parmesan evenly over tortilla all the way to the edges. Season lightly with salt. Sprinkle with onion and bell pepper. Lay pepperoni and sausage chunks over pizza. Scatter with basil.

Place skillet under broiler and broil until sausage is cooked through and cheese is melted and starting to brown in spots, 2 to 4 minutes. Remove from oven and sprinkle with remaining Parmesan. Using a small metal spatula, gently pry edges of pizza, releasing the cheese from the skillet. Peek under bottom. If more crispness is desired, place skillet over medium heat and cook, swirling pizza and peeking occasionally, until desired crispness is achieved. Slide pizza out onto a cutting board. Cut and serve immediately.

Adjust oven rack to 6 to 8 inches below broiler element and preheat broiler to high. Heat oil in a large cast iron skillet over high heat until shimmering. Reduce heat to medium-low and wipe out excess oil with a paper towel.

Place tortilla in skillet with the rougher textured-side facing down. Spread sauce evenly over tortilla all the way to the edges. Spread mozzarella and half of Parmesan evenly over tortilla all the way to the edges. Season lightly with salt. Scatter with basil and drizzle with olive oil.

Place skillet under broiler and broil until cheese is melted and starting to brown in spots, 2 to 4 minutes. Remove from oven and sprinkle with remaining Parmesan. Using a small metal spatula, gently pry edges of pizza, releasing the cheese from the skillet. Peek under bottom. If more crispness is desired, place skillet over medium heat and cook, swirling pizza and peeking occasionally, until desired crispness is achieved. Slide pizza out onto a cutting board. Cut and serve immediately.
Combine the pineapple and olive oil in a large dutch oven and bring to a simmer over high heat. Cook for 5 minutes or until the pineapple is beginning to brown.
Add the jalapeos, garlic, and shallot and bring to a simmer. Cook for 1-2 minutes or until starting to soften.
Add the rice and toast for 1 minute.
Add the mushroom stock and bring to a simmer. Cover and cook for 20 minutes or until the rice is cooked.
Add the peanuts%2C salt%2C pepper%2C and vinegar to taste. Serve.

Using spider or slotted spoon%2C scoop gnocchi directly into skillet with sage butter%2C allowing some of the water clinging to them to come along. Cook gnocchi in sage butter over medium-high heat%2C tossing very gently and adding a splash of cooking water as needed if sauce becomes greasy or breaks%2C until gnocchi are coated in a rich%2C creamy sauce%2C about 1 minute.
Carefully spoon gnocchi into serving dishes and top with grated Parmesan cheese. Salt and pepper to taste%3B serve right away.
Combine vodka and orange juice in a highball glass and stir to combine. Add ice and serve immediately.
Combine ingredients in a mixing glass and fill with ice. Stir well for 20 seconds%3B strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

Using a bench scraper or slotted spatula to scoop them up%2C transfer gnocchi to boiling water. Stir once very gently with a spider or slotted spoon to prevent sticking. When gnocchi begin to float to the surface%2C wait about 20 seconds%2C then taste one%3B it should be soft yet cooked through%2C without any raw-flour flavor.
Using bench scraper%2C cut snake into 1-inch portions%2C trimming off uneven ends as necessary. Transfer gnocchi to a well-floured area or baking sheet and repeat with remaining dough.
Bring a large pot of very well-salted water to a boil.
Melt butter in a large skillet over medium-high heat until it foams. Add sage and fry until very aromatic and butter begins to lightly brown%3B remove from heat.
Dust potato dough all over with flour and gently form into a log.

Clean work area well and dust with fresh flour. Using bench scraper%2C slice off a roughly 2-inch-thick portion of dough and roll into a snake about 1%2F2 inch thick%3B use a light touch as you roll%2C trying to use your palms more than your fingers%2C and dusting as necessary with flour to prevent sticking.

Scoop remaining 1%2F4 cup flour into sieve and dust all over potato dough. Continue to gently fold and press%2C just until a uniform dough comes together. %28Make sure to simply fold and press down%3B avoid the smearing motion more commonly used when kneading bread.%29
Serve immediately with lemon wedges.

Using a spoon%2C scoop potato flesh into a ricer or food mill fitted with the finest disk. Press potato flesh onto a clean work surface%2C spreading it into an even layer%2C and allow steam to escape for a few minutes.
Drizzle egg yolks all over%2C if using.
Scoop 1%2F2 cup flour into a fine-mesh sieve and tap to dust flour all over potatoes. Using a pastry blender or bench scraper%2C chop down repeatedly all over to cut flour and egg into potato.
Using a bench scraper%2C gather up shaggy potato mass and pat into a loose ball. Press ball flat with hands%2C then fold in half using bench scraper and press down again.

Add 2 cups oil to large Dutch oven and heat over medium-high heat to 350 degrees. Lay 2 or 3 cutlets %28depending on size%29 in oil%2C without overlapping them%2C and cook%2C shaking pot continuously and gently%2C until cutlets are wrinkled and light golden brown on both sides%2C 1 to 1%C2%BD minutes per side. Transfer cutlets to paper towel%E2%80%93lined sheet%2C flip to blot excess oil%2C and transfer sheet to oven to keep warm. Repeat with remaining cutlets.
Halve chicken breasts horizontally to form 8 cutlets of even thickness. Place 1 cutlet between 2 sheets of plastic wrap and pound to %C2%BC-inch thickness. Repeat with remaining cutlets.
Sprinkle each cutlet on both sides with salt and pepper.

Working with 1 cutlet at a time%2C dredge cutlets thoroughly in flour%2C shaking off excess%2C then coat with egg mixture%2C allowing excess to drip back into dish to ensure very thin coating. Coat evenly with bread crumbs%2C pressing on crumbs to adhere. Place cutlets on prepared wire rack%2C taking care not to overlap cutlets. Let coating dry for 5 minutes.
Mic bread crumbs with salt and pepper%3B place bread crumbs in third shallow dish.
Set wire rack in rimmed baking sheet. Line second rimmed baking sheet with double layer of paper towels. Adjust oven rack to middle position and heat oven to 200 degrees.

In a large bowl%2C toss both cheeses together along with mustard powder. Using an immersion blender or working in batches with a countertop blender%2C blend soup%2C adding cheese a handful at a time%2C until completely smooth.

Stir in hot sauce and season to taste with salt and pepper. Stir in reserved broccoli florets and pulse with blender a few more times until a few pieces are broken down%2C but most bite-size pieces remain. Serve immediately.
Preheat oven to 450%C2%B0F %28232%C2%B0C%29. Set potatoes directly on the oven%27s racks. Bake until completely tender throughout when pierced with a fork%2C about 45 minutes.
Spread flour in shallow dish.
Beat eggs and oil in second shallow dish.

Return Dutch oven to medium heat and add butter%2C onion%2C carrot%2C and broccoli stems. Season with salt and pepper and cook%2C stirring frequently%2C until tender but not browned%2C about 5 minutes%2C lowering heat if necessary.
Transfer potatoes to a work surface. Using tongs to hold hot potatoes%2C slice each in half lengthwise.

Add water or chicken stock%2C milk%2C and potato and bring to a boil over high heat. Reduce to a bare simmer and cook%2C stirring occasionally%2C until broccoli and potato are completely tender%2C about 30 minutes.
Add garlic and cook%2C stirring%2C until fragrant%2C about 30 seconds.

To serve%2C cut each crumpet into 4 wedges and toast until crumpets are heated through and exteriors are crisp. Spread crumpets generously with butter and jam or honey and serve. %28Untoasted crumpets can be transferred to zipper-lock bag and refrigerated for up to 1 week or frozen for up to 1 month.%29

Slide skillet off heat. Place dry%2C flat spatula on top of crumpet and pull up sharply to remove excess batter and reveal holes. Scrape excess batter from spatula back into measuring cup. Repeat procedure until holes are exposed over entire surface. Flip crumpet%2C return skillet to burner%2C increase heat to high%2C and cook until edges of second side are lightly browned%2C 1 to 2 minutes. Invert crumpet onto wire rack. Immediately add half of remaining batter to skillet. Return skillet to high heat and repeat cooking process %28omitting 5-minute preheat%29. Repeat with remaining batter. Let crumpets cool completely.

Increase heat to medium and heat skillet for 1 minute. Using paper towel%2C wipe out skillet%2C leaving thin film of oil on bottom and sides. Pour one-third of batter into skillet and increase heat to high. Cook for 45 seconds %28bubbles will be visible just under surface of entire crumpet%29. Reduce heat to medium-low and continue to cook until edges are risen%2C set%2C and beginning to dry out%2C about 4 minutes longer. %28Gently lift edge and peek at underside of crumpet occasionally%3B reduce heat if underside is getting too dark%2C and increase heat if underside doesn%27t appear to be browning.%29
Add 1%C2%BC cups warm water and whisk until smooth. Cover and let rise in warm place until doubled in volume%2C about 40 minutes.
Heat oil in 8-inch nonstick skillet over low heat for at least 5 minutes. While skillet heats%2C add remaining %C2%BC cup warm water to batter and whisk until smooth.
Mix masa harina and salt together in medium bowl.
Add boiling water and oil and mix with rubber spatula until soft dough forms. Cover dough and let rest for 20 minutes.
While dough rests%2C line rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper. Process cotija cheese in food processor until cotija is finely chopped and resembles wet sand%2C about 20 seconds.
Add Monterey Jack cheese and process until mixture resembles wet oatmeal%2C about 30 seconds %28it will not form cohesive mass%29. Remove processor blade.
Form cheese mixture into 8 balls%2C weighing about 1%C2%BC ounces each%2C and place balls on 1 half of prepared sheet.

Knead dough in bowl for 15 to 20 seconds. Test dough%27s hydration by flattening golf ball%E2%80%93size piece. If cracks larger than %C2%BC inch form around edges%2C add warm tap water%2C 2 teaspoons at a time%2C until dough is soft and slightly tacky.

Transfer dough to counter%2C shape into large ball%2C and divide into 8 equal pieces. Using your damp hands%2C roll 1 dough piece into ball and place on empty half of prepared sheet. Cover with damp dish towel. Repeat with remaining dough pieces.

Place open cut bag marked side down on counter. Place 1 dough ball in center of circle. Fold other side of bag over ball. Using glass pie plate or 8-inch square baking dish%2C gently press dough to 4-inch diameter%2C using circle drawn on bag as guide. Turn out disk into your palm and place 1 cheese ball in center. Bring sides of dough up around filling and pinch top to seal. Remoisten your hands and roll ball until smooth%2C smoothing any cracks with your damp fingertip. Return ball to bag and slowly press to 4-inch diameter. Pinch closed any small cracks that form at edges. Return pupusa to sheet and cover with damp dish towel. Repeat with remaining dough and filling.

Heat oil in 12-inch nonstick skillet over medium-high heat until shimmering. Wipe skillet clean with paper towels. Carefully lay 4 pupusas in skillet and cook until spotty brown on both sides%2C 2 to 4 minutes per side. Transfer to platter and repeat with remaining 4 pupusas. Serve warm with salsa and curtido.

To Make Ahead%3A At end of step 5%2C wrap baking sheet in plastic wrap and freeze until pupusas are solid. Wrap pupusas individually in plastic%2C then transfer pupusas to zipper-lock bag. Freeze for up to 1 month. Cook directly from frozen%2C increasing cooking time by 1 minute per side.
Pulse onion%2C cilantro%2C and jalape%C3%B1o in food processor until finely chopped%2C 5 pulses%2C scraping down sides of bowl as needed.
Add tomatoes%2C lime juice%2C garlic%2C salt%2C and pepper and process until smooth%2C 20 to 30 seconds.
Season with salt and extra lime juice to taste.
Whisk vinegar%2C water%2C sugar%2C and salt in large bowl until sugar is dissolved.
Add cabbage%2C onion%2C carrot%2C jalape%C3%B1o%2C and oregano and toss to combine.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 1 hour or up to 24 hours.
Toss slaw%2C then drain.
Return slaw to bowl and stir in cilantro. Serve.
Adjust oven rack to middle position and heat oven to 375 degrees. Generously spray 24-cup mini-muffin tin with baking spray.

Melt butter in 10-inch skillet over medium-high heat. Cook%2C stirring and scraping skillet constantly with rubber spatula%2C until milk solids are dark golden brown and butter has nutty aroma%2C 1 to 3 minutes. Immediately transfer butter to heatproof bowl.

Whisk almond flour%2C sugar%2C all-purpose flour%2C and salt together in second bowl. Add egg whites. Using rubber spatula%2C stir until combined%2C mashing any lumps against side of bowl until mixture is smooth.
Stir in butter until incorporated. Distribute batter evenly among prepared muffin cups %28cups will be about half full%29.
Place 1 chocolate chunk on top of each cake %28do not press into batter%29.

Bake until edges are well browned and tops are golden%2C about 14 minutes%2C rotating muffin tin halfway through baking. Remove tin from oven and immediately invert wire rack on top of tin. Invert rack and tin%3B and carefully remove tin. Turn cakes right side up and let cool for at least 20 minutes before serving.
Adjust oven rack to middle position and heat oven to 375 degrees. Generously spray 24-cup mini-muffin tin with baking spray.

Melt butter in 10-inch skillet over medium-high heat. Cook%2C stirring and scraping skillet constantly with rubber spatula%2C until milk solids are dark golden brown and butter has nutty aroma%2C 1 to 3 minutes. Immediately transfer butter to heatproof bowl.

Whisk almond flour%2C sugar%2C all-purpose flour%2C and salt together in second bowl. Add egg whites. Using rubber spatula%2C stir until combined%2C mashing any lumps against side of bowl until mixture is smooth. Stir in butter until incorporated. Distribute batter evenly among prepared muffin cups %28cups will be about half full%29.
Place 1 raspberry on its side on top of each cake %28do not press into batter%29.

Bake until edges are well browned and tops are golden%2C about 14 minutes%2C rotating muffin tin halfway through baking. Remove tin from oven and immediately invert wire rack on top of tin. Invert rack and tin%3B carefully remove tin. Turn cakes right side up and let cool for at least 20 minutes before serving.
Adjust oven rack to middle position and heat oven to 375 degrees. Generously spray 24-cup mini-muffin tin with baking spray with flour.
Process pistachios and all purpose flour in food processor until finely ground%2C about 1 minute%2C scraping down sides of bowl twice during processing.

Melt butter in 10-inch skillet over medium-high heat. Cook%2C stirring and scraping skillet constantly with rubber spatula%2C until milk solids are dark golden brown and butter has nutty aroma%2C 1 to 3 minutes. Immediately transfer butter to heatproof bowl.

Whisk pistachio mixture%2C sugar%2C and salt together in second bowl. Add egg whites. Using rubber spatula%2C stir until combined%2C mashing any lumps against side of bowl until mixture is smooth. Stir in butter until incorporated. Distribute batter evenly among prepared muffin cups %28cups will be about half full%29.

Bake until edges are well browned and tops are golden%2C about 14 minutes%2C rotating muffin tin halfway through baking. Remove tin from oven and immediately invert wire rack on top of tin. Invert rack and tin%3B carefully remove tin. Turn cakes right side up and let cool for at least 20 minutes before serving.
Whisk all-purpose flour%2C cake flour%2C yeast%2C baking powder%2C and salt together in 8-cup liquid measuring cup.
Using marker%2C draw 4-inch circle in center of 1 side of 1-quart or 1-gallon zipper-lock bag. Cut open seams along both sides of bag%2C but leave bottom seam intact so bag opens completely.
Separate broccoli into florets and stems. Cut florets into bite-size pieces and set aside. Roughly chop stems and reserve separately.

Heat oil in a large Dutch oven over high heat until shimmering. Add broccoli florets and cook%2C without moving%2C until charred on the bottom%2C about 1 minute. Stir%2C season with salt and pepper%2C and continue cooking%2C stirring occasionally%2C until tender and charred on several surfaces%2C about 1 minute longer. Transfer to a rimmed baking sheet to cool.

The sauce should be thick enough to coat the back of a spoon and leave a trail when you drag your finger through it. If it%27s still a little thin%2C whisk the cornstarch together with the water%2C add the slurry%2C and bring to a simmer until thickened slightly.
Season sauce with salt and pepper to taste. Return short ribs to Dutch oven%2C spooning the sauce all over and around them to glaze and rewarm. Serve.

Skim accumulated fat from surface of braising liquid and discard. Strain braising liquid through a fine-mesh strainer set over a large heatproof bowl%2C pressing on solids to extract as much liquid as possible.

Rinse out Dutch oven%2C then return strained braising liquid to it. Return to heat and bring to a gentle simmer%2C adjusting heat to maintain simmer. Simmer until braising liquid is reduced to 2 cups%2C about 1 hour%3B skim any foam that accumulates on the surface as needed. Add port wine reduction to braising liquids.

Meanwhile%2C in a large saucepan%2C bring ruby port to a very gentle simmer%2C regulating heat to maintain that simmer. Cook%2C uncovered%2C until reduced until syrupy and about 1%2F2 cup %28120ml%29 in volume%2C about 1 hour. Set aside.
Carefully remove short ribs from pot and transfer to a clean platter %28they will be very tender%2C so the bones may slip out%3B try to hold them together as you transfer them%29. Tent with foil.

Return short ribs to pot along with any accumulated juices%2C nestling them into braising liquids. Add thyme and bay leaf%2C cover partially%2C then transfer to oven%2C and cook until beef is fork-tender%2C 2 to 3 hours.

Add dry red wine%2C scraping up any browned bits from bottom and sides of pot. Bring to a simmer. Add stock%3B if using store-bought stock%2C place it in a large bowl first and sprinkle all over with gelatin until bloomed%2C then add to Dutch oven.
Pour off all but 2 tablespoons of fat from the Dutch oven. Return to the heat and add celery%2C carrot%2C onion%2C and garlic. Cook%2C stirring%2C until browned%2C about 6 minutes.
Stir in tomato paste and cook for 1 minute longer%3B lower heat at any point if the contents of the pot threaten to burn.
Gently stir chives%2C lemon zest and juice%2C and butter into risotto. Season with salt and pepper to taste. If desired%2C stir in additional stock to loosen texture of risotto.
Serve%2C passing lemon wedges and extra Parmesan separately.
Add %C2%BE cup stock to risotto and stir gently and constantly until risotto becomes creamy%2C about 3 minutes. Stir in Parmesan and shrimp. Cover pot and let stand off heat for 5 minutes.
Add sugar and salt and bring to boil.
Off heat%2C stir in cream.
Using immersion blender or blender%2C process until smooth%2C 30 to 60 seconds.
Return sauce to simmer over medium heat and whisk in butter. Remove saucepan from heat and cover to keep warm. Sauce can be refrigerated for up to 4 days.

Adjust oven rack 6 inches from broiler element and heat broiler. Combine chicken%2C yogurt%2C and salt in bowl and toss well to coat. Using tongs%2C transfer chicken to wire rack set in aluminum foil%E2%80%94lined rimmed baking sheet.
Broil until chicken is evenly charred on both sides and registers 175 degrees%2C 16 to 20 minutes%2C flipping chicken halfway through broiling.

Let chicken rest for 5 minutes. While chicken rests%2C warm sauce over medium-low heat. Cut chicken into %C2%BE-inch chunks and stir into sauce. Stir in 2 tablespoons cilantro and season with salt to taste. Transfer to serving dish%2C sprinkle with remaining 1 tablespoon cilantro%2C and serve.
Peel and devein the shrimp%2C reserving the shells. Cut each shrimp crosswise into thirds. Toss with salt and set aside.
Heat oil in Dutch oven over high heat until shimmering. Add reserved shrimp shells and cook%2C stirring frequently%2C until shells begin to turn spotty brown%2C 2 to 4 minutes.

Add water%2C peppercorns%2C bay leaf%2C and 1 teaspoon salt and bring to boil. Reduce heat to low and simmer for 5 minutes. Strain stock through fine-mesh strainer set over large bowl%2C pressing on solids with rubber spatula to extract as much liquid as possible%3B discard solids.
Melt butter in now-empty pot over medium heat.

Add onion%2C fennel%2C baking soda%2C and remaining %C2%BC teaspoon salt. Cook%2C stirring frequently%2C until vegetables are softened but not browned%2C 8 to 10 minutes %28volume will be dramatically reduced and onion will have mostly disintegrated%29.
Add garlic and stir until fragrant%2C about 30 seconds.
Add rice and cook%2C stirring frequently%2C until grains are translucent around edges%2C about 3 minutes.
Add wine and cook%2C stirring constantly%2C until fully absorbed%2C 2 to 3 minutes.

Stir 4 cups stock into rice mixture%3B reduce heat to medium-low%2C cover%2C and simmer until almost all liquid has been absorbed and rice is just al dente%2C 16 to 18 minutes%2C stirring twice during simmering.
Add water and tomato paste and whisk until no lumps of tomato paste remain.
Add garam masala%2C coriander%2C cumin%2C and pepper and cook%2C stirring frequently%2C until fragrant%2C about 3 minutes.
Stir to chill%3B then%2C top with the club soda and sparkling wine.
Twist the grapefruit peel over the drink%2C drop it in%2C and serve immediately.
Place rice in fine mesh strainer and rinse under a cold running faucet until the runoff is clear. Place strainer over bowl and set aside.

Melt butter in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Add cumin%2C cardamom%2C and cloves%2C and cook%2C stirring constantly%2C until fragrant%2C about one minute. Take care not to burn the spices%3B nothing smells worse than burnt cloves.
Add water%2C cinnamon stick%2C bay leaf%2C and salt%2C and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to low%2C cover%2C and simmer until all water is absorbed%2C about 17 minutes.
Let stand%2C covered%2C off heat%2C for 10 minutes.
Discard all whole spices and serve immediately.
Melt butter in large saucepan over medium heat.
Add onion%2C garlic%2C ginger%2C and serrano and cook%2C stirring frequently%2C until mixture is softened and onion begins to brown%2C 8 to 10 minutes.
Add the olive and serve.
combine wine%2C vermouth%2C and elderflower and pine liqueurs in a large ice-filled wine glass.
Strain into a chilled highball glass filled with ice. Float the sparkling wine on top.
Garnish with the lemon twist and serve.
Add prosecco%2C aperol%2C and soda water to a tumbler filled with ice and gently stir%2C taking care not to flatten the prosecco too much.
Muddle the grapefruit with the butters in the bottom of a mixing glass.
Fill the glass with ice and bitters%2C syrup%2C lillet blanc%2C and cognac. Shake vigorously until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe%2C garnish with a grapefruit twist%2C and serve.
Season short ribs all over with salt and pepper.

Heat oil in a large Dutch oven over medium-high heat until shimmering. Working in batches%2C add short ribs and brown on all sides%2C about 4 minutes per side. Transfer browned short ribs to a platter and repeat with remaining short ribs.
Preheat oven to 300%C2%B0F %28150%C2%B0C%29.
Toss everything together in a large mixing bowl until well combined.
Add to a large skillet and turn to medium high. Cook for about 5-7 minutes until the shrimp is pink and the vegetables are tender.
Garnish with fresh parsley if desired and serve immediately.
Muddle the fruits in a mixing glass.
Fill the glass with ice and add the bitters%2C rum%2C and campari. Shake vigorously until well chilled.
Top with chilled champagne%2C squeeze the lemon twist over the drink%2C rub it on the rim%2C drop it in%2C and serve immediately.
Combine ice%2C gin%2C lemon juice%2C and syrup in a cocktail shaker. Shake until very well chilled. Strain into a chilled champagne flute.
Top with sparkling wine%2C squeeze lemon twist over glass%2C rub on rim%2C drop it in the liquid%2C and serve immediately.
Strain into a chilled champagne flute%2C top with rose champagne%2C and serve immediately.
Combine ice%2C apple brandy%2C scotch%2C lemon juice%2C and simple syrup. Shake 30 seconds or until well-chilled. Strain into a chilled champagne flute.
Top with additional crushed ice and garnish with remaining strawberry. Serve immediately.
Muddle grapes in a mixing glass.
Add lemon juice%2C syrup%2C and Pisco.
Shake with ice in a cocktail shaker.
Garnish with additional tomato and watercress sprig and serve immediately.
Pour syrup into chilled wine glass.
Gently muddle the lemon and one of the halved strawberries inside.
Fill glass halfway with crushed ice.
Add champagne.
Combine pepper vodka%2C regular vodka%2C celery salt%2C hot sauce%2C and 2 cups of the tomato water. Shake well with ice.
Strain into four chilled martini glasses. Garnish with additional cherry tomatoes and serve immediately.
Muddle the tomatoes and watercress with the lemon juice in the bottom of a cocktail shaker.
Add the remaining ingredients and use and shake well.
Strain through the cocktail strainer and a fine mesh strainer into a chilled martini glass.
Core the tomatoes and cut them into chunks.
Combine tomatoes%2C sea salt%2C and lemongrass in a food processor and puree for about one minute.
Combine sugar and water in a small pot over low heat. Bring to a simmer.
Stir with a rubber spatula for 5 minutes or until the sugar has completely melted. Let cool.

Pass the mixture through a fine mesh strainer with cheesecloth laid inside it. Place the strainer over a bowl and pour the tomato mixture in. Tie the cheesecloth into a pouch and set aside to drip for two hours. Twist the cheesecloth if necessary to extract all juice and set the resulting tomato water aside.
Slice the steak thinly against the grain and transfer to a serving platter.
Serve steak%2C tortillas%2C lime wedges%2C cilantro%2C crema%2C and salsa.
Stem and seed the jalape%C3%B1os %28leave the skins on%29. Reserve their seeds. Chop them finely and transfer them to a bowl. Coarsely chop the scallions and transfer them to the same bowl.
Add lime juice%2C adobo sauce%2C 2 tbsp olive oil%2C and salt. Adjust seasoning %28including jalape%C3%B1o seeds for spice%29 to taste.
Cook the tortillas in two batches of 6%2C charring them on the hot side of the grill for about a minute and then storing them in aluminum foil.
Transfer steak to a clean cutting board and tent with aluminum foil so it can finish cooking. Transfer the jalape%C3%B1os to a medium bowl and cover.

Place scallions on the hot side of the grill and cook until the greens are charred on one side%2C 1-2 minutes. Flip the scallions and arrange them so that the greens are over the cool part of the grill and the whites are over the hot part and cook another 1-2 minutes or until the whites are charred. Transfer to the bowl with the jalape%C3%B1os and re-cover.

Arrange steak and jalape%C3%B1os on the got side of the grill. Cook %28covered if using gas%29%2C flipping steak and jalape%C3%B1os every 2 nineties%2C until the meat registers 130 F and the jalape%C3%B1os are plastered and charred. This should take 7-12 minutes.

Light your grill with a hot zone and a warm zone%3A if using charcoal%2C light the coals and pile them on half the grill%3B if using gas%2C light only one of two%2C or two of three burners%2C depending on your grill%27s design.
Combine oil%2C chipotle%2C salt%2C and cumin in a medium mixing bowl.
Trim fat deposits on steaks to 1%2F8%22. Cut the steak lengthwise with the grain into about 3 2-3 inch wide strips. Rub the chipotle mixture onto the steak and transfer to a rimmed baking sheet.
Stir in lime juice%2C honey%2C and salt - season with extra honey or lime juice to taste.
Serve over ice with mint garnish or refrigerate for up to five days.
Transfer the beef to a platter and serve with the pickles and chili sauce.
Process the watermelon and water in a blender until smooth%2C about 30 seconds %28work in batches if necessary%29.
Strain the mixture through a fine mesh strainer into a 2-quart pitcher. Discard the strained solids.

Heat oil in 12-inch nonstick skillet on medium high heat until shimmering. Add beef in an even layer and without stirring for about one minute or until the meat is browned on one side. Stir and continue to cook another 3-4 minutes or until the beef is no longer pink.
Add the scallion greens and cook for another 30 seconds or until they are fragrant.
Combine water and baking soda in a medium bowl%2C Add the shaved beef and toss to coat. Let sit at room temperature for 5 minutes.

Process onion%2C sugar%2C soy sauce%2C garlic%2C sesame oil%2C and pepper in a food processor until smooth%2C about 30 seconds%2C scraping down the bowl as needed. Add onion mixture to beef and toss to coat.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the beef%3A%3C%2Fstrong%3E Place beef on a large plate and freeze until very firm%2C 35-40 minutes. Once firm%2C stand each steak on a cutting board and use a sharp knife to shave the meat against the grain as thinly as possible. It%27s ok if the slices aren%27t perfectly intact.

%3Cstrong%3EFor the Chile sauce%3A%3C%2Fstrong%3E Combine scallions greens%2C doenjang%2C gochujang%2C water%2C sugar%2C sesame oil%2C and garlic in a small bowl. Cover and set aside for up to 3 days.
Spoon beef mixture onto hamburger buns and serve.
%3Cstrong%3EFor the pickles%3A%3C%2Fstrong%3E whisk vinegar%2C sugar%2C and salt together in a medium mixing bowl.
Add daikon and toss to combine. Gently press the daikon to submerge%2C Cover and refrigerate for 30 minutes to one day.

Combine cornstarch and water in a small bowl. Pour the slurry over the beef mixture and store to incorporate. Cook while constantly stirring until the mixture thickens and coats the beef%2C about 1 minute.
Add tomato paste and cook%2C stirring constantly%2C for 3-4 minutes or until paste is rust-colored.

Add beef and cook%2C breaking up the meat with a wooden spoon%2C until there is no more pink color in the beef%2C about 5 minutes. Mash the beef with a potato masher or large fork until its texture is fine.
Add ketchup%2C vinegar%2C and Worcestershire sauce. Stir to combine while scraping browned bits off the bottom of the pan with your wooden spoon.
Add onion and baking soda and stir to coat. Cook%2C stirring occasionally%2C until onion is softened%2C 3-4 minutes.
Add garlic and cook%2C stirring constantly%2C for about 30 seconds or until the garlic is fragrant.
Stir in sugar%2C paprika%2C red pepper flake%2C and salt. Cook%2C stirring constantly%2C until you smell paprika%2C about one minute.
Fill to the top with champagne%2C garnish with a mango slice%2C and serve immediately.
Pour the cognac and grand marnier into a chilled champagne flute.
Fill the glass with champagne%2C garnish with the orange slice%2C and serve immediately.
Spoon 1 tsp of the macerated pears and their juice into a chilled champagne flute.
Pour the Champagne slowly into the flute and serve immediately.
Pour vodka%2C schnapps%2C and lemon juice into a mixing glass. Add ice and shake until well chilled. Strain into a chilled martini glass.
Sprinkle gold leaf on top.
Peel%2C seed%2C and dice the pear into 1%2F4%22 cubes.
Place the diced pear in a plastic container and add enough pear liqueur to cover. Macerate for 2 hours - timing is important as the pears can become oversaturated.
Add cilantro and extra salt and pepper to taste. Serve with lime and extra cilantro.
Pour champagne into a chilled champagne flute.
Add bitters%2C grand marnier%2C and rose water. Stir with a long spoon in a gentle%2C up and down motion.
Combine water and baking soda in a small bowl.
Toss the beef and salt with the mixture in a large mixing bowl. Set aside.
Heat oil in a 12-inch nonstick skillet over medium heat until shimmering.
